Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the markets in which we operate and compete. Certain economic and industry data, market data and market forecasts set forth in this Offering Memorandum were extracted from market research, governmental and other publicly available information, independent industry publications and reports prepared by industry consultants, including an industry report (the “Industry Report”) prepared by a global consulting company. Industry reports, publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. We believe that these industry publications, surveys and forecasts, to the extent quoted or referred to herein, are reliable, but we have not independently verified them and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. While we accept responsibility for accurately summarizing the information from these external sources, and as far as we are aware and able to ascertain no facts have been omitted which would render this information inaccurate or misleading, we accept no further responsibility in respect of such information. Certain information and estimates in this Offering Memorandum, including without limitation, statements regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in the industry and our market share, as well as the expected growth of the market in which we operate and the relevant factors supporting such trend, has also been based on our own experience, internal studies, estimates and investigations of market conditions, in some cases combined with the aforementioned external sources. We cannot assure you that any of the assumptions we have made are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the market. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of this information. Such information and estimates involve risks and uncertainty and are subject to change based on various factors. See “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements”. Prospective investors should not place undue reliance on any forecasts presented in this Offering Memorandum and should make their own independent assessment of our future prospects and the risks relating to the markets in which we operate. All of the information set forth in this Offering Memorandum relating to the operations, financial results or market share of our competitors has been obtained from publicly available information or independent research. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified this information and cannot guarantee its accuracy. -----

We are a leading global design company in the high-end furniture and lighting markets. We design, produce, distribute and sell high-end lighting and furniture solutions. We offer our products through three core companies with leading positions in the global high-end design market: Flos, an Italian lighting brand, Louis Poulsen, a Danish lighting brand, and B&B, an Italian group comprising several leading furniture brands (B&B Italia, Maxalto, Azucena and Arclinea). Our Core Brands are complemented by our three Emerging Brands, which have growing relevance in the global high-end lighting, accessories and furniture markets: Lumens, a U.S. digital ecommerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture which we acquired in June 2021, Fendi Casa, an Italian furniture, lighting and home accessories brand and operated through our joint venture with high-end luxury brand Maison Fendi, which commenced operations in January 2022, and Audo, a Danish furniture, lighting and accessories brand which we acquired in May 2022. For the twelve months ended June 30, 23, we had total revenue of €857.3 million, Adjusted EBITDA of €218.4 million, net profit of €41.1 million and Adjusted EBITDA Margin above 25% and, as of June 30, 2023, we had 2,171 employees. Since our incorporation in 2018, we have successfully created a one-stop shop for high-quality design furniture and lighting products for both individuals and businesses around the world. We benefit from a well-balanced and diversified portfolio resulting from the combination of unique brand heritage and iconic products of each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B Italia and those of our Emerging Brands, and provide a complementary, high-end offering across a broad range of product categories, brands, sales channels and geographic areas. As part of our business model, Design Holding provides the strategic direction necessary for the continued development of our business, while acting as a “center of excellence” across key capabilities. Through its coordinating activities, Design Holding sets the vision and strategic direction of the Group and establishes the necessary guidelines and coordination among our brands, in particular in the areas of finance, control, legal affairs, governance, human resources management, business strategy and digital strategies. In particular, we believe the role of Design Holding in coordinating our efforts among our distribution channels with the aim to foster the growth of our brands is of paramount importance and has been one of the key contributors to our success. Design Holding also facilitates the adoption of consistent Group policies and operating processes, with a particular focus on environmental, social and corporate governance (“ESG”) matters. The following charts set forth a breakdown of our gross merchandise value (“GMV”) for the year ended December 31, 2022 by brand and product category, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022:

(1) Includes the B&B Italia, Maxalto, Arclinea and Azucena brands. (2) Includes the Lumens, Fendi Casa and Audo brands. ----- As a global design company, we offer our high-end lighting and furniture products to a diversified customer base of individual consumers, architects, designers and other specifiers for residential use and businesses around the globe for commercial use through an omni-channel approach comprising four key sales channels: (i) _Contract. Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services for residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom-made products, as well as certain complementary products from third-party producers; (ii) _Direct E-Commerce. Our direct e-commerce channel consists of our e-commerce websites selling in approximately 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our U.S. online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products; (iii) _Directly-Operated Stores (“DOS”). Our DOS channel comprises retail stores that are directly managed by us and sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands; and (iv) _Wholesale. Our wholesale channel comprises over 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale, operated by third parties, located around the world in a range of formats, including mono-brand stores, shop-in-shops and multi-brand stores, as well as 1,122 e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure players in e-commerce. Our contract, DOS and e-commerce channels represent our “direct-to-customer” channels, which allow us to directly reach our end-customers with a flexible, tailor-made and cost-efficient approach adapted to a rapidly evolving market. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by sales channel, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: We operate directly or indirectly in more than 130 countries around the world. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by geography, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: Our products are distinguished by their design content, combining innovation and technology with the rich design heritage that characterizes the Italian and Danish traditions. Each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B maintains a portfolio of iconic products, a number of which have been popular for more than 50 years and were created in collaboration with some of the most prestigious designers in the world, including Antonio Citterio, Gaetano Pesce, Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, Philippe Starck, Poul Henningsen and Arne Jacobsen. Our products have received numerous global design awards and are held in the permanent collections of art and design museums worldwide, including in the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, Le Centre Pompidou in Paris and La Triennale di Milano in Milan. Our Core Brands ----- are complemented by the over 400 brands (including third-party brands) sold by Lumens through its U.S. ecommerce website, the prestigious Fendi Casa brand, which is the result of our joint venture with Maison Fendi, and The Audo, Menu and ByLassen (now merged into the Audo brand), our Nordic-design furniture and lighting brands, which draw upon both historical design archives and collaborations with new designers. Throughout our history, our strong relationships with prestigious designers and our ability to attract up-and-coming design talents coupled with our continuous efforts in technology and product development have enabled us to complement our heritage collection with successful new products that have reinforced the growth of each of our brands over the years. Since our early years of operation, we have also shown attention to sustainability, as demonstrated by the publication of sustainability reports by Flos and B&B since 2015 and 2016, respectively, and by Louis Poulsen since 2019, and the publication of the first Group Sustainability Report in 2021. Sustainability is key to our business and our brands are committed to being recognized as leaders in adopting sustainable policies and practices and in developing a new concept of luxury high-end design that has sustainability at its core. The Group achieved carbon neutrality (scope 1 and 2) in 2020. Our commitment to sustainability is founded on the following three principles: (i) Design for Planet, (ii) Design for People and (iii) Design for Culture. For more information on our ESG initiatives, achievements and goals, see “Our Business—ESG Initiatives”.

Subsubsection Title: Leadership position and strong track record of prestigious industry awards in the attractive luxury design market with highly attractive growth prospects
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global design company in the highly fragmented and attractive core high-end design market, with €857.3 million in total revenue, Adjusted EBITDA of €218.4 million and net profit of €41.1 million, in each case for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We believe that we are approximately 1.2 times larger than our closest competitor, almost 2 times larger than our second closest competitor and 3.2 to 3.8 times larger than our third through fifth closest competitors, in each case based on 2022 revenues and our analysis of publicly available financial data for such year. Despite our size, our reference market is highly fragmented. We focus on the luxury segment of the core high-end design market, characterized by rich product heritage, strong and globally recognized brands, iconic products, superior craftmanship, brand exclusivity and premiumness. We estimate our market share to be approximately 4% based on 2022 revenues and our analysis of publicly available financial data for such year, implying a tangible opportunity to further consolidate our market share by expanding in underpenetrated geographies. Many of our brands and products have received various international design accolades and the highest industry awards throughout their history, including 16 Compasso d’Oro awards (including the Compasso d’Oro Product Lifetime Achievement Award awarded to Flos’ Arco lamp in 2020), the first of which in 1955 and the last of which in 2022, NYCxDesign Award, IF Gold Award, IF Design Award, FX Interior Design Awards, Danish Design Award, German Design Award, Elle Deco International Design Award and Lighting Design Award. Our products are held in the permanent collections of art and design museums such as the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, Le Centre Pompidou in Paris, the Design Museum in Copenhagen, La Triennale di Milano in Milan and the Today Art Museum in Beijing, confirming the excellence, renown and appeal of our designs. We estimate that in 2022 the luxury design market (a subset of the global luxury market), which is our focus market, represented approximately 63% (valued at approximately €31 billion in that same period) of the total core high-end design market, with the remaining approximately 37% represented by the premium design market (valued at approximately €16 billion in that same period), typically addressed by branded retailers and premium design brands. The global luxury market grew at a CAGR of 6% between 2014 and 2019 and 3% between 2019 and 2022, reaching €1.4 trillion in 2022, while the global core high-end design market grew at a CAGR of 5% between 2014 and 2019 and 7% between 2019 and 2022, notwithstanding a moderate contraction in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The global core high-end design market exceeded pre-pandemic levels already in 2021, reaching €40 billion in such year (compared to €38 billion in 2019 and €35 billion in 2020), continued to grow in 2022, reaching €47 billion, and is estimated to further grow between 2022 and 2026 at a CAGR of between 2% and 5%, reaching approximately €50 to €60 billion in 2026. For 2023, temporary headwinds are expected to affect the global core high-end design market, while the mid-term outlook remains broadly unchanged. Between 2014 to 2022, we outperformed our reference market by increasing our revenues at a CAGR of 9% for each period, which enabled us to reinforce our market positioning, notwithstanding a moderate contraction in 2020 due to the COVID 19 pandemic. Our CAGR for these periods was calculated on the basis of like-for-like growth of certain of our acquired brands beginning from the year of their respective acquisition (namely, Flos in 2014, B&B in 2015, Louis Poulsen in 2018 and Lumens in 2021). ----- The growth of the high-end design market is driven by certain structural tailwinds, including (i) the increasing working time that people spend in their homes (estimated to be approximately 3.5 days per week in 2022, compared to approximately 2.6 days per week prior to COVID-19 pandemic), with approximately 98% of workers indicating that they prefer to work remotely, in part due to the change of work habits resulting from the COVID19 pandemic, (ii) the increased use of home offices (with approximately 60% of the people working from home estimated to have a dedicated home office space) and the increasingly important role played by kitchens, which are often considered the heart of the home (with approximately 60% of kitchen renovators having upgraded or added a kitchen island), (iii) the global GDP increase driven by infrastructure renovation (estimated to have contributed approximately 20% of the global GDP growth from 2010 to 2020), (iv) wealth ruralization, which has caused migration of wealth to rural communities and countryside, thereby increasing the demand for high-end design products (with over 50% of adults estimated to prefer living in small towns and rural areas compared to approximately 39% in 2018), and (v) the urbanization trends and associated economic growth in emerging markets, in particular China and India, with an urbanization index estimated to reach approximately 116 and 113, respectively, in 2025 (compared to approximately 100 for both countries in 2016). In addition, the high-end design market is characterized by smaller competitors, making us one of the few design groups that can serve a diverse customer base across a variety of product and service categories and geographies, enabling us to benefit from cross-selling initiatives and giving us the opportunity to grow through selected strategic acquisitions in the segments where we currently operate or in complementary adjacent segments. See “Our Strategies—Pursue _strategic acquisition opportunities that align with our overall goals and objectives”._

Subsubsection Title: Balanced and highly resilient portfolio of iconic designs and new products generating a predictable revenue mix
Subsubsection Text: Our internationally-acclaimed product portfolios represent a balance between timeless heritage designs and innovative products. Certain iconic designs have become synonymous with our brands and continue to attract significant customer demand decades after being introduced. We believe that maintaining these products in our portfolio helps to limit the effect of market trends and improves our revenue resiliency. Our internal research and product development teams work closely with our designers to continually update and reconfigure iconic pieces to meet the evolving needs and tastes of our customers while maintaining the identity of each of our brands and the distinctive original features that loyal customers worldwide have long associated with our products. Moreover, to further support the success of our most iconic designs and refresh existing and new customers’ interest in our products, from time to time, we also launch new special or limited editions of our heritage products, such as Flos’ Arco K lamp in 2022 with an innovative crystal base, B&B Italia’s Le Bambole x Stella McCartney in 2023, as a result of a collaboration with the renowned English stylist, and PH Pale Rose, a special edition collection of Louis Poulsen’s PH lamps designed in 1926, which we launched in 2022. We also launch new products on an ongoing basis to complement our portfolio of heritage designs and our design portfolio also comprises numerous unexploited heritage designs from prestigious international designers that have not been commercialized before, which we believe represents an important growth opportunity for our Group. For example, we estimate that Louis Poulsen, Audo, B&B and Flos have a significant archive with unexploited designs from heritage designers dating back to the 1950s and 1970s. Between 2020 and 2023, our brands have reintroduced several heritage designs from their archives, including “Camaleonda” and “Scacchi” from B&B Italia, certain versions of “La Lampadina” by Flos, and the “PH Septima Pendant” and “PH 2/2 Question” from Louis Poulsen. Our efforts in research and product development and innovation in both design and technology ensure both the longevity of our iconic products and the continued introduction of creative and successful new designs, all of which ensures a balanced and predictable revenue mix. The following chart sets forth the revenue of B&B Italia, Maxalto, Flos and Louis Poulsen for the year ended December 31, 2022, divided by launch year of the products that these brands sold in such year (i.e. before 2010, between 2010 and 2017 and between 2018 and 2022). ----- Our revenue mix is well balanced relative to the year of launch of the various products we sell in any given period. We believe that such balanced revenue mix, coupled with the significant contribution of made-to-order sales to our total sales, gives us good visibility of our expected revenue streams in the short term (approximately eight weeks for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, providing estimated revenue visibility of approximately two months for our made-to-order products).

Subsubsection Title: Unique brand power based on design heritage, iconic products, long-standing relationships with top designers and loyal networks of specifiers in local markets
Subsubsection Text: Our business benefits from significant competitive advantages that make our business model difficult to replicate, including our iconic product portfolio, design heritage, long-standing relationships with top designers and specifiers and strong technical know-how. Our iconic brands benefit from association with a broad base of (i) prestigious and globally renowned designers, such as Mario Bellini, Antonio Citterio, Vincent Van Duysen, Piero Lissoni, Philippe Starck, Jasper Morrison, Gaetano Pesce, Olafur Eliasson, Patricia Urquiola, Nendo, Michael Anastassiades, Konstantin Grcic, Naoto Fukusawa, Barber & Osgerby, Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec and Formafantasma; (ii) heritage designers, such as Tobia Scarpa, Poul Henningsen, Arne Jacobsen, Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, Gino Sarfatti, Mogens Lassen, Flemming Lassen and Verner Panton; and (iii) talented emerging designers, such as Chiara Andreatti, Anne Boysen, Joris Laarman, Gabriel Tan, Øivind Alexander Slaatto and Peter Mabeo. Many of our designer partners have received multiple awards and recognitions for their designs and have their designs held in the collections of museums around the world. We believe our privileged relationships with renowned designers and our ability to attract new promising designers represent a significant competitive advantage. Some of our designers have collaborated with our brands for many years, creating a strong design relationship and mutual understanding of the needs and preferences of our customer base. Our relationship with designers is mutually beneficial, as it allows us to expand our brand recognition across a wider customer demographic and adds value for the designers, who gain prestige and visibility by working with leading furniture and lighting brands. Designers collaborate closely with our internal research and product development teams, which have accumulated extensive technical expertise and industry knowledge over decades and continually support our design innovation. The research and product development teams add substantial value to designers, providing an extensive knowledge base on product feasibility with respect to design, materials and market success; research on the latest trends, materials and technological innovations; design and development support for concepts, prototypes and molds; negotiation support with suppliers to ensure high component quality standards at competitive prices; and centralized assembly process and production planning. In addition, management teams at each of our brands ensure that any new design that is being proposed or considered internally is fully consistent with the relevant brand’s image and philosophy, which we believe is key to the success of any product and the continued integrity of our brands. In addition to our ability to attract and maintain relationships with world-renowned designers, we also benefit from strong relationships with a widespread network of specifiers, especially smaller, committed professional design and architecture studios that continually choose and promote our products to meet the design needs of their clients. We consider these specifiers, which we define as any party that is involved in the purchasing decision but is not the end user of our products, including but not limited to architects, interior designers, lighting engineers and landscape architects, a loyal and resilient customer intermediary that, through repeat business, provides us ----- with a significant competitive advantage locally in the geographic markets we serve and add to our recognition with end customers.

Subsubsection Title: Diversified business model across product categories, geographies and distribution channels with low customer concentration risk
Subsubsection Text: Our business is well diversified across product categories, geographies and distribution channels. We offer a broad and diversified portfolio of products addressing the full spectrum of our customers’ requirements and we believe we are not dependent on any specific product category. Our product offering is comprised of two product categories, lighting and furniture, which accounted for 64.0% and 34.1% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively, giving _pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022. The lighting category includes our decorative, architectural and outdoor products, which accounted for 27.0%, 11.1% and 5.7% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively). The furniture category includes our living room and bedroom furniture and kitchen products (which accounted for 19.6% and 4.0% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively). Geographically, our business benefits from a balanced and diversified reach, with more than 130 countries served. The United States and Italy, as individual countries, represent the two largest contributors to our sales and accounted for 23.7% and 14.2% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively. Customers outside of our home geographies of Italy and Denmark generated approximately 79.3% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, and approximately 26.0% of our GMV for such period was generated from sales in North America which were mainly attributable to Lumens, our digital e-commerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture in the United States, which we acquired in 2021. We expect the APAC region and North America to continue to drive growth, with consistent demand also expected in our home geographies and Western Europe. We also benefit from a diversified distribution network comprised of four distribution channels (contract, ecommerce, DOS and wholesale), enabling us to reach a broad range of customers. We expect our omni-channel distribution network will continue to represent a key contributor to our growth, driven in particular by our ecommerce business, which grew from €3.9 million of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 (or 0.7% of our revenue from contracts with customers in such year) to €103.7 million of revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (or 12.2% of our revenue from contracts with customers for such period), mainly as a result of the acquisition of our U.S. based e-commerce platform Lumens in 2021. For further details on our distribution channels, see “—Sophisticated omni-channel distribution network focused on DTC and branded channels, _optimizing customer reach and maximizing brand strength”._ In addition to a diversified mix of product categories, geographies and distribution channels, we benefit from low customer concentration risk. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our top 20 customers generated 18.9% of our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Sophisticated omni-channel distribution network focused on DTC and branded channels, optimizing customer reach and maximizing brand strength
Subsubsection Text: Our distribution network is comprised of three direct-to-customer (“DTC”) channels (contract, DOS and ecommerce) and the wholesale channel. For the year ended December 31, 2022, the wholesale channel generated approximately 47.2%, the contract channel approximately 24.5%, the DOS network approximately 5.7% and ecommerce sales approximately 22.6% of our GMV, respectively. Our omni-channel approach allows us to reach a wide range of diversified customers both directly via our contract, DOS and e-commerce channels, and indirectly via our wholesale channel through a variety of intermediate players, including dealers, resellers, retailers and an extensive network of approximately 350,000 loyal specifiers, including architects and designers serving the local markets where we are present, which in our experience have a high degree of influence over the end customers purchase decisions. We believe our omni-channel distribution network optimizes customer reach and maximizes the strength of our brands. _Contract_ Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services to customers that are not typically accessible through traditional retail outlets, including residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom made products, as well as certain complementary products from third party producers. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our contract channel has approximately 12,000 projects in pipeline. Among some of the notable recent projects completed by the Contract division are the One Thousand Museum Residences by Zaha Hadid Architects in Miami, The Polaris Lounge by Studio SCB Chicago and the Bulgari Hotel in Tokyo and Rome by Antonio Citterio and Patricia Viel. We believe the wide variety of commercial ----- customers and the larger scale of contract projects make our contract channel a strong vehicle for cross-selling opportunities, increasing the visibility of the products from all our brands and our market penetration. Although a large proportion of contract work is currently driven by B&B, the combination of our brands has provided us with the opportunity to broaden the scope of our contract work, offering a floor-to-ceiling contract service encompassing furnishings from B&B, kitchens from Arclinea and lighting products from Flos and Louis Poulsen. _DOS_ Our DOS channel is a powerful marketing tool that drives brand awareness, allows full control over our brands and often provides enhanced visibility to our end customers. It comprises retail stores that sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands, thereby increasing cross selling opportunities by giving our customers the opportunity to purchase such products. As an example, our new DOS in Boston, Massachusetts, sells products from our B&B Italia, Maxalto and Arclinea brands. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our DOS channel includes 19 stores managed directly by our Group companies, all located in key luxury markets around the world in cities such as Milan, London, New York, Paris and Hong Kong. DOS and directly-operated showrooms are a highly valuable distribution channel as they not only drive sales, but also increase brand strength, serving as a hub for marketing events and design fairs. _E-Commerce_ Our e-commerce channel consists of our e-commerce websites selling in 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our U.S. online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products. _Wholesale_ Our wholesale channel includes 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale throughout the world, managed by third parties, in various different formats, with a special focus on (i) mono-brand stores (137), accounting for 6.9% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022; (ii) shop-in-shops (875), accounting for 9.0% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022; and (iii) multi-brand stores (4,490), accounting for 21.2% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022. We classify the mono-brand and shop-in-shop stores as the branded segment of our wholesale channel as our brands in those stores are clearly identifiable by the end-customers. The wholesale channel also includes e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure players in e-commerce (approximately 1,122), accounting for 10.1% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022. The wholesale channel enables us to increase customer reach while limiting distribution costs. We benefit from long-standing customer relationships within our wholesale channel, with many of our dealers having sold products from our respective brands for several years.

Subsubsection Title: Flexible and robust industrial platform with control over entire value chain
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have ten in-house production facilities, differentiated by brand and product type, each of which focuses on the most critical and delicate processing phases to ensure the highest quality of our products. Specifically, we operate seven production facilities in Italy (two of which are located in Misinto (Milan), dedicated to B&B Italia and Fendi Casa, respectively), one in Valencia (Spain), one in Vejen (Denmark) and one in New York. Each facility is dedicated to a single brand’s production. As of June 30, 2023, our production facilities were supported by a network of approximately 1,950 carefully selected and diversified external suppliers located throughout the world and typically in close proximity to our inhouse production facilities, many of whom have been longstanding partners of ours. The following chart shows the composition of our suppliers by geographical area as of December 31, 2022: ----- For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, approximately 44% of our production was carried out in house at our production facilities (typically relating to the most critical components of our products), while the remainder of our production (fabrication or assembly) was carried out through suppliers and partners outside the Group. This approach enables us to combine high levels of flexibility and scalability of production levels with the maintenance of high-quality standards and, coupled with our make-to-order driven footprint (with approximately 69% of our total production relating to make-to-order purchases for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023), allows us to have strong control over the entire value chain, from initial design of the product to supply and in-house production or outsourced production, as applicable, assembly of the finished product and transportation and logistics.

Subsubsection Title: Predictable revenues coupled with asset light, variable cost base and limited working capital requirements and strong cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: Our production is mainly focused on sales of made-to-order products, in particular that associated with our furniture, which represented approximately 69% of our total production for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, with the remainder being made-to-stock products. Our made-to-order sales typically have upfront payment terms, with approximately 30% to 50% of the final product price being paid by customers at the time of the order confirmation and the remaining approximately 70% to 50%, as applicable, being paid upon delivery. The significant contribution of our made-to-order sales to our total sales gives us visibility of our expected revenue streams in the short term (approximately eight weeks for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, providing revenue visibility of approximately two months for our made-to-order products). Where we do not operate on a made-to-order basis, we benefit from limited inventory risk given the long lifespan of our products. Our business, which is asset light by nature, also has a predominantly variable cost base. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we estimate that approximately 68% of our operating expenses was represented by variable costs. Our cash flow generation is in turn supported by low working capital and capital expenditure requirements. Our net operating working capital was €69.9 million as of June 30, 2023 (representing 8.2% of our total revenues for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023), €46.9 million as of December 31, 2022 (representing 5.5% of our total revenues for such year), €3.3 million as of December 31, 2021 (representing 0.5% of our total revenues for such year) (exceptionally low mainly due to the acquisition of Lumens in 2021), and €33.9 million as of December 31, 2020 (representing 6.4% of our total revenues for such year), resulting in limited working capital requirements. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively, capital expenditures represented only 4.7%, 4.6%, 5.1% and 4.3% of our total revenues for such periods, of which the majority represented discretionary growth capital expenditures. We have historically enjoyed strong cash flow generation through the economic cycle, including during the 20082010 global financial crisis, the European sovereign debt crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic, supported by our high profitability levels and limited capital expenditure requirements. We have also historically recorded stable Adjusted EBITDA Margin and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, we delivered consistently high Adjusted EBITDA Margins above 25% for each relevant period, despite the Emerging Brands having delivered lower margins than our Core Brands for these periods, mainly in light of the initial phase of their development. For the six months ended June 30, 2022 and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, our Pro Forma Revenue was €426.5 million, €700.3 million and €867.6 million, respectively (in each case giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Lumens, as regards 2021, and Audo, as regards 2022, as if we had acquired them on January 1 of the relevant year). The revenue of Flos for the year ended December 31, 2014, the year of its acquisition, was €159.2 million. For the same periods, our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was €102.2 million, €194.6 million and €219.3 million, respectively, and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 24.0%, 27.2% and 25.3%, respectively. Our Free Cash Flow (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant period minus Maintenance Capital Expenditure for such period) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020 was €208.0 million, €206.6 million, €175.0 million and €133.2 million, resulting in Free Cash Flow Conversion (calculated as the ratio of Free Cash Flow for the relevant period to Adjusted EBITDA for such period) for each such period of 95.2%, 94.7%, 91.8% and 93.0%, respectively. We believe that our brand strength gives us strong pricing power, typically allowing us to pass the effects of increased raw material and component costs or adverse exchange rate fluctuations to our customers. Since our incorporation upon the joint acquisition by entities affiliated with Carlyle and Investindustrial of Flos, B&B Italia and Louis Poulsen in 2018, we have been able to reduce our net leverage from approximately 5.4x at the time of the acquisition (calculated at that time as the ratio of net financial indebtedness to (pre-IFRS 16) “Target Group Synergized EBITDA”) to 4.4x as of June 30, 2023 (calculated as the ratio of net financial indebtedness to Adjusted EBITDA, as presented in this Offering Memorandum). -----

Subsubsection Title: Experienced management team backed by a strong holding structure and committed shareholders
Subsubsection Text: All the Group companies operate under the strategic guidance of the highly dedicated and experienced management team and the board of directors of Design Holding. Our Group Chief Executive Officer Daniel Lalonde, who joined the Group in October 2021, and our Group Chief Financial Officer Alberto Toni, who joined the Group in May 2023, have brought a wealth of experience and an exceptional track record, further strengthening our role as an industry leader. In addition to the Group CEO and CFO roles, over the past few years, Design Holding has further reinforced its holding structure through the hires of a Group Strategy, M&A & Business Development Director, Group Chief Digital Officer, Group Human Resources Director, Group Contract Director, Group General Counsel, Group Marketing Director and Group E-commerce Manager. All of our recently hired personnel have long-standing experience and proven track-record in their respective fields, with over 20 years of experience on average per each member of the management team. See “Management”. Additionally, the executive teams at each of our brands are highly experienced in leading and growing successful design businesses, with relevant prior experience at large international companies. This experienced management team is backed by our principal shareholders, Investindustrial and Carlyle, each of which, directly or through its affiliates, has successfully invested in the design and luxury industries both in Europe and worldwide. We believe that our current management team and ownership structure will allow us to continue to attract and retain the industry’s top talent, further driving profitable growth. See “Principal Shareholders”.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance the desirability and strength of our brands
Subsubsection Text: Leveraging on our existing portfolio of high-end lighting and furniture solutions, we intend to further enhance the desirability of our brands through a series of initiatives. We aim to continue to attract up-and-coming international design talents and seek new collaborations with renowned stylists, fashion maisons and other players in the highend luxury industry to both develop new attractive and innovative products and reinforce the strength of our existing heritage designs, through for example the launch of new limited editions of our timeless iconic products. Our collaboration with English stylist Stella McCartney in 2023 for the development of B&B Italia’s Le Bambole x Stella McCartney is an example of how the close cooperation with top international brands in the high-end Luxury industry can reinforce the strength of our existing heritage designs. In addition, Louis Poulsen’s collaboration with talented emerging architect and designer Anne Boysen led to the production of the Moonsetter lamp, which was the winning design in the Next Danish Design Classic competition broadcast on national Danish television in 2020 and received the Lamp of the Year Award at the Design Awards in 2021. Another example of recent successful cooperation with a talented emerging designer is the Kompa Collection, designed by Botswanan Peter Mabeo for Fendi Casa, merging traditional African artisanship with luxury design. Going forward, we believe the enhancement of the desirability of our brands will also be increasingly dependent on our ability to deliver innovative products with a sustainability focus, including through eco-design, which considers environmental aspects at all stages of the product development process, in an effort to develop design solutions which make the lowest possible environmental impact throughout the product life cycle. For example, in 2023, we launched several eco-design projects, including Céramique, Emi, Bilboquet, Black Flag and Workmates for Flos, Eryt, Tortello Heri ‘O, Nooch and Cordoba Outdoor for B&B Italia, and Arclinea’s “g_cover” innovative new finishing, which is made with the recycled by-product from the manufacturing process of man-made graphite, enhancing the durability of Arclinea’s kitchens. We also intend to continue to support our younger brands through the various development phases and, in particular, we seek to accelerate the growth trajectory of our brands which are currently in their start-up phase, such Audo and Azucena, and development phase, such as Fendi Casa, Maxalto, Lumens and Arclinea, and to continue to develop new products. In order to continue to strengthen the desirability of our brands, we expect to continue to coordinate our marketing and advertising efforts through a single and pre-defined strategy for the Group, focusing on the creation of compelling contents, the prioritization of digital and social media for our advertisement campaigns and a deeper comprehension of our customers’ preferences and behaviors through dedicated customer relationship management (“CRM”) tools. -----

Subsubsection Title: Expand our geographic reach with focus on the United States and Greater China
Subsubsection Text: We plan to strategically expand our geographic reach in markets where we expect to see continued growth, particularly outside of Europe. In particular, we aim to concentrate our focus on North America and Greater China, where we believe there is the greatest growth potential. As part of our strategy to expand in the United States, in 2021, we acquired Lumens, our U.S. based online platform which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products. This acquisition materially boosted both e-commerce sales and sales in the Americas, which grew from €3.9 million and €74.9 million in 2020, respectively, to €103.7 million and €225.3 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, respectively. We believe the U.S. market is still underpenetrated and plan to continue to leverage on Lumens and our network of architects and designers to increase our sales in the region. Key growth initiatives in the United States will include: (i) expanding our architects and designers network through CRM and other digital tools and marketing events across brands; (ii) increasing the number of points of sales with a focus on space branding (mono-brand and shop-in-shop); (iii) selectively opening new stores in key locations with high growth potential, including New York, Miami and Boston; (iv) accelerating our contract channel expansion in the hospitality and retail space; and (v) optimizing the regional supply chain in our lighting business (both production and logistics). Moreover, the expansion in the Greater China region is one of our strategic priorities and, to that end, we have appointed a CEO Greater China at the Design Holding Level who oversees the commercial efforts in the region, including the opening of local stores, the roll-out of mono-brand stores with local partners and a digital-led marketing strategy to generate brand awareness and support distribution of products in the area. In 2022, we incorporated a new subsidiary in Shanghai, Design Holding (Shanghai) Co. Ltd., to facilitate our expansion in the region. We have the opportunity to establish our brands as pioneers in the region, especially in light of the still underdeveloped knowledge of the luxury design market among customers. Key growth initiatives in Greater China will include: (i) the creation of a Greater China Business Unit with its own sales and marketing teams and a dedicated e-commerce website; (ii) increasing wholesale distribution in key urban areas through mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops; (iii) selectively opening new stores (including via the B&B Italia Design Studio format) in key locations with high growth potential, such as Shanghai; and (iv) accelerating marketing activities and digital penetration through dedicated platforms. We also plan to expand our reach in the Middle East, Korea and Japan.

Subsubsection Title: Shift focus towards DTC and “branded” channels, develop our store network and foster growth of our online segment
Subsubsection Text: One of our key strategic goals is to grow our DTC distribution channels, which typically allow us to exercise greater control over pricing of our products and be closer to our end customers, in particular by supporting the migration of end customers in our wholesale channel (e.g., consumers walking into third-party managed multibrand or mono-brand stores or shop-in-shops or customers purchasing our products from online resellers) to either our DOS or in-house e-commerce platforms. Growth initiatives for our DOS channel will include (i) the selected roll out of B&B Italia, Fendi Casa and Flos / Louis Poulsen DOS in key cities with high growth potential; (ii) the enhancement of retail customer experience across our network through sales personnel excellence; and (iii) increased focus on our architects and designers network to drive qualified traffic into our DOS. Growth initiatives for our e-commerce channel will include (i) the launch of new limited editions, collaborations and other exclusive products or e-marketing campaigns; (ii) the enhancement of digital services available to architects and industry professionals, which raise our profile and support our success across the value chain from the creation of the designs, to the development of the products and the final distribution to customers; and (iii) offer premium services to our e-customers in connection with product delivery and installation. In our wholesale channel, our main efforts will focus on the “brandization” of wholesale spaces through the increase in the number of mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops and, wherever possible, the increase of in-store space, as well as the selective expansion in luxury department stores.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance leadership position in high-end contract business
Subsubsection Text: We intend to selectively accelerate the growth of our contract business in attractive sectors with high growth potential, such as the high-end residential, hospitality and office sectors, and expand our contract channel in selected underpenetrated geographies, such as North America and Greater China. Our contract channel played a key role in the recent projects relating to the Bulgari Hotel in Rome and Tokyo and the One Thousand Museum Residences by Zaha Hadid Architects in Miami, as regards our Arclinea and B&B Italia brands, as well as the Bourse du Commerce in Paris, as regards our Flos brand. ----- Key growth initiatives include: (i) improvement of the contract business capillarity by expanding the pipeline in specific regions (United States, China and the Middle East) and segments (residential, hospitality, retail and office for lighting); and (ii) increase synergies with other brands of the Group, increasing average project value and accelerating business generation by adding sister brands to projects and boosting cross-brand penetration on identified top accounts. We also plan to increase “soft” contract retail business opportunities within our DOS network by targeting retail customers and their specifiers in connection with smaller projects than the projects traditionally developed by our contract business. Soft contract projects may entail, for example, the supply of integrated furniture and lighting products to private individuals in connection with the construction or refurbishment of their homes or vacation houses. We believe the required cooperation with our customers in the development of these projects helps us build closer relationships with them.

Subsubsection Title: Significant opportunity from new procurement cost saving initiatives under implementation
Subsubsection Text: One of our key operational priorities, along with maintaining and improving our high quality standards, is to continue the deployment of cost synergies from the creation of Design Holding and the further consolidation of our Group and coordination among our brands. In particular, we have identified a number of procurement optimization opportunities across both direct and indirect procurement categories, which we currently expect will deliver run-rate annual cost savings for an aggregate estimated amount of €17.8 million in the next three to four years, with approximately 43% of these savings estimated to be achieved by 2024 (€1.4 million in 2023 and €6.2 million in 2024) and the remainder in 2025 (€6.6 million) and 2026 (€3.6 million). We expect to incur one-off costs in order to achieve these cost savings of approximately €3 million between 2023 and the first half of 2024 related to the fees charged by the external consultant we have engaged in connection with the implementation of these procurement optimization initiatives. In the case of direct procurement, the identified initiatives relate to the procurement of semi-finished and finished products and raw materials. With respect to semi-finished and finished products, initiatives include the application of best-practice contracting methods and negotiations with suppliers, leveraging price transparency, should-cost analyses and win-win strategies, as well as improved visibility over prices applied by competing suppliers. With respect to raw materials, we intend to increase the competition among our suppliers (including by approaching competing suppliers and reviewing the existing supplier base) to obtain immediate or retroactive price decreases. We currently estimate that our cost savings and efficiency initiatives in the direct procurement category have the potential of delivering €9.4 million of run-rate annual cost savings in the next three to four years. In the case of indirect procurement, the identified initiatives relate to: (i) logistics and facility management, where we intend to call for tenders of regional logistics services with volume bundles over common routes, as well as renegotiate existing contractual arrangements; (ii) marketing and sales, where we intend to consolidate our expenditures by bundling our products into a single unit, apply demand management and leverage marketing benchmarks; (iii) professional services, where we intend to bundle demand, select preferred suppliers, review and renegotiate contracts and disable unused licenses; (iv) information technology and communication, where we intend to reduce costs by bundling hardware and software volumes, using benchmarks to increase supplier competition and renegotiating contracts; (v) packaging, where we intend to reduce costs by calling for tenders, leveraging value engineering and harmonizing specifications; and (vi) other indirect categories (e.g. R&D activities, mobility and travel, maintenance, repair and operations, etc.), where we intend to achieve cost savings by performing structured procurement activities, such as harmonization, bundling, benchmarking, standardization and negotiation. In addition, we launched the optimization of our insurance coverage by way of coordinated policy management and alignment of risk management across our brands. We currently estimate that our cost savings and efficiency initiatives in the indirect procurement category have the potential of delivering €8.4 million of run-rate annual cost savings in the next three to four years.

Subsubsection Title: Pursue strategic acquisition opportunities that align with our overall goals and objectives
Subsubsection Text: Although we are currently focused on delivering organic growth by further developing and consolidating our brands, our global footprint and diverse product portfolio create opportunities for acquisitions of selected and profitable brands in the high-end design market or adjacent markets that may bolster or complement our existing offering and geographical footprint. We are open to considering and we constantly scrutinize additional strategic acquisitions, some of which could be significant in size, to add to our portfolio, capitalize on our competitive strengths, expand our geographic footprint and reach in jurisdictions, including outside of Europe, where we see potential growth opportunities and/or where we currently have limited operations, further diversify our product offering, preserve or improve our financial performance and/or benefit from further consolidation expected in the design industry. Any further potential acquisition opportunities will be evaluated in light of a prudent and rigorous ----- analysis to preserve a solid financial position and high profitability. We will continue to apply a disciplined approach to pricing in connection with these potential acquisitions and will place significant emphasis on carefully planning and executing our acquisition strategy. As part of this strategy and to the extent possible, we will aim to use the investments we have already made in our IT, finance, operational, governance and business processes to reduce costs associated with on-boarding acquired businesses and will aim to utilize these synergies to benefit the entire Group.
The key elements of our strategy are:

The Issuer is beneficially owned by Investindustrial and Carlyle. The Investindustrial group is a leading European investment and advisory group with over €13 billion of raised fund capital, which provides industrial solutions and capital to European high-quality mid-market companies. Founded in 1990 from an industrial conglomerate, the Investindustrial group operates with a deeply rooted approach to ESG issues and the support of one cohesive team of approximately 150 professionals with independently managed investment and advisory companies in Lugano, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Paris, New York and Shanghai. The Investindustrial group is mainly focused on the following sectors: Healthcare & Services, Industrial Manufacturing, Consumer & Leisure and Technology. Companies in the Investindustrial group are managed independently from each other and funds are managed in the exclusive interest of their own limited partners. Founded in 1987, Carlyle is a global alternative asset manager and one of the world’s largest global private equity firms with approximately $385 billion of assets under management across 576 vehicles as of June 30, 2023. Carlyle invests across three business segments—Global Private Equity, Global Credit and Global Investment Solutions—in Africa, Asia, Australia, Europe, the Middle East, North America and South America. Carlyle has expertise in various industries, including technology, media and telecommunications, aerospace, defense and government services, consumer and retail, energy, financial services, healthcare, industrial, real estate, and transportation. Carlyle employs more than 2,200 employees in 29 offices across five continents.

The Issuer is a joint stock company (società per azioni) incorporated in Italy and is registered with the Companies’ register of Milan-Monza-Brianza-Lodi under registration number and fiscal code 10462810960. The registered office of the Issuer is at Via Alessandro Manzoni, 38, 20121 Milan, Italy.

A portion of the cash proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with cash on the Issuer’s balance sheet, will be used by the Issuer to satisfy and discharge and ultimately redeem the Existing Fixed Rate Notes at a price of 100% of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of redemption, and additional amounts, if any, and to repay certain indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility (collectively, the “Refinancing”). For purposes of the Refinancing: (i) €285.0 million of the Existing Fixed Rate Notes, the proceeds of which were used by the Issuer to, among others, finance the acquisition by the Issuer of Flos, B&B and Danish HoldCo and to fund a portion of the Danish HoldCo I/C Loan to Danish HoldCo, will be redeemed with proceeds from Tranche A (as defined under “Sources and Uses”) under the Notes; (ii) €66.3 million of the Existing Fixed Rate Notes, the proceeds of which were used by the Issuer to fund a portion of the Flos I/C Loan to Flos, will be redeemed with the proceeds from Tranche B (as defined under “Sources and Uses”) under the Notes; and (iii) €48.7 million of the Existing Fixed Rate Notes, the proceeds of which were used by the Issuer to fund a portion of the B&B I/C Loan to B&B, will be redeemed with the proceeds from Tranche C (as defined under “Sources and Uses”) under the Notes. We expect that the Existing Fixed Rate Notes will be satisfied and discharged on the Issue Date and ultimately redeemed shortly thereafter. The Existing Floating Rate Notes are not expected to be redeemed as part of the Refinancing. -----

To further support our liquidity, on October 31, 2023, certain lenders agreed to participate, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions specified therein, in an upsize of the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility from €100 million to €140.0 million through an amendment and restatement agreement (the “Revolving Credit

Subsection Title: Facility Upsize”). We expect the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize will become effective on or around the Issue
Subsubsection Text: Date, subject to, among others, the Issue Date occurring. As part of the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize, the maturity of the Revolving Credit Facility will be extended to mature on the earlier of (i) the date falling six months prior to the scheduled maturity date of the Notes and (ii) the date falling 54 months after the Issue Date of the Notes; provided that to the extent more than €100.0 million of the principal amount of the Existing Floating Rate Notes remain outstanding on the date falling three months prior to their scheduled maturity date (i.e. on February 15, 2026), the Revolving Credit Facility will spring to mature on such date. We expect that €18.6 million of drawn amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will remain outstanding following the Refinancing. In addition, in the event that freely available cash on our balance sheet on or about the Issue Date is lower than our estimate, we may draw down additional amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date or shortly thereafter. We refer to the offering of the Notes hereby, the Refinancing, the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize and any actions or steps related thereto, collectively, as the “Transactions”.

Subsubsection Title: Current Trading for the Twelve Months Ending September 30, 2023
Subsubsection Text: _The preliminary indications set forth below are based on an initial review of our results of operations from our management accounts. Neither our independent auditors nor any other independent auditors have audited, reviewed, compiled or performed any procedures with respect to such preliminary unaudited financial information for the purpose of its inclusion herein or for any other purposes and, accordingly, neither our nor any other independent auditors have expressed an opinion or provided any form of assurance with respect thereto for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum. Furthermore, the preliminary unaudited financial information below does not take into account any circumstances or events occurring after the period to which it refers. The preliminary unaudited information set forth below regarding our results for the periods indicated is based on management accounts and systems and in part on estimates. We believe the estimates underlying the financial information presented below may provide investors with a helpful indication of the development of our results of operations following June 30, 2023. However, our actual results for the third quarter of 2023 may differ materially from the trends and ranges included herein. The preliminary information set forth below should not be regarded as an indication, forecast, capsule financial information or representation regarding our financial results for the three months ending September 30, 2023 or for any other period. Moreover, the comparative information presented for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, have been calculated on a pro forma basis to give effect to the acquisition of Audo, as if it had occurred on October 1, 2021. Such pro forma information has been prepared by management for illustrative purposes only. The pro forma information included herein has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the U.S. Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards, and does not purport to project the future financial results of operations of the combined entities. Neither our independent auditors nor any other independent auditors have audited, reviewed, compiled or performed any procedures with respect to such pro forma information for the purpose of its inclusion herein or for any other purposes and, accordingly, neither our independent auditors nor any other independent auditors have expressed an opinion or provided any form of assurance with respect thereto for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum. You should therefore not place undue reliance on the preliminary information presented below. In addition, the revenue recognition and measurement criteria we utilize in our management accounts may be different from those we utilize in our statutory accounts. Therefore, sales and operating results from our management accounts are marginally different from revenues and operating results deriving from our statutory accounts and consolidated financial statements. See “Forward-Looking Statements”, “Risk Factors”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, “Presentation of financial and other information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures” and “Presentation of financial and other information—Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information in Respect of the Emerging Brands”._ As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have not finalized trading results for the three months ending September 30, 2023. However, based on preliminary results derived from our unaudited management accounts and other information currently available to us, we estimate our sales from customers for the twelve months ending September 30, 2023 to be between €805 million and €815 million, compared to €841.3 million pro forma sales from customers for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 (after giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo, as if it had occurred on October 1, 2021). Notwithstanding the decrease in sales from customers, we estimate our EBITDA margin adjusted for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 to be above 25%. The expected decrease in sales from customers was primarily driven by reduced volumes in our wholesale distribution channel, mainly due to uncertainty on the economic outlook as a result of the current adverse global macroeconomic environment, while we expect our DTC channels achieved single digit growth in sales from customers. In particular, in respect of our contract distribution channel we estimate our sales from customers for the twelve months ending September 30, 2023 increased by approximately 9% from €231.2 million pro forma sales from customers for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. Our strong focus on and timely implementation of cost containment measures enabled us to mitigate the estimated decrease in sales from customers for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 and achieve an estimated higher EBITDA margin adjusted as compared to the corresponding period of 2022. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have identified a number of additional procurement optimization opportunities across both direct and indirect procurement categories, which we expect will deliver run-rate annual cost savings for an aggregate estimated amount of €17.8 million in the next three to four years, as further described under “—Our Strategies—Significant _opportunity from new procurement cost saving initiatives under implementation”. See also “Forward-Looking Statements”._

On July 25, 2023, the extraordinary weather events that affected the Monza Brianza area in northern Italy caused the breakage of certain skylights in our facilities located in Misinto, Italy, in use by B&B Italia and Design Quality ----- Manufacturing S.p.A. (“DQM”). In addition to damage to the buildings, we suffered damage to some of the raw materials and semi-finished products stored in the facilities. As a result, the operations of B&B Italia were interrupted, while operations of DQM resumed shortly after the weather events. B&B Italia’s facility is currently operating at reduced capacity and is expected to restore full capacity in November 2023. Although we do not expect these extraordinary events to have had a material adverse effect on the operations of B&B Italia and DQM, we are continuing to evaluate with the assistance of an expert appointed by B&B and DQM the final amount of losses caused by the business interruption of B&B Italia’s operations as well as by the damage to the raw materials, semi-finished products and building. We have filed with our insurance provider an initial insurance claim for the damage, and documentation to support the insurance claim is in the process of being collected. We intend to seek an advanced payment on the insurance indemnification in the fourth quarter of this year, as provided by the insurance policy, and the rest as soon as possible thereafter. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business— _Our insurance coverage could prove inadequate”._ -----
