Section Title: CORPORATE STRUCTURE AND CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The following chart shows a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure as of the date of this Offering Memorandum adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. The chart does not include all of our subsidiaries or all the debt obligations thereof. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections entitled “Description of Notes”, “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Capitalization”. Unless otherwise indicated, entities shown in the chart are wholly owned. (1) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, each of Carlyle and Investindustrial have joint beneficial ownership, indirectly through intermediate holding companies, of approximately 96.3% of the share capital of the Issuer. Certain employees and members of management indirectly hold, via Design Holding S.p.A. (“Design Holding”), approximately 1.3% of the share capital of the Issuer, and the Issuer indirectly owns, via Design Holding, the remaining approximately 2.4% of its share capital. See “Principal Shareholders”. (2) The management team that oversees the operations of the Group is employed by Design Holding. For further information, see “Management”. (3) The Issuer is a holding company incorporated under the laws of Italy as a joint stock company (società per azioni). See “Risk Factors— _Risks Related to Our Structure and Our Indebtedness—The Issuer is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and depends exclusively on cash from its operating companies”._ (4) On the Issue Date, the Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer, will not be guaranteed or secured. Subject to certain agreed security principles and certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be secured on a first-ranking basis, within five Business Days from the Issue Date, by the Initial Collateral and, within 20 Business Days from the Issue Date, by the Post Issue Date Collateral. Within 20 Business Days from the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to certain agreed security principles and certain material limitations under applicable law, as described under “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations”. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—The Notes Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability”, “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, capital maintenance and other limitations on the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral”, “Summary—The Offering— Security” and “Description of Notes—Security”. The Guarantors also guarantee on a senior basis the Existing Notes and the Revolving_ Credit Facility. The Collateral also secures or will secure, as applicable, on a first-ranking basis the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations (if any). Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of enforcement of the Collateral, holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility and counterparties to certain super priority hedging obligations (if any) have been repaid in full. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”. The security interests in the Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain_ defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of Notes— _Security” and “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral”._ (5) The Issuer has made, inter alia, certain intercompany loans (the “Intercompany Loans”) to certain of its existing subsidiaries (Flos, B&B, Danish HoldCo and Lumens) in order to, inter alia, allow those companies to refinance certain of their respective outstanding indebtedness. The Intercompany Loans were originally funded by the Issuer with, among other things, a portion of the proceeds from the Existing Notes and certain other previously existing indebtedness of the Issuer, as applicable. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Flos I/C Loan amounts to €119.2 million, the B&B I/C Loan amounts to €87.5 million, the Danish HoldCo I/C Loan amounts to €101.5 million and the Lumens I/C Loan amounts to approximately $66.8 million. For further information on the Intercompany Loans, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercompany Loans”. The receivables of the Issuer under the Intercompany Loans will form part of the Collateral securing the Notes, and currently already secure on a _pari passu basis the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. ----- (6) Approximately 1.6% of Lumens’ issued and outstanding equity interests is currently owned by members of Lumens’ management team. Such minority equity interests are not part of the Collateral. (7) Following the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions specified therein, €140 million Revolving Credit Facility will be available under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. We expect the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize will become effective on or around the Issue Date, subject to, among others, the Issue Date occurring. See “Summary—The Transactions— _The Revolving Credit Facility Upsize”. We expect that €18.6 million of drawn amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will remain_ outstanding following the Refinancing. In addition, in the event that freely available cash on our balance sheet on or about the Issue Date is lower than our estimate, we may draw down additional amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date or shortly thereafter. The Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the same entities that guarantee the Existing Notes and will guarantee the Notes, and will be secured on a first-priority basis over the same Collateral that secures the Existing Notes and will secure the Notes, subject to the applicable contractual and legal limitations. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to certain material limitations under applicable law as described under “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and _the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—The Notes Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability”, “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, capital maintenance and other limitations on the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”._ (8) On the Issue Date, the Notes will not be guaranteed. Within 20 Business Days from the Issue Date, subject to certain agreed security principles and certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by each of B&B, Flos, Louis Poulsen, Antares and Lumens (collectively, the “Guarantors”). As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 61.1% of the consolidated revenue of the Issuer, 77.6% of the consolidated Adjusted EBITDA of the Issuer and 80.2% of the consolidated total assets of the Issuer (as to assets, including the value of goodwill and trademark allocated to B&B, Flos and Louis Poulsen in the Consolidated Financial Statements), in each case, including the contribution of Ares S.r.l. (which generated approximately 1.2% of the consolidated revenue of the Issuer and approximately 2.6% of the consolidated Adjusted EBITDA of the Issuer and accounted for approximately 2.3% of the consolidated total assets of the Issuer) and Flos Bespoke S.r.l. (which generated approximately 0.8% of the consolidated revenue of the Issuer and approximately 1.0% of the consolidated Adjusted EBITDA of the Issuer and accounted for approximately 0.4% of the consolidated total assets of the Issuer), which we plan to merge into Flos by the first half of 2024. As of June 30, 2023, the Guarantors (including Ares S.r.l. and Flos Bespoke S.r.l., which we plan to merge into Flos by the first half of 2024) had €32.3 million in aggregate principal amount of external third-party indebtedness, none of which was secured and €21.6 million of which was represented by lease obligations under IFRS 16, and all of which is expected to remain in place following the Transactions. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to certain material contractual and legal limitations. See “Certain _Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations”._ By virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Notes Guarantee will be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Notes Guarantee. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related _to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—The Notes Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability”_ and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, _capital maintenance and other limitations on the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral”. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor_ Agreement and may be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of Notes—The Notes Guarantees”._ (9) Certain subsidiaries of the Issuer will not guarantee the Notes. As of June 30, 2023, the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not expected to guarantee the Notes (excluding Ares S.r.l. and Flos Bespoke S.r.l., which we plan to merge into Flos by the first half of 2024) had €68.4 million in aggregate principal amount of external third-party indebtedness, none of which was secured and €64.8 million of which was represented by lease obligations under IFRS 16, and all of which is expected to remain in place following the Transactions. As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, the subsidiaries of the Issuer which are not expected to guarantee the Notes represented 38.9% of the consolidated revenue of the Issuer, 22.4% of the consolidated Adjusted EBITDA of the Issuer and 19.8% of the consolidated total assets of the Issuer. -----

The Guarantors also guarantee on a senior basis the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 61.1% of the consolidated revenue of the Issuer, 77.6% of the consolidated Adjusted EBITDA of the Issuer and 80.2% of the consolidated total assets of the Issuer (as to assets, including the value of goodwill and trademark allocated to B&B, Flos and Louis Poulsen in the Consolidated Financial Statements), in each case, including the contribution of Ares S.r.l. and Flos Bespoke S.r.l., which we plan to merge into Flos by the first half of 2024. As of June 30, 2023, the Guarantors (including Ares S.r.l. and Flos Bespoke S.r.l.) had €32.3 million in aggregate principal amount of external third-party indebtedness, none of which was secured and €21.6 million of which was represented by lease obligations under IFRS 16, and all of which is expected to remain in place following the Transactions.

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes Guarantees ..... The Notes Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of that Guarantor; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s obligations under the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging obligations (if any); - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness or obligation of such Guarantor and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of such Guarantor’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. See also “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes _Guarantees_ _and_ _the_ _Collateral_ _and_ _Certain_ _Insolvency_ _Law Considerations—Italy—Limitation on validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral—Certain additional considerations in relation to Notes Guarantees and Collateral”._ -----

Subsection Title: Security, Enforcement of Security ... On the Issue Date, the Notes will not be secured.
Subsubsection Text: Within five Business Days following the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by first-ranking security interests in: - 100% of the share capital of the Issuer; - certain material bank accounts of the Issuer; and - the Issuer’s receivables in respect of the B&B I/C Loan, the Flos I/C Loan, the Danish Holdco I/C Loan and the Lumens I/C Loan (collectively, the “Initial Collateral”). Within 20 Business Days following the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by first-ranking security interests in (A) 100% of the share capital of each of Flos S.p.A., Antares Iluminación S.A.U., B&B Italia S.p.A., Danish HoldCo and Louis Poulsen, and (B) the equity interests of Lumens held by the Issuer (collectively, the “Post Issue Date Collateral” and, together with the Initial Collateral and any other collateral securing the Notes from time to time pursuant to the Indenture, the “Collateral”). The Collateral also secures on a first-ranking basis the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations (if any) and may also secure certain future indebtedness. The Collateral will be granted subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, certain agreed security principles, certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws and the terms of the security documents. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of Notes will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral only after the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility and counterparties to certain super priority hedging obligations (if any) have been repaid in full. See “Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”. The security interests in the Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of _Notes—Security” and “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral”._

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds .................................. The gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with cash on
Subsubsection Text: the Issuer’s balance sheet, will be used to (i) redeem the Existing Fixed Rate Notes, (ii) repay certain indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility, and (iii) pay accrued and unpaid interest thereon and costs, fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See “Summary—The _Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds”._

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption ........................ The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or after
Subsubsection Text: November 15, 2025 at the redemption prices as described under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption”. At any time prior to November 15, 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus a “make-whole” premium, as further described under “Description of _Notes—Optional Redemption”._ At any time on or prior to November 15, 2025, the Issuer may, at its option, redeem the Notes, in whole or in part, following the occurrence of any Initial Public Offering (as defined herein), with funds in an aggregate amount not exceeding the net cash proceeds of such Initial Public Offering, ----- at a redemption price equal to 102% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, as further described under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption”. At any time prior to November 15, 2025, the Issuer may on one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any additional Notes), using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 110% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any; _provided that,_ _inter alia, at least 50% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any additional Notes) remains outstanding after each redemption, as further described under “Description of Notes— _Optional Redemption”._ At any time prior to November 15, 2025, the Issuer may redeem during each calendar year up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes originally issued (including any additional Notes) at its option, from time to time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, as further described under “Description of Notes— _Optional Redemption”._

Subsection Title: Optional redemption for taxation reasons ................................................ If certain changes in the law (or in its interpretation) of any relevant taxing
Subsubsection Text: jurisdiction impose certain withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to (but not including) the date of redemption. See “Description of Notes— _Redemption for Taxation Reasons”._

Subsection Title: Additional amounts ........................... Except as provided in “Description of Notes—Additional Amounts”, all
Subsubsection Text: payments the Issuer makes with respect to the Notes, or each Guarantor makes with respect to its Notes Guarantee, will be made without withholding or deduction for, or on account of, any present or future taxes unless required by law. If withholding or deduction for taxes is required to be made in any relevant taxing jurisdiction with respect to a payment on the Notes or any Notes Guarantee, subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or Guarantor, as the case may be, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes after the withholding or deduction (including any such withholding or deduction in respect of the additional amounts) is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of Notes—Additional Amounts”. The Issuer is organized under the laws of the Republic of Italy and therefore payments of principal and interest on the Notes and, in certain circumstances, any gain on the Notes, will be subject to Italian tax laws and regulations. Subject to and as set forth in “Description of Notes— _Additional Amounts”, the Issuer will not be liable to pay any additional_ amounts to holders of the Notes if any withholding or deduction is required pursuant to Decree No. 239 or pursuant to Decree No. 461, except, in the case of Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461, where the procedures required under Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461 in order to benefit from an exemption have not been complied with due solely to the actions or omissions of the Issuer or its agents. See “Description of Notes— _Additional Amounts”._ Although we believe that, under current law, Italian withholding tax will not be imposed under Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461 where a holder of the Notes is resident for tax purposes in a country which allows for a satisfactory exchange of information with Italy (as identified currently in ----- Ministerial Decree of September 4, 1996 as subsequently amended and supplemented and, in the future, in any decree to be issued under Article 11(4)(c) of Decree No. 239; any such decree, the “White List”) and such holder of the Notes complies with certain certification requirements, there is no assurance that this will be the case. Moreover, holders of the Notes will bear the risk of any change in Decree No. 239 or in Decree No. 461 after the date hereof, including any change in the White List. See “Taxation—Certain Italian Tax Considerations”.

Subsection Title: Change of Control ............................. Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: may be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified net consolidated leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of Notes”.

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ............................. The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer and
Subsubsection Text: its restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests created for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of Notes—Certain _Covenants”._

Subsection Title: Additional Notes ................................ Subject to compliance with the Indenture, the Issuer will be permitted to
Subsubsection Text: issue additional Notes, without notice to or the consent of holders of Notes, which shall have terms substantially identical to the Notes offered hereby except in respect of certain specified terms. Such additional Notes will be treated, along with all other Notes of the relevant series, as a single class for the purposes of the Indenture with respect to waivers, amendments and all other matters which are not specifically distinguished for such series. For all purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes, additional Notes shall be deemed to form one series with the initial Notes if they have terms substantially identical in all material respects to the initial Notes. Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may at the option of the Issuer be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the initial Notes ----- without being fungible with the initial Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined in “Taxation—Certain _United States Federal Income Tax Considerations”) considering the_ purchase of Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S as part of this Offering or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular U.S. federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such Notes, including with respect to the potential issuance of additional Notes that are not fungible with the initial Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being separately identified. In the event additional Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the initial Notes, without being fungible with such initial Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes on or prior to the date of issuance of such additional Notes, will no longer be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a Rule 144A Global Note. Such a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Notes _Guarantees and the Collateral—Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with the Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes”, “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers” and_ “Description of Notes—General”.

Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ......................... The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be,
Subsubsection Text: registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Notice to Prospective U.S. Investors” and “Notice to Certain _European Investors”. We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to,_ register the Notes under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer).

Subsection Title: No Established Market for the Notes ................................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established
Subsubsection Text: trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes.

Subsection Title: Listing ................................................. Application has been made to admit the Notes to listing on the Official List
Subsubsection Text: of the LuxSE and to trading on the Euro MTF Market, in accordance with the rules thereof. There is no assurance that the Notes will remain listed and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market.

Subsection Title: Governing Law .................................. The Indenture, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by
Subsubsection Text: the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction under which the security interests are granted.

Subsection Title: Trustee ................................................ The Law Debenture Trust Corporation p.l.c. Security Agent .................................... UniCredit S.p.A. Paying Agent ...................................... The Bank of New York Mellon, London Branch. Registrar and Transfer Agent .......... The Bank of New York Mellon SA/NV, Dublin Branch.
Subsubsection Text: ----- Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section of this Offering Memorandum before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes. -----

The following summary contains basic information about the Notes. It is not intended to be complete and it is subject to important limitations and exceptions. For a more complete description of the terms of the Notes, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of Notes”.

(1) Adjusted EBITDA is defined as net income (loss) for the period excluding the effect of income taxes, net financial expenses (income), amortization and depreciation and net profit of discontinued operations (if any), on the basis of our consolidated profit and loss statement presented in accordance with IFRS, as derived from our Consolidated Financial Statements, as adjusted for certain non-core and non-recurring items occurred in the relevant period. Adjusted EBITDA is a supplemental measure of the performance of the Issuer that is not required by, or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. This measure is not a measurement of the financial performance of the Issuer under IFRS and should not be considered in isolation or as an alternative to net income, cash flows or any other measures of performance or liquidity prepared in accordance with IFRS or as an alternative to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities as a measure of liquidity. We believe Adjusted EBITDA provides useful information with respect to the overall operating performance and debt service capacity of the Issuer by facilitating comparisons of operating performance on a consistent basis by removing the impact of items not directly resulting from the Group’s core operations. We believe Adjusted EBITDA may be helpful to securities analysts, investors and other interested parties to assist in their assessment of the trading performance of the business of the Issuer. We note, however, that Adjusted EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered a substitute measure to net income, net income margin, as an indicator of operating performance, as an alternative to operating cash flows or as a measure of our liquidity. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures”. ----- The following table provides a reconciliation of our Net income (loss) to Adjusted EBITDA for the periods indicated:

Subsubsection Text: (a) Non-recurring items include: (i) for the year ended December 31, 2020, €1.2 million of stock option costs, €1.7 million of extraordinary costs we incurred in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, including donations, prepaid non-reimbursable costs related to fairs and shows and purchases of individual and collective protection devices, €2.1 million of costs related to personnel dismissals, €4.0 million of management fees paid to Design Holding, €1.1 million of other provisions for risks and charges and €2.2 million of other minor non-recurring costs (including in respect of certain non-recurring consultancy fees, extraordinary costs paid to agents and costs related to the closure of certain of our offices). (ii) for the year ended December 31, 2021, €1.3 million of costs related to personnel dismissals, €9.4 million of management fees paid to Design Holding, €4.5 million of extraordinary advisory and other transaction costs we incurred in connection with acquisition activities, including advisory fees for the acquisition of Lumens, €9.2 million of start-up and ramp-up costs in connection with, among other things, the opening of directly operated stores, €1.9 million in respect of the reversal of purchase price allocation in respect of inventories and €3.0 million of other minor non-recurring costs. (iii) for the year ended December 31, 2022, €5.3 million of costs related to personnel dismissals, €9.3 million of management fees paid to Design Holding, €4.8 million of extraordinary costs we incurred to strengthen the Group’s organization and compliance policies and procedures, €3.2 million relating to extraordinary shipping costs incurred by Audo in the period as a result of the exceptional high inflationary environment, €1.0 million of extraordinary costs for the rebranding of Lumens, primarily in connection with the migration of YLighting’s website to Lumens’ website, €2.8 million of extraordinary advisory and other transaction costs we incurred in connection with acquisition activities, including advisory fees for the acquisition of Designers Company, €8.0 million of start-up and ramp-up costs in connection with, among other things, the opening of directly operated stores and the normalization of the loss of Fendi Casa, still in start-up phase and impacted by the macroeconomic situation of 2022, €1.4 million related to the purchase price allocation on inventory for the Designers Company acquisition, which was reversed in the period, €0.9 million of provisions for risks and charges in respect of certain mediations involving Lumens in the United States, and €1.2 million of other minor non-recurring costs. (iv) for the six months ended June 30, 2022, €2.5 million of costs related to personnel dismissals, €4.9 million of management fees paid to Design Holding, €0.8 million of extraordinary costs we incurred to strengthen the Group’s organization and compliance policies and procedures, €1.7 million of extraordinary advisory and other transaction costs we incurred in connection with acquisition activities (including with respect to the acquisition of Audo), €0.7 million of start-up and ramp-up costs in connection with, among other things, the opening of directly operated stores and €1.1 million of other minor non-recurring costs. (v) for the six months ended June 30, 2023, €3.0 million of costs related to personnel dismissals, €4.8 million of management fees paid to Design Holding, €2.1 million of extraordinary costs we incurred to strengthen the Group’s organization and compliance policies and procedures, €0.3 million of extraordinary costs for the rebranding of Audo, €1.2 million of start-up and ramp-up costs in connection with, among other things, the opening of directly operated stores, net of the positive impact from the sale of the Flos’ store in Rome, €1.1 million related to the purchase price allocation on inventory for the Designers Company acquisition, which was reversed in the period, and €0.1 million of other minor non-recurring costs. (b) Removing the impact of IFRS 16 for the relevant periods, our Adjusted EBITDA was €127.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, €175.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, €198.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, €92.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, €90.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023, and €197.0 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. Subsubsection Text: (6) As Adjusted Cash and Short-term Deposits represents our cash and short-term deposits as of June 30, 2023 as adjusted for the Transactions, as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2023. It does not reflect the amount of cash used or generated and not utilized by the Group between June 30, 2023 and the Issue Date, as further described in footnote (1) under “Capitalization”. See also “Use of Proceeds”. (7) As Adjusted Net Financial Debt is defined as Adjusted Net Financial Debt as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on June 30, 2023. For further information, see “Capitalization”. (8) As Adjusted Cash Interest Expense is defined as the cash interest expense of the Issuer for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on July 1, 2022. In particular, this estimate reflects (i) the issuance of €425.0 million Notes carrying an interest rate per annum of 10.00%, (ii) the redemption of the Existing Fixed Rate Notes and the repayment of €25.0 million of drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility and (iii) the cash interest payments on the Issuer’s other financial indebtedness (including the Existing Floating Rate Notes, the amount of the Revolving Credit Facility which is expected to remain in place after the Refinancing and the €86.4 million IFRS 16 lease liabilities outstanding on June 30, 2023 that we expect will remain in place after the Refinancing, as further described under “Capitalization”), and is calculated gross of any debt issuance costs in connection with the Existing Floating Rate Notes and the offering of the Notes. As Adjusted Cash Interest Expense assumes that the three-month EURIBOR rate as of November 6, 2023 was in effect for the entire period. As Adjusted Cash Interest Expense does not include commitment fees on the undrawn Revolving Credit Facility. As Adjusted Cash Interest Expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest expense would have actually been had the Transactions occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any future date.

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables present the summary historical consolidated financial information and operating data of the Issuer. The summary historical consolidated financial information in the tables below is derived from the relevant Consolidated Financial Statements presented in accordance with IFRS. Due to minor reclassifications which were made in the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements with respect to certain profit and loss and financial position line items relating to the financial year ended December 31, 2020, the consolidated profit and loss and statement of financial position of the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented in the following tables have been derived from the corresponding comparative column in the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements, and not from the 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements, which are only included in the financial pages of this Offering Memorandum. Similarly, due to minor reclassifications which were made in the 2022 Consolidated Financial Statements with respect to certain profit and loss and financial position line items relating to the financial year ended December 31, 2021, the consolidated profit and loss and statement of financial position of the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 presented in the following tables have been derived from the corresponding comparative column in the 2022 Consolidated Financial Statements, and not from the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements, which are only included in the financial pages of this Offering Memorandum. The information presented below is not necessarily indicative of the results of future operations. We have also presented certain summary unaudited as adjusted consolidated financial and other data prepared to give effect to the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2023 for the as adjusted statement of financial position information and on July 1, 2022 for the as adjusted statement of profit or loss information. Such summary unaudited as adjusted financial information is based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ from actual amounts. It is for informational purposes only and does not purport to present what our results or other metric would actually have been had the Transactions occurred on the dates presented or to project our results of operations or financial position for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. The summary consolidated financial information presented below includes certain non-IFRS financial and other measures that we use to evaluate our economic and financial performance. These measures are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered a substitute for, or superior to, the equivalent measures calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS or those calculated using financial measures that are prepared in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information— Non-IFRS Financial Measures”. The following tables should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and with the information set forth under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalization”, “Selected Historical Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”._

Subsubsection Title: We are affected by general economic conditions worldwide, and unfavorable economic conditions could result in a decline in the demand for our products and a material adverse effect on our financial performance.
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue, profitability, cash flow and future growth are affected by general economic conditions, consumer confidence and spending patterns. The foregoing may also be adversely affected by negative local, regional, national or international political or economic trends, whether actual or perceived, or adverse developments such as wars and geopolitical tensions, pandemics or other health related crisis, increasing energy or other commodity prices and surging benchmark interest rates, as well as a highly inflationary environment, any of which may reduce consumers’ ability or willingness to spend. In particular, our business is heavily dependent on the demand for high-end furniture and lighting products, especially in Europe, North America and the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, which make up a significant portion of our revenue. Declining economic conditions in any of the locations in which we operate, economic stagnation as a result of geopolitical tensions and their associated effects or negative perceptions about economic conditions, could lead to a decrease in consumer spending and ultimately a decline in the demand for our products, which in turn would adversely affect our business. In particular, our products are discretionary items and sales of such items normally depend on positive consumer sentiment and the availability of discretionary income. For example, according to certain industry sources, the effects of the COVID19 pandemic resulted in the high-end furniture and lighting design market decreasing in size from approximately €38 billion in 2019 to approximately €35 billion in 2020. The current unstable geopolitical, macroeconomic and financial environment, including as a result of the ongoing military conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East and global inflationary surge, at both the EMEA level, where our revenue is concentrated, as well as at the global level, could affect our production capacity, results of operations and growth prospects. From 2013 until the COVID-19 pandemic started, the global economy was growing at a modest pace, curbed by the stagnation of economic activity in parts of Europe, as well as the slow-down of several emerging economies. The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 significantly increased global uncertainty from an economic and social perspective, which resulted in materially increased volatility and declines in financial markets, supply chain disruptions and weaker demand in the global economy. See “—The COVID-19 pandemic adversely affected and may continue to pose risks to our business, financial _condition, results of operations and cash flows, and other epidemics or outbreaks of infectious diseases may have a similar impact”. More recently, global economic conditions have been, and are likely to continue to be, affected_ by concerns over increased geopolitical tensions as well as political developments affecting several countries, the possible exit from the European Union of more Member States and/or the replacement of the euro by one or more successor currencies. See “—Market perceptions concerning the instability of the euro, the potential _reintroduction of individual currencies within the Eurozone or the potential dissolution of the euro entirely, could negatively impact our business or our ability to refinance our liabilities. In addition, economic conditions and political uncertainty in Italy and Europe could affect our business”. These events could have a detrimental impact_ on the global economic recovery and the repayment of sovereign and non-sovereign debt in certain countries, as well as on the financial condition of European institutions, further increasing the volatility in the European financial markets, which may affect demand for our products. 31 ----- In particular, tensions resulting from the conflict between Russia and Ukraine in late February 2022 and the associated effects on the global economy including, among others, increasing energy prices and surging benchmark interest rates, the current tensions between China and the United States, continued hostilities in the Middle East and tensions in North Africa and Eastern Europe have adversely affected and could continue to negatively affect international economic conditions. The possibility that geopolitical tensions among the major world economies continue for an indefinite period of time or deteriorate further cannot be excluded. As of the time of this Offering Memorandum, the climate of economic uncertainty generated by the conflict between Russia and Ukraine and the ensuing conflict is ongoing. Additional geopolitical tensions arose on October 7, 2023, when Hamas militants and members of other terrorist organizations infiltrated Israel’s southern border from the Gaza Strip and conducted a series of terror attacks on civilian and military targets. Shortly following the attack, Israel’s security cabinet declared war against Hamas. The intensity and duration of Israel’s current war against Hamas is difficult to predict, and as are such war’s economic implications on our business and operations. Material increases in global inflation since early 2022, reaching double-digit levels not seen since the 1980s, and expectations that annual inflation may remain high for a long period of time (driven at least in part by the Russia-Ukraine conflict and the resulting impact on food and energy markets) have also forced central banks of the major world economies, including the U.S. Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, to accelerate the withdrawal of emergency monetary policies and liquidity support measures put in place prior to and during the earlier stages of the COVID19 pandemic and to significantly increase market interest rates in a very short timeframe. As some of these measures expire, are withdrawn or are no longer supported by governments, and as global inflation levels and interest rates continue to remain high, economic growth may be negatively impacted, which in turn may adversely affect our business, operations and financial performance. These factors have also impacted the availability and price of energy and, in general, of raw materials, increased inflationary pressure on the global economy as well as led to bank failures, events involving limited liquidity, defaults, non-performance and other adverse corporate developments. Further increases in global inflation levels would result in increased production costs through higher raw material costs (which might be further exacerbated by the potential rise of oil and gas prices following the recent outbreak of conflict between Israel and Hamas) and related transport costs, in addition to higher labor costs. Production costs may vary significantly depending on several other factors, including the economic cyclicality of the target markets, supply scarcity, government measures and regulatory restrictions, such as those that may be imposed in the event of a resurgence of COVID-19 cases or other infectious disease outbreaks, new or increased tariffs or customs duties and higher energy costs. Each of these events are, largely, beyond our control and difficult to predict. Increased production costs may require us to pass through volatility to the end consumer by way of increased prices, which may have negative effects on our sales volume. Deteriorating economic conditions limiting demand for our products may also increase pricing pressure on the products that we sell and result in a corresponding decline in our margins. Historically, we have not used derivatives to hedge the price fluctuation risk of raw materials, relying instead on our ability to pass on volatility to our customers through price increases. However, there is no guarantee that we may be able to pass on such cost increases to our customers promptly, if at all, which may adversely affect our business, financial conditions and results of operations. See “—If prices of _the raw materials we employ in our manufacturing processes or of the components or finished products we purchase were to increase, our business could be adversely affected to the extent we are not able to pass any such price increases on to our customers”._ Although the U.S. economy currently appears to be withstanding the global economic headwinds, supported, in part, by resilient consumer spending and various economic measures passed under the Biden administration, including the Inflation Reduction Act of August 16, 2022, there can be no assurance that it will avoid a downturn, or that it will not, in the near future, and particularly in view of the 2024 presidential elections, engage in protectionism or trade wars with other countries that could adversely impact global economic conditions. Furthermore, the weakening of currencies in some emerging countries from time to time increases the risk of financial contagion in emerging markets globally. Any extended recession or other periods of declining economic conditions, either globally or in any of the locations in which we operate, could substantially decrease the demand for our products and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Uncertainty remains in the global markets and the global economy could experience another recession, or a depression, which could be more prolonged or have greater financial impact than past global recessions. Continued weakness in the global economy for a significant period of time, or a further deterioration of global economic conditions, may lead to a collapse in consumer and business confidence that could adversely affect consumer-spending behavior, which is driven by levels of unemployment, inflation or deflation, disposable income, interest rates, the availability of consumer credit and consumer perception of their own economic prospects and overall economic conditions. Global economic conditions and uncertainties may also affect our suppliers, resulting in, for example, supplier plant closures or increases in the cost of merchandise and/or raw 32 ----- materials. As a result, an economic downturn or persistent unfavorable economic conditions in the markets in which we operate, particularly conditions that negatively affect consumer spending, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Although to different degrees, these factors affect all markets in which we operate. Our revenue, profitability, expansion of our customer base, which is characterized by high spending power, and growth prospects could therefore be adversely affected by unfavorable economic conditions, economic downturns or an otherwise uncertain economic outlook, globally or in one or more of the principal markets in which we operate or will operate in the future. For example, as a result of low consumer confidence from uncertainty over the economic outlook in the Nordic countries, especially in Denmark, Sweden and Norway, for the six months ended June 30, 2023, Louis Poulsen generated €55.6 million of revenue from contracts with customers compared to €77.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, a decrease of 28.4%. The contraction is also related to high interest rates and cost of mortgages discouraging residential real estate transactions, which, in turn, reduced demand for Louis Poulsen products as well as customer footfall in the brand’s stores. See “—Consumer spending on high-end design products could be displaced by _spending on other activities as driven by a number of factors”._ Global economic conditions may also be impacted by continued adverse developments in the banking and financial services industry. In March 2023, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank were closed by regulators in the United States following liquidity concerns. In Europe, Credit Suisse came close to a collapse in March 2023, which led to UBS agreeing to acquire its business, following the intervention of Swiss regulatory authorities. The pressure on U.S. regional banks has continued, leading to the announcement by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on May 1, 2023, that First Republic Bank, a California based regional bank, would be taken over by JPMorgan Chase. In addition, China’s property market currently faces stressing events (including, for example, the Evergrande group commencing Chapter 15 proceedings in the United States in August 2023) which may lead to a widespread crisis of the entire real estate and financial sectors, with systemic implications which are currently difficult to predict. While we have no material exposure to these institutions, there is no guarantee that other financial institutions will not experience similar liquidity issues in the near future, or that actions taken by government authorities to mitigate these risks will be sufficient to ensure access to our cash deposits held at financial institutions and sources of liquidity. In addition, there can be no assurance that there will not be additional bank failures or issues in the broader financial system, which may have an impact on the broader capital markets and, in turn, our ability to access those markets, as well as general consumer confidence and their willingness for discretionary spending. Adverse conditions in the credit and financial markets could prevent us from obtaining financing or credit on favorable terms in order to fulfill our financing needs (including the need to refinance or repay our debt obligations, including the Notes). If we are unable to repay our debt obligations or access the credit and capital markets, we may not be able to pursue certain of our business plans, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. For example, as a consequence of the EURIBOR interest rate increase, our interest payment on the Existing Floating Rate Notes increased to approximately €15.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023 from €9.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. A substantial increase in consumer interest rates or tightening of lending standards could have a material and adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Global economic conditions and uncertainties may also affect our suppliers, resulting in, for example, supplier plant closures or increases in the cost of merchandise and/or raw materials. As a result, an economic downturn or persistent unfavorable economic conditions in the markets in which we operate, particularly conditions that negatively affect consumer spending, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Consumer spending on high-end design products could be displaced by spending on other activities as driven by a number of factors.
Subsubsection Text: Consumer spending on high-end design products could decrease or be displaced by spending on other activities as driven by a number of factors including: - general economic conditions and other factors that affect consumer discretionary spending; - reduced purchasing power as a result of the economic effects caused by inflation and higher costs of living; - housing market conditions, as consumers are generally more likely to purchase new lighting and furniture when they purchase a home; 33 ----- - shifts in behavior away from home decorating in favor of other products or activities, such as travel, entertainment or electronics; - natural and other disasters, including pandemics, hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, droughts, heavy snow, ice or rain storms, which disrupt the ability of consumers to continue spending on high-end design products; - man-made disasters, such as terrorism or war, as well as other national and international security concerns; and - other matters that influence consumer confidence and spending. Total consumer spending may not rebound from the slowdown caused by the ongoing high inflation and recessionary risks. Even if it rebounds, it may not regain its historical rates in the short to medium term due to relative disposable income decreases and the spending habits of potential customers changing to reflect any increased uncertainty or apprehension regarding economic conditions, and it may not increase in certain product markets given changes in consumer interests. Moreover, as we expand into new geographic markets and product categories, we may not accurately predict consumer preferences in that market or product category, which could result in lower-than-expected sales. A decline in consumer spending on high-end design products could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to fully realize our commercial, strategic vision or expected synergies from acquired companies, including the Emerging Brands.
Subsubsection Text: We may experience difficulties in maximizing collaboration across our portfolio brands and achieving our strategic vision, including taking advantage of cross-selling opportunities. We were formed as a result of the combination of three large and complex businesses that had historically been operated separately and have since then acquired Lumens and Audo and entered into the Fendi Casa joint venture. Although we have been successful to date, we cannot assure you that our management team will continue to effectively direct the combined businesses or fully achieve the synergies from both the full integration of Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen, as well as the Emerging Brands, including through the coordination of certain activities by our centralized management team. Generally, the more brands and companies we acquire and consolidate in our Group, the more difficult it may become for us to ensure coordination among them. In addition, our ability to maintain our growth rates will depend, among other things, on our ability to structure our internal organization in order to respond promptly and effectively to the needs arising from our consolidation and growth process, the successful implementation of our strategy and the investments that we intend to make to expand our operations. Should we be unable to continue and efficiently manage the process of growth and adjustment of the organizational model, we may not realize our commercial and strategic vision. To the extent that we pursue further acquisitions or joint ventures in line with our growth strategy, any of these risks may be further exacerbated. We may also incur higher than expected costs or fail to realize any or all of the anticipated benefits and synergies. We believe that our combined portfolio can continue to generate synergies from, inter alia, the opening of new stores directly operated by us, including DOS, mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops while reducing the number of multi-brand stores; sharing information on contracts and pipelines of new contract projects among all of our businesses through a centralized CRM infrastructure; the centralization of certain administrative functions; optimizing warehousing and logistics functions in certain countries where we operate and renegotiating contracts with logistics service providers; and integrating and consolidating operations and management across the geographies in which we operate. There can be no assurance that we will be able to realize any of these synergies, and the costs we incur in trying to realize these synergies may be substantially higher than our current estimates and may outweigh the benefits. With the integration of our Emerging Brands into our existing operating structure, we have generated certain synergies, as for example we have benefited from increased sales of our products through Lumens’ e-commerce platform and we will also benefit from the sale of Lumens private label products, which Lumens is currently in the process of setting up. Our acquisitions of Lumens and Audo, as well as our Fendi Casa joint venture, have also enabled us to expand our international reach, given Lumens’ solid positioning within the market for online sales of lighting and furniture brands in the Unites States, Audo’s extended international distribution network, which also covers the United States, and Fendi Casa’s brand association with the high-value fashion brand of Maison Fendi. Although we have benefited from such initiatives, there is no guarantee that current and expected synergies, including following the acquisition of Lumens and Audo, and our Fendi Casa joint venture, will continue or be 34 ----- achieved in the expected timeframe or at all, or that the costs, both one-off and recurring, incurred to achieve such synergies will not be greater than the synergies themselves. In particular, we may be unable to successfully combine our operating structure and extensive distribution network with the online sales platform operated by Lumens efficiently or effectively and in that case we may not be able to recover the cost incurred to obtain the envisaged synergies, including the costs related to the improvement of the on-line sales platform of the Lumens and any potential loss of revenues from existing customers of Lumens who might prefer to sell their products through our competitors maintaining that the Lumens focuses more on promoting our products than theirs. In addition, following our acquisition of Audo, the company was impacted by a sharp increase of freight costs, as well as increases in inventory levels and net debt, which required us to implement a recovery plan to contain additional expenses and regulate margins. See also “—In case we carry out acquisitions as part of our growth _strategy, they may not deliver anticipated benefits”._ In addition, we may fail to achieve our organic growth objectives as a consequence of inflation and high interest rates, which may increase costs of expanding our store network and geographic reach. Capital expenditures that we estimate for use in such capacity expansion projects may be insufficient to cover the actual cost. In particular, as we focus on expanding our store network, we may incur substantial structural and operational costs to carry out this expansion through DOS, due to our direct control and management of these locations. The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a negative impact on our financial results.

Subsubsection Title: Our substantial amount of intangible assets could adversely affect our consolidated net income and our capitalization.
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2023, our main trademarks include “FLOS”, “Louis Poulsen”, “B&B”, “Arclinea” “Maxalto” and “Lumens”, which are recorded among the intangible fixed assets in our balance sheet with a total value of €618.3 million, representing 23.6% of our total assets, which amounted to €2,619.5 million as of June 30, 2023. Such trademark is considered an asset with indefinite useful life and, accordingly, is not amortized and is subject to periodical impairment tests. We cannot assure you that an adverse development in our business activities resulting in our financial performance and cash flow differing from the assumptions used for purposes of the impairment tests, or where there are significant macroeconomic uncertainties attributable, for example, to high interest rates or the prolongation or expansion of the conflict between Ukraine and Russia or any other geopolitical crisis, will not require us to reassess the useful life of our trademarks as finite rather than indefinite, or to recognize impairment charges to write-off all or a part of the carrying amount of our trademarks. No impairment or write-off of trademarks and other intangible assets resulted from the last impairment test performed on December 31, 2022 and no trigger events have been identified in the interim period ended June 30, 2023. The impairment test that will be performed as of December 31, 2023 will take into account the current adverse macroeconomic environment, changes in the financial and market conditions and their impact on our expected financial performance and cash flow. A write-off of all or a part of our trademarks would adversely affect our consolidated net income and capitalization. Furthermore, if we were to recognize substantial amounts of trademarks as a result of any future acquisitions, an adverse development in any of these future acquisitions could require us in the future to recognize impairment charges to write-off all or a part of the carrying amount of the trademarks, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We have recorded a significant amount of goodwill and we may not realize the full value thereof.
Subsubsection Text: As a consequence of the acquisitions we completed over the years, we have recorded a significant amount of goodwill. As of June 30, 2023, our total goodwill, which represents the excess of the cost of acquisitions over the net fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed, amounted to €1,309.4 million, representing 50.0% of our total assets, which amounted to €2,619.5 million as of June 30, 2023. While goodwill is not subject to depreciation, we are required to conduct impairment tests on goodwill at least once a year and any such impairments could affect our results of operations and cash flow. The impairment test assesses the recoverable amount of each cash-generating unit (“CGU”) to which the goodwill acquired in a business combination is allocated. There is significant judgment required in the analysis of a potential impairment of goodwill. Impairment tests rely on the latest available business plan of each CGU as well as external parameters, such as discount and growth rate assumptions as well as benchmarking analyses of other companies. General economic slowdowns, high inflation rates, high interest rates, exchange rate volatility, deterioration in one or more of the markets in which we operate, impairment in our financial performance and/or future outlook could affect the recoverable amount of our goodwill if, as a result of such impairment test, the fair value of the assets (CGU) is lower than their carrying value. In such case, an impairment charge would be recorded on our financial 35 ----- statements by means of a write off or write down of the amount of goodwill and a depreciation thereof and any such impairment could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation. No impairment of goodwill resulted from the last impairment test performed on December 31, 2022 and no trigger events have been identified in the interim period ended June 30, 2023. The impairment test that will be performed as of December 31, 2023 will take into account the current adverse macroeconomic environment and changes in financial and markets conditions and their impact on our expected financial performance and cash flow.

Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to successfully introduce new products, develop our brands and adapt to changing customer preferences, our business may suffer.
Subsubsection Text: The high-end furniture and lighting industries are subject to rapidly changing consumer preferences and trends. The purchasing decisions of consumers are highly subjective and can be influenced by many factors, such as marketing programs, product design and brand image. Consumers of our products tend to be design conscious, have rigorous standards and sophisticated tastes, which can be difficult to satisfy or anticipate. The historical success of our brands is attributable, in part, to our ability to introduce products which are perceived to anticipate, shape and reflect interior design trends. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and for the year ended December 31, 2022, we incurred €6.6 million and €6.4 million, respectively, of capital expenditures on research and product development to support our ability to continue to produce innovative and beautifully designed products that meet our customers’ needs and expectations, which we believe is critical to our future success. As inflation and interest rates remain high, our ability to fund organic growth through capital expenditures may be negatively impacted. Our success also depends on our ability to react to changing customer and consumer demands, preferences and habits in a timely manner. We cannot predict whether the new products we launch will be well received by consumers in our target markets and/or demographics, or even whether such new products will be introduced in a timely or cost-effective manner. Decisions regarding product design must be made months in advance of the time when consumer acceptance can be measured and, therefore, such decisions are inherently uncertain. An inability to keep pace with product development, anticipate consumer preferences, meet consumer demands or understand consumer habits could result in material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. Decreased consumer demand may also result in decreased spending on promotional activities for our products, which may exacerbate the adverse impact on our volume of sales. Our business is also subject to changes in technology, such as the expanded use of LEDs in lighting, and if we fail to anticipate or adequately respond to such changes, or do not have sufficient capital to invest or respond to these developments, our profits may decline. Our future financial performance will depend in part upon our ability to adapt our products to evolving technology successfully, both to keep up with customer expectations and preferences and to improve our business operations. We cannot predict all the effects of future technological changes. The cost of adapting our products to new technologies could be significant, and our ability to finance these costs may be adversely affected by poor market conditions resulting in lower revenues and cash generation, our debt servicing requirements or our inability to obtain the financing we require. There can be no assurance that the investments we have made in product development and technology will generate expected returns by enabling us to increase or maintain market share. In addition, there can be no assurance that we will be able to comply with our investment and business plans. Any inability to successfully adapt to changing customer preferences and technologies, make sufficient investments in research, technology renovation and product development or generate expected returns on those investments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: We face significant competition in the development, production and sale of our products.
Subsubsection Text: The market for high-end designer furniture and lighting is highly competitive. The key factors that affect competition in this market include the profiles of designers and the designs themselves, the technical know-how of internal research and product development teams, the breadth of distribution networks and the ability to interact with existing and new customers. Also important is a strong design heritage and the quality of relationships with designers and specifiers. Our competitors may focus more of their resources than we do on competitive activities, such as sales and marketing, research and product development and strategic acquisitions, or may have greater purchasing economies of scale and lower cost bases, including as a result of business combinations, such as the acquisition of Knoll by Herman Miller in 2021. To counter any of the aforementioned developments and preserve our position in the market, we may have to incur unplanned costs for the development of marketing activities, among other things, which may adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. 36 ----- Over the past several years, certain large international retailers such as IKEA and Maisons du Monde, historically focused on lower range furnishing and lighting products characterized by a low or absent design component, have expanded their product offerings to enter the “affordable inspirational” segment of the furniture and lighting market. This is an attempt to enlarge their customer base through the offering of quality products with appealing design and at lower price points compared to the high-end furnishing and lighting segment in which we operate. While we do not consider them our direct competitors, should these retailers continue to improve the design and quality of their products and maintain accessible price points, we may lose existing customers or fail to attract new customers if we are not able to continue to materially differentiate our products and brands in terms of quality and design. Such an outcome could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In addition, although our custom and contract operations are currently less impacted by this competition, these retailers could expand their operations to such segments in the future. In particular, there are companies (such as Bemz, Semihandmade, Prettypegs) dedicated solely to taking minimal IKEA furniture and customizing it for the customer’s unique style and aesthetic. Moreover, our license agreements with designers typically do not grant us the rights to future designs of the licensors. When bidding for these licenses, or for licenses with new designers, our competitors may be able to offer more favorable payment terms or new license arrangements that strengthen their competitive position or prevent us from taking advantage of opportunities to work with certain designers, or we may be required, as a result of competitive pressure, to agree to less favorable terms than we have achieved historically in order to maintain our relationships or build new relationships with designers. Competitors may also be able to respond more quickly and effectively than we can to new or changing opportunities, technologies, standards or consumer preferences. Competitors may also possess broader distribution networks, have more extensive e-commerce operations, more actively sell through social media or have larger networks of directly operated stores, which could allow them to exercise more control over their brand than we can. In particular, barriers to entry for e-commerce or social networks are low, and current and new competitors can launch new e-commerce platforms or sell their products through social media at a relatively low cost while also reaching large numbers of potential customers by using the internet for marketing. Low barriers to entry also enable competitors to sell on e-commerce platforms counterfeit products that make unauthorized use of our brand names or other intellectual property assets. See “—If we are unable to protect our license and other _intellectual property rights from others, if counterfeiting increases or if our competitors or third parties assert intellectual property rights against us, our business may suffer, and we may incur significant additional costs”._ As a result of competition through e-commerce channels, we may experience pricing pressure and loss of market share, which could have a material adverse effect on our business. Increased competition could limit our ability to increase our prices or require us to reduce prices or increase our spending on marketing, sales and research and product development, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Our failure to effectively control our distribution network and their commercial practices could adversely affect our brand reputation. In addition, any disruption in the operations of our distributors or in our relationships with them could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: We generate a large portion of our revenue through wholesale retailers that we do not own and that we may approach either directly (including through our subsidiaries, where possible) or through third-party agents and distributors, depending on the features and practices of each relevant market. We normally have little control over the commercial practices of wholesale retailers, some of whom operate partially or exclusively as online retailers, or over third-party agents and distributors. In particular, while in certain regions we have implemented selective distribution policies that grant us a level of control over wholesalers’ pricing, it is otherwise difficult for us to monitor the price levels and commercial practices applied by wholesale retailers, third-party agents and distributors, especially through the internet, where our products could be subject to multiple interim sales before reaching the end customers. In most cases, wholesale retailers are not contractually bound to apply minimum price levels and could therefore apply discounts inconsistently in the same market or in different markets, which could be perceived negatively by our customers. In addition, if our wholesale retailers were to apply unfair commercial practices to the detriment of the end customers or offer material discounts on our products, our brand reputation could be harmed and sales in our retail channel could also suffer.
