Subsubsection Title: No assurance can be given that the listing of the Notes will satisfy the listing requirement of Decree No. 239.
Subsubsection Text: No assurance can be given that the listing of the Notes on the Official List of the LuxSE and the admission of the Notes to trading on the LuxSE’s Euro MTF Market will satisfy the listing requirement of Decree No. 239 in order 94 ----- for the Notes to be eligible to benefit from the provisions of such legislation relating to the exemption from the requirement to apply withholding tax. The Italian tax authorities issued an interpretive circular relating to, among others, the listing requirement of the aforementioned legislation in order for the Notes to be eligible for the exemption from deduction of tax. According to a strict interpretation of this circular, the Notes may not be eligible to benefit from such provisions if the listing of the Notes is not effective as of the Issue Date. In the event that the Notes are not listed as of the Issue Date or that such listing requirement is not satisfied, payments of interest, premium and other income with respect to the Notes would be subject to a withholding tax, currently at a rate of 26%, and, subject to certain exceptions, see “Description of Notes—Additional Amounts”, the Issuer would be required to pay additional amounts with respect to such withholding tax. We cannot assure you that the Italian tax authorities will not interpret the applicable legislation as requiring that the listing be effective upon issuance of the Notes and we cannot assure you that the listing can be achieved by the Issue Date. The imposition of withholding taxes with respect to payments on the Notes and the resulting obligation to pay, subject to certain exceptions, additional amounts to holders of the Notes could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: No assurance can be given that the procedural requirements to apply the Italian tax regime provided by Decree No. 239 will be met.
Subsubsection Text: The regime provided by Decree No. 239, and in particular the exemption from withholding tax, which is in principle granted to holders of the Notes who are the beneficial owners of the proceeds from the Notes (or, if the Holders are institutional investors not subject to tax, as they are identified in any case as the beneficial owners of the Notes, as clarified by the Italian tax authorities in the Circular Letter No. 23 of March 1, 2002, par. 4) and who are resident in a country included in the White List (or are established in a country included in the White List, in case of Holders that are non-Italian institutional investors), applies if certain procedural requirements are met. It is not possible to assure that the non-Italian resident investors can claim the application of the withholding tax exemption where the relevant non-Italian intermediary fails to comply with the procedural rules set for the application of the exemption regime or fails to provide sufficient information to the relevant Italian tax authorities under the procedures set for applying the exemption regime. See “Taxation—Certain Italian Tax Considerations”. Should the procedural requirements not be met, Italian withholding tax may apply on the payments made on the Notes to non-Italian investors resident in countries that allow for satisfactory exchange of information with Italy. In such event, the Issuer will not be required to pay any additional amounts with respect to such withholding tax.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: The Indenture will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee. See “Description of the Notes”.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed above and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurances can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the Issue Date, the Notes issued under the Indenture receive an investment grade rating from each of Moody’s and S&P, and no default or event of default has occurred 95 ----- and is continuing, then beginning that day and continuing until such time as the Notes are no longer rated investment grade by either ratings agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to the Notes. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade _Status”. At any time when these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among other things, incur additional_ indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness without restriction, each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if achieved will be maintained.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: Total remuneration under the Notes will be automatically reduced if it exceeds the anti-usury cap levels set under Italian law.
Subsubsection Text: Under Italian law, any obligation of an Italian company and/or any obligation secured or guaranteed by an Italian company, to pay any portion of remuneration (including interest, default interest, fees, charges, expenses and other costs and any other form of compensation related to the Notes) in excess of the thresholds permitted under the Italian Usury Law may not be enforceable. Although the applicability of the Italian Usury Law to securities such as the Notes (and, among others, related original issue discounts and make-whole payments that may be due under the applicable indenture) remains untested, the Indenture will provide that, if the remuneration applicable to the Notes (including interest, default interest, fees, original issue discounts, premium, charges, expenses and other costs and any other form of compensation related to the Notes (the “Total Remuneration”)) at any time exceeds the maximum remuneration permitted under applicable Italian law (including the Italian Usury Law), then the Total Remuneration will immediately and automatically be reduced to the maximum remuneration permissible under applicable Italian law (including the Italian Usury Law) for, and limited to, the period during which it is not possible to apply the remuneration as originally provided. This will result in a change of the economic terms of the Notes which, in turn, may adversely impact the rights of the holders of the Notes and may have a material adverse effect on the market value of the Notes.

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID for U.S. federal income tax purposes, U.S. investors will generally be required to include amounts representing OID in their gross income as it accrues in advance of the receipt of cash payments attributable to such income using the constant yield accrual method. See “Taxation—Certain United States _Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount”._ 96 -----

Subsection Title: 239”) or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended or
Subsubsection Text: supplemented from time to time), and any implementing regulations (“Decree No. 461”), except where the procedures prescribed by Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461 in order to benefit from an exemption have not been complied with solely due to the Issuer’s (or its agents’) actions or omissions. In such circumstances, where no additional amount are due, investors subject to Italian withholding tax will only receive the net proceeds of their investment in the Notes. Although we believe that, under current law, Italian deduction of tax should not be imposed under Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461 where a beneficial owner of Notes is resident for tax purposes in a country or territory which allows for a satisfactory exchange of information with the Italian tax authorities as identified by (i) the Italian tax authorities in Italian Ministerial Decree of September 4, 1996 as subsequently amended, supplemented and replaced or (ii) once effective, in any other decree that will be issued in the future under Art. 11(4)(c) of Decree No. 239 to provide the list of such countries (the “White List”), and such holder complies with certain certification requirements, there is no assurance that this will be the case. Moreover, holders of the Notes will bear the risk of any change in Decree No. 239 or in Decree No. 461 after the date hereof, including any change in the White List.

_An investment in the Notes is subject to a number of risks. Prospective investors should consider carefully the risks described below and the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum prior to making any investment decision with respect to the Notes. Each of the risks discussed below could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on the principal amount and interest which investors will receive in respect of the Notes. In addition, each of the risks discussed below could adversely affect the trading or the trading price of the Notes or the rights of investors under the Notes and, as a result, investors could lose some or all of their investment. Prospective investors should note that the risks described below may not be the only risks we face. We have described only those risks that we currently consider to be material and there may be additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us, or that we currently consider immaterial, that might also have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-looking statements”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global design company in the high-end furniture and lighting markets. We design, produce, distribute and sell high-end lighting and furniture solutions. We offer our products through three core companies with leading positions in the global high-end design market: Flos, an Italian lighting brand, Louis Poulsen, a Danish lighting brand, and B&B, an Italian group comprising several leading furniture brands (B&B Italia, Maxalto, Azucena and Arclinea). Our Core Brands are complemented by our three Emerging Brands, which have growing relevance in the global high-end lighting, accessories and furniture markets: Lumens, a U.S. digital ecommerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture which we acquired in June 2021, Fendi Casa, an Italian furniture, lighting and home accessories brand and operated through our joint venture with high-end luxury brand Maison Fendi, which commenced operations in January 2022, and Audo, a Danish furniture, lighting and accessories brand which we acquired in May 2022. For the twelve months ended June 30, 23, we had total revenue of €857.3 million, Adjusted EBITDA of €218.4 million, net profit of €41.1 million and Adjusted EBITDA Margin above 25% and, as of June 30, 2023, we had 2,171 employees. Since our incorporation in 2018, we have successfully created a one-stop shop for high-quality design furniture and lighting products for both individuals and businesses around the world. We benefit from a well-balanced and diversified portfolio resulting from the combination of unique brand heritage and iconic products of each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B Italia and those of our Emerging Brands, and provide a complementary, high-end offering across a broad range of product categories, brands, sales channels and geographic areas. As part of our business model, Design Holding provides the strategic direction necessary for the continued development of our business, while acting as a “center of excellence” across key capabilities. Through its coordinating activities, Design Holding sets the vision and strategic direction of the Group and establishes the necessary guidelines and coordination among our brands, in particular in the areas of finance, control, legal affairs, governance, human resources management, business strategy and digital strategies. In particular, we believe the role of Design Holding in coordinating our efforts among our distribution channels with the aim to foster the growth of our brands is of paramount importance and has been one of the key contributors to our success. Design Holding also facilitates the adoption of consistent Group policies and operating processes, with a particular focus on ESG matters. The following charts set forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by brand and product category, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Includes the B&B Italia, Maxalto, Arclinea and Azucena brands. (2) Includes the Lumens, Fendi Casa and Audo brands. 99 ----- As a global design company, we offer our high-end lighting and furniture products to a diversified customer base of individual consumers, architects, designers and other specifiers for residential use and businesses around the globe for commercial use through an omni-channel approach comprising four key sales channels: (i) _Contract. Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services for residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom-made products, as well as certain complementary products from third-party producers; (ii) _Direct E-Commerce. Our direct e-commerce channel consists of our e-commerce websites selling in approximately 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our U.S. online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products; (iii) _Directly-Operated Stores. Our DOS channel comprises retail stores that are directly managed by us and sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands; and (iv) _Wholesale. Our wholesale channel comprises over 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale, operated by third parties, located around the world in a range of formats, including mono-brand stores, shop-in-shops and multi-brand stores, as well as 1,122 e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure players in e-commerce. Our contract, DOS and e-commerce channels represent our “direct-to-customer” channels, which allow us to directly reach our end-customers with a flexible, tailor-made and cost-efficient approach adapted to a rapidly evolving market. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by sales channel, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: We operate directly or indirectly in more than 130 countries around the world. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by geography, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: Our products are distinguished by their design content, combining innovation and technology with the rich design heritage that characterizes the Italian and Danish traditions. Each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B maintains a portfolio of iconic products, a number of which have been popular for more than 50 years and were created in collaboration with some of the most prestigious designers in the world, including Antonio Citterio, Gaetano Pesce, Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, Philippe Starck, Poul Henningsen and Arne Jacobsen. Our products have received numerous global design awards and are held in the permanent collections of art and design museums 100 ----- worldwide, including in the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, Le Centre Pompidou in Paris and La Triennale di Milano in Milan. Our Core Brands are complemented by the over 400 brands (including third-party brands) sold by Lumens through its U.S. ecommerce website, the prestigious Fendi Casa brand, which is the result of our joint venture with Maison Fendi, and The Audo, Menu and ByLassen (now merged into the Audo brand), our Nordic-design furniture and lighting brands, which draw upon both historical design archives and collaborations with new designers. Throughout our history, our strong relationships with prestigious designers and our ability to attract up-and-coming design talents coupled with our continuous efforts in technology and product development have enabled us to complement our heritage collection with successful new products that have reinforced the growth of each of our brands over the years. Since our early years of operation, we have also shown attention to sustainability, as demonstrated by the publication of sustainability reports by Flos and B&B since 2015 and 2016, respectively, and by Louis Poulsen since 2019, and the publication of the first Group Sustainability Report in 2021. Sustainability is key to our business and our brands are committed to being recognized as leaders in adopting sustainable policies and practices and in developing a new concept of luxury high-end design that has sustainability at its core. The Group achieved carbon neutrality (scope 1 and 2) in 2020. Our commitment to sustainability is founded on the following three principles: (i) Design for Planet, (ii) Design for People and (iii) Design for Culture. For more information on our ESG initiatives, achievements and goals, see “Our Business—ESG Initiatives”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, including this “Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and _results of operations”, we discuss our consolidated financial condition and results of operations for the years_ ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022 and for the six months ended June 30, 2022 and 2023. Due to minor reclassifications which were made in the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements with respect to certain profit and loss and financial position line items relating to the financial year ended December 31, 2020, the consolidated profit and loss and statement of financial position of the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived from the corresponding comparative column in the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements, and not from the 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements, which are only included in the financial pages of this Offering Memorandum. Similarly, due to minor reclassifications which were made in the 2022 Consolidated Financial Statements with respect to certain profit and loss and financial position line items relating to the financial year ended December 31, 2021, the consolidated profit and loss and statement of financial position of the Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived from the corresponding comparative column in the 2022 Consolidated Financial Statements, and not from the 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements. In this section, we present revenue breakdown by sales channel, geographical area and brand, each of which does not represent accounting segments under IFRS 8. The business division information presented herein should be read in conjunction with our Consolidated Financial Statements. For further information, see “Presentation of _financial and other information”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Text: Our business is dependent on the demand for high-end furniture and lighting products, especially in Europe, North America and the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, which make up a significant portion of our revenue. Demand for our products is in part affected by general economic conditions, consumer confidence and spending patterns, which generally depend on economic growth in the countries in which we operate. Notwithstanding general market conditions worldwide, we have historically been able to achieve strong cash flow generation supported by our high profitability levels and limited capital expenditure requirements. Our Free Cash Flow (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant period minus Maintenance Capital Expenditure for such period) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020 was €208.0 million, €206.6 million, €175.0 million and €133.2 million, resulting in a very high Free Cash Flow Conversion (calculated as the ratio of Free Cash Flow for the relevant period to Adjusted EBITDA for such period) for each such period of 95.2%, 94.7%, 91.8% and 93.0%, respectively. 101 ----- Following the sharp downturn in 2020 resulting from the first waves of the COVID-19 pandemic which affected our operations particularly in the first part that year, an improvement in global economic conditions in 2021 and 2022 positively influenced our results of operations for such periods with our revenues from contracts with customers growing across our platform, geographies and brands. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the outlook for the global economy, however, remains uncertain, in part due to the highly inflationary environment that has been adversely affecting the major global economies since early 2022, and certain markets, including Europe, may not achieve the growth rates that were forecasted. Such uncertainty has been recently exacerbated by the frictions between China and the United States, continued hostilities in the Middle East, including the currently unpredictable consequences of the conflict between Israel and Hamas and the long-lasting tensions in North Africa and Eastern Europe, as well as the global turmoil resulting from the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine, which has resulted in severe political, social and economic consequences in the countries directly involved in the conflict and more broadly on the European continent. While we have not experienced any significant supply chain disruptions or delays in shipping products to our customers or receiving input from suppliers, the ongoing war in Ukraine has been a driver behind a significant surge in energy and other commodity prices and transportation costs in 2022 globally, which has been, and may continue to be, a key factor in driving inflationary pressure and may ultimately adversely affect general economic conditions, consumer confidence and spending power as well as our results of operations. The direct impact of the war on our results in terms of revenue has been limited, as we generated less than 2% of our revenue from sales in Russia and Ukraine for each of the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021. The amount of outstanding orders from customers in Russia and Ukraine amounted to €3.9 million as of June 30, 2023, compared to €4.4 million as of December 31, 2022 (with most of the sales being guaranteed by advance payments). In addition, we do not source any strategic supply from those regions and do not operate any DOS in the affected areas. Notwithstanding, the geopolitical situation and the associated inflationary environment that has affected most of the major world economies since early 2022 have contributed in part to the increase in our transport and custom expenses, and utilities, maintenance and IT expenses, from €19.9 million and €11.8 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2021, to €44.3 million and €21.0 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2022. Over the periods under review, our market positioning, brand recognition and the quality of our products have allowed us to mitigate such increases by passing the vast majority of such higher costs on to our customers. However, there can be no assurance that continued or renewed geopolitical tensions will not impact the spending power of our customers and in turn their willingness or ability to accept any such price increase. High levels of inflation or sovereign debt, combined with weak growth and high unemployment, could affect the spending capacity of our customers leading to weaker demand and an increase in the risk of bad debts and increased counterparty credit risk. While we have not experienced any material delays in payments by customers over the periods under review, and our allowance for bad and doubtful debt as a percentage of our total receivables from third parties as of June 30, 2023 remained substantially stable compared to December 31, 2022, our products may be perceived as luxuries not essential for daily life and customers may reduce their purchases of these products before other essentials or opt for cheaper products if they need to reduce their spending. The Nordics, for example, were particularly affected by the adverse macroeconomic environment over the past year, and our revenues in the region decreased by 34.3% in the six months ended June 30, 2023 as compared to the same period in the prior year. The continued changes in general economic conditions and, most recently, the impact of the adverse global, European and Italian economic and market conditions, including, among others, the current and lingering effects of geopolitical tensions, ongoing conflicts and inflationary environment, are likely to impact the levels of spending by consumers and businesses on discretionary products, such as high-end furniture and lighting products. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We are affected by general economic conditions _worldwide, and unfavorable economic conditions could result in a decline in the demand for our products and a_ material adverse effect on our financial performance”._ According to the Industry Report, the Core High-End Design market in which we operate has grown steadily over the past few years at CAGRs of 5% and 7% per annum between 2014 and 2019 and between 2019 and 2022, respectively, being valued approximately €47 billion by retail value in 2022. We currently estimate (based on provisional data available to us) that following a slowdown in 2023 on the back of temporary headwinds which are not expected to affect the long term trajectory of the market, the Core High-End Design market will grow at a CAGR of between 2% and 5% to reach a value of between €50 billion and €60 billion in 2026. For a description of the key drivers of growth in the high-end design market, see also “Industry and Market Data”. Increases in interest rates, which are determined and controlled by central banks in response to macroeconomic events (including the numerous increases applied by the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve since mid-2022), may negatively affect general economic growth in the countries in which we operate and, consequently, could have a negative impact on the demand for our products as well as our financing costs. In 102 ----- addition, surging interest rates, among other factors, have also resulted in a material increase of our financial charges (primarily in respect of our Existing Floating Rate Notes) of €8.2 million (or 25.2%) from €32.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022 to €40.8 million for the same period in 2023. Moreover, as inflation and interest rates remain high, our ability to fund organic growth through capital expenditures may be negatively impacted. Inflation surges, the increase in energy prices, transportation costs and raw materials and a shift in consumer spending may also have a negative impact on our cost base (particularly on our service costs), on our revenue levels and on our overall profitability levels. Increases in our service costs could place strains on our working capital requirements if we are unable to increase the prices of our products proportionally. Given that we do not normally use derivatives to hedge the price fluctuation risk of, among others, input costs, if prices are volatile in the future, we might need to constantly adjust our sales prices, including on an extraordinary basis or more frequently than what we usually do, to maintain sufficient profitability. Even if we are successful in passing through cost increases to our customers, as we typically adjust the selling price of our products yearly, any lag between a change in the underlying input cost of our products and the time we surcharge our customers could affect our results of operations and profitability. Moreover, if we pass the increase in costs on to our customers by raising the prices of our products, the demand for our products may decline, in particular if competitors choose not to raise prices or if our customers decide to opt for cheaper solutions. In turn, if we are unable to pass cost increases on to our customers, we may experience pressure on our margins, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Title: Key Revenue and Cost Drivers by Sales Channel
Subsubsection Text: We generate our revenue from sales to customers through the following four sales channels, which we group in Direct-to-customer (including our Contract, Directly Operated Stores and Direct E-Commerce channels) and Wholesale (i.e. indirect sales): (i) _Contract. Our contract channel generated 30.7%, 27.7%, 26.8% and 19.7% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively. It delivers bespoke design services for both residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom-made products, as well as certain complementary products from third-party producers. Large “fit-out” projects in the contract channel normally generate significant revenue streams, although depending on the complexity and level of customization of each project, variable costs may be higher than in our other sales channels, including in connection with higher planning and design costs. (ii) _Directly-Operated Stores (“DOS”). Our DOS channel generated 6.9%, 6.4%, 6.1% and 6.2% of our revenue for the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively, and we expect that it will represent an increasingly important channel for the sale of our products. It comprises retail stores that are directly managed from our headquarters and sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands. An example is our DOS in Boston, Massachusetts, which sells products from our B&B Italia, Maxalto, Azucena and Arclinea brands. We have increasingly invested in the openings of new DOS in recent years, and we expect that such investments will allow us to increase the share of consumers, specifiers and other customers to whom we sell our products directly. Unlike the wholesale channel, we have direct pricing control in the DOS channel and so our revenue reflects the end price of our products. However, we typically incur fixed costs in the DOS channel in connection with our stores that we do not have in our wholesale channel. The impact that such fixed costs have on our margins primarily depends on the location, geographic area and size of the relevant DOS. (iii) _Direct E-Commerce. Our direct online channel generated 11.6%, 12.5%, 7.0% and 0.8% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively, with the material increase from 2020 to 2021 primarily attributable to the acquisition of Lumens (formerly YDesign) in June 2021. This channel encompasses our e-commerce websites selling in approximately 35 countries around the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products. Our customers in this channel are typically consumers, architects, interior decorators and designers to whom we sell our products directly. We have direct pricing control in our online channel, as we do in our DOS channel, and our revenue generally reflects the end price of our products. Moreover, online sales do not require the operation of a physical store and delivery costs are normally paid by the customers. We expect that the online channel will continue to represent an increasingly important channel 103 ----- for the sale of our products. See “Summary—Our Strategies—Shift focus towards DTC and “branded” _channels, develop our store network and foster growth of our online segment”._ (iv) _Wholesale. Our wholesale channel generated 50.7%, 53.4%, 60.2% and 73.3% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively. It comprises brick-and-mortar monobrand stores located around the world, shop-in-shops and multi-brand stores. The wholesale channel also includes e-tailers (e-commerce websites) and online retailers. The end customers of the wholesale channel are highly diversified and include consumers, specifiers (e.g. architects, designers, contractors, developers, etc.) and corporate customers. Revenue generated in the wholesale channel reflects a discount on the retail price of our products, which in turn represents profit for our direct customers. As part of our strategy, over the years we have increasingly focused our activities to direct-to-customer sales channels which resulted in lower incidence of the wholesale channel on our total revenues, from 73.3% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 50.7% for the six months ended June 30, 2023 (with part of this drop being due to the integration of Lumens into our business in 2021).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Title: Research and Product Development and Technological Innovation
Subsubsection Text: Maintaining the appeal of our products to existing customers and attracting new customers depends in part on our ability to reflect prevailing trends and adapt to evolving technology and customer taste. In addition to the continuing popularity of some of our older iconic designs that represent a significant portion of our revenues, the historical success of our brands is also in part attributable to our ability to introduce products which are perceived to anticipate, shape and reflect interior design trends. Our investments in research and product development, including molds and prototypes, and technological innovation have allowed us to introduce new products and designs, or updates to historical products and designs (e.g., by introducing new upholstery materials) that we believe are high quality, aesthetically appealing, suited to our customers’ needs and technologically advanced. In 2022, we launched more than 90 new product families (including extensions of existing product lines and special editions). Most launches have been successful and product development has been a primary contributor to growth in revenue. We estimate that we generated approximately 25% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 from the sale of products we launched in the last three years. Moreover, we believe that providing designers with advanced research and development facilities that support their work by making available the most advanced technologies in the industry is key to attract and collaborate with established international designers with diverse professional experience and across different generations. For example, through the periods under review, B&B Italia has also improved the technological status at its production facilities. In particular, it upgraded technology in Caldogno (Italy), aiming to increase productivity and volumes of both the Arclinea kitchen and wardrobes and in Novedrate and Misinto (Italy) with the goal of increasing productivity and sales level of B&B Italia and Maxalto upholstery and furniture. We continue to invest in research and product development and technological innovation. To that end, we incurred capital expenditures for the development of our products and updates to existing products of €3.3 million, €6.4 million, €6.7 million and €6.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively (see also “—Capital Expenditure”).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Text: Advertising, marketing and promoting are fundamental factors to maintain and develop our brand recognition. We have a unique multi-dimensional brand-building ecosystem consisting of (i) a global presence, (ii) use of different media platforms and (iii) presence in DOS and branded wholesale supported by a coordinated and unified marketing strategy across channels, media and distributions. We focus our communication and marketing efforts on four main areas: brand experience, sales support, B2B relationships and B2C relationships and we have invested and continue to invest in communication and marketing as a key part of our business strategy. In particular, through sophisticated marketing tools across various media and channels, we aim to expand the recognition of our brands on the market, enhancing their value and increasing customer engagement across various touch points. Our marketing approach is implemented through (i) digital communication tools and publications in the main international media, (ii) events such as the Milan Design Week (Salone del Mobile) and other prestigious international events in the design field, (iii) sophisticated branded publications and magazines supporting sales and dealers, (iv) tools enhancing consumers’ experience in stores, (v) social media and key opinion leaders engagement and (vi) visibility resulting from special fashion collaborations or specific projects that are commissioned to us, including, among others, B&B for the Bulgari Hotel and Resorts in Tokyo, Paris and Rome, 104 ----- M+ Museum in Hong Kong, La Bella Vita, Taichung, Taiwan, One Thousand Museum Residences in Miami and The Whiteley in London. We constantly strive to entrench and combine the above-mentioned channels in order to efficiently bring to the final consumer a consistent brand image capable of expressing the values and correct market positioning of our brands. In the past years, we have implemented or started implementing several initiatives to increase efficiency and maximize the reach of our sales and marketing functions. Such initiatives, have led, among other things, to the establishment of dedicated sales organizations serving a number of key markets, with the result that most of the markets in which we are present now have dedicated sales organizations, internal marketing divisions, with an increase in the number of full-time employees in marketing and digital marketing functions as well as e-commerce departments. Advertising, marketing and promotional expenses generally tend to increase in connection with key design industry events, such as the Milan Design Fair (Salone del Mobile), Euroluce, held biennially within the Milan Design Fair, ICFF, held annually in New York and “3daysofdesign”, held annually in Copenhagen, and in the preparation phases that precede each new product launch as prototypes are developed, supply chains are engaged, production lines are prepared and marketing content is deployed to the sales force. Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have increasingly leveraged digital marketing tools and online communication which enable us to reach a wider range of potential customers, with interactions with followers growing rapidly in size and significance, while best optimizing our cost structure. Our advertising, marketing and promotional expenses represented approximately 5% to 6% of our sales from customers for each of the six months ended June 30, 2023 and the year ended December 31, 2022. From an operational perspective, we launched a centralized CRM platform, thus administering the interactions with customers in a more efficient way, leveraging the data gathered by each of our companies. This initiative allows our Contract sales organizations at each of Flos, B&B Italia, LP, Lumens, Fendi Casa and Audo to coordinate with each other and in the different geographical areas in which we operate. In 2021, we also strengthened Flos’ e-commerce potential by adding to the already existing e-commerce platform in the U.S., a twin platform enabling our customers to purchase Flos’ products in Europe. In 2022, B&B launched its e-commerce website in the United States, followed by certain other European countries in 2023, including France, Italy, Germany and Austria, thereby enabling our customers to buy a selection of B&B products online. We have also significantly expanded our brands’ digital marketing activities, strengthening their presence on the main social networks. In addition to targeted Google advertising and search engine optimization activity based on brand keywords, we maintain a strong presence on social media with accounts and fan pages on Facebook, Instagram, Pinterest, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube, WeChat, Weibo and Little Red Book. For additional information on such focus areas, see “Our Business”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Title: Product, Distribution Channel and Geographic Mix
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are in part affected by the mix of products and brands that we sell, as different brands, and different products and collections within each brand, can carry different price points, entail different production, marketing and distribution costs and generate different gross margins. For example, for B&B and Maxalto, upholstered furniture, including sofas, armchairs, chairs and beds, generate the majority of revenue and are also the products that generate the highest gross margins, primarily because production occurs on an industrial scale through cost-efficient manufacturing processes (such as the application of polyurethane extrusions to a metal skeleton in a mold). Among the B&B furniture brands, Maxalto products have a higher price point than B&B Italia products primarily due to the different brand positioning of Maxalto and the exclusive materials utilized in the Maxalto collections (such as special leathers and precious wood), and normally generate higher gross margins, notwithstanding the higher production costs mostly deriving from the supply of such materials. In addition, sales effected through different distribution channels, whose margins vary, can impact our profitability and therefore our results of operations. For instance, sales generated by DOS may yield higher or lower gross margins than those generated through the wholesale channel, primarily depending on the performance of the individual store, as well as the impact of the fixed costs associated with the leases of the real estate property where our stores are located which vary by market and size of the individual store. In addition, gross margins in the wholesale channel are impacted by the wholesalers’ profit and, to the extent applicable, the relevant agents’ or distributors’ commissions, which are not applicable in the retail channel where we sell directly to consumers. As regards our geographic mix, through our six complementary companies, we have significant geographic diversity of sales that includes Europe, North America and the Asia Pacific region. In particular, we operate directly or indirectly in more than 130 countries around the world. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 59.8%, 26.3% and 13.9% of our revenue from contracts with customers, respectively, in Europe, the 105 ----- Americas and APAC. Following the acquisition of Lumens, our geographic mix has reflected a higher contribution of the American area, as Lumens sells products primarily to customers in the United States and Canada, which resulted in our revenue from contracts with customers increasing from €132.8 million (or 19.8% of our total revenue from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €222.0 million (or 26.3% of our total revenue from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2022. For more information, see “Our Business—Our Strategies—Expand our geographic reach with focus on the United States and Greater _China”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Title: Price Increases and Flexible Operating Structure
Subsubsection Text: Whenever manufacturing activities are outsourced (such as for most of Flos’ decorative products), fluctuations in the prices of the raw materials utilized by the third-party suppliers in their manufacturing processes may also affect prices paid by us for the supply of finished or semifinished products. Most of our contractual arrangements with suppliers do not protect us from price increases and price lists are revisited quite frequently. Historically, we have not used derivatives to hedge the price fluctuation risk of our production cost components (including, for example, input, freight, energy and transportation costs), relying instead on our ability to pass on volatility to our customers through price increases. For example, despite the severe inflationary trend in 2022, we were able to pass on the vast majority of such price increases to our customers on a permanent basis, which contributed for substantially half of the revenues percentage increase for that period. Although raw materials and other components we purchase from suppliers normally represent a relatively small percentage of the price of our products, our margins are partially impacted by the relationship between the prices that we are able to charge for our products and the costs of input costs and components required to make these products, or of the finished or semifinished products we purchase where manufacturing activities are outsourced to the extent we are not able to pass on the full cost of such price increases. As a leading player in the high-end luxury industry, we are less affected by pricing pressure than other companies in different or adjacent markets. We normally increase the prices of our products on an annual basis at levels that are considered reasonable and take into account a number of factors, including our market positioning vis-à-vis our competitors, market analysis on pricing trends in our industry, inflation, increases in sourcing costs, fluctuations of the exchange rate of the currencies of the various destination markets. In particular, price increases are often the result of an analysis that we perform on the current and expected market trend, which takes into account how we position ourselves compared to our direct and indirect competitors. From time to time, price increases are also the result of an increase in our sourcing costs or the cost of the services we outsourced for, among others, the manufacturing of our products. In addition to price increases, we are typically able to optimize the level of production that we outsource, particularly at B&B Italia’s which, alongside a number of improvements we implemented across the supply chain targeted at reducing costs and operating expenses, ultimately enhanced our ability to maintain and increase our margins over time. These improvements include, among others, renegotiation of supply contracts with certain key suppliers of raw materials and product components, streamlining the supplier base and reducing packaging costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Text: We have embraced digital transformation to position us as a digital cutting edge organization in our industry and markets. Our use of digital technologies aims to create more effective business relationships with our customers (such as dealers, end-customers, and specifiers), enhance customer experience in line with evolving market expectations and customer habits, offer innovative design services to customers through a data-driven, client-centric relationship approach. Since 2020, we have started deploying a two-level organization, with certain key digital competences shared at Group level and existing IT competences reinforced at the level of each of the Group companies. In particular, our activities have focused on: (i) increasing the automation process through the use of the CRM platform, which enables us processing data to create, among others, tailored marketing campaigns; (ii) simplifying the IT application of each of our companies, including by using the same SAP ERP platform across the companies focusing on the lighting business (LP and Flos) and the same Oracle platform across the companies focusing on the sale of furniture (B&B Italia and Arclinea); 106 ----- (iii) introducing a common platform for the entire Group’s e-commerce applications; and (iv) developing advanced configurator systems, that allow both B2B and B2C customers, distributors and specifiers to create their customized products online. In addition, our companies have made continuous progress on the digitalization of their business model, by expanding the geographical reach and access of their corporate websites and e-commerce platforms. Among other things, in 2020, Audo (then doing business as Designers Company) optimized its entire operating platform to increase product quality, delivery accuracy, and seamless customer service, while also implementing significant digitalization improvements, such as updating the website layout, creating a new digital sales tool and opening its own operational web-shop in Europe.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Text: Supply chain and sourcing is specific to the various brands of the Group. For example, for the Flos brand, we outsource almost all of our manufacturing requirements to carefully selected third-party assemblers, with part of production on a make-to-order basis in order to preserve cost efficiencies given the wide range of techniques and materials required for the manufacture of Flos products. The outsourcing of most manufacturing processes lowers Flos’ fixed cost base, which results in operational and financial flexibility, as Flos may adapt to customer demand by increasing or decreasing production, without a significant impact on margins. Suppliers and assemblers are carefully selected mainly according to their technical capacity, quality, financial stability and cost and are usually located in close proximity to our facilities to minimize transaction costs and lead times. For the Louis Poulsen and B&B Italia brands, we outsource certain manufacturing processes to carefully selected third-party assemblers, with the majority of B&B production being made on a make-to-order basis in order to preserve cost efficiencies given the wide range of techniques and materials required to manufacture B&B’s furniture. While outsourcing for Louis Poulsen and B&B Italia is typically considerably lower than Flos’, the outsourcing of some manufacturing processes reduces such companies’ fixed cost base, hence resulting in high operational and financial flexibility. For the Fendi Casa brand, production is entirely made-to-order, with the exception of the accessories, while Audo’s production is entirely outsourced. Suppliers of furniture products are mainly located in the Baltic countries while those in the lighting and accessories sector are mainly located in China. The flexible operational structure of our companies allows us to decide what level of production to outsource based on our customers’ demand, therefore further increasing our ability to adjust to different market conditions timely and efficiently.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting the Results of Operations of the Group
Subsubsection Text: We operate worldwide and have non-euro denominated assets, liabilities, revenue and costs. We are exposed to limited currency risk, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, Danish Krone and Yen against the euro, our reporting currency. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we derived approximately 43% of our revenue from sales in non-euro currencies (mainly U.S. Dollar and Danish Krone). We currently do not maintain currency hedges in place. _Transaction risk_ Our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to having a strong international presence. Our other fixed costs, such as energy, personnel and services related to production are typically denominated in the currency of the country where the relevant production facility is located (e.g., euro for Italy, U.S. dollar for the U.S., etc.). Additionally, our customer contracts are typically payable in the currency of the country where the contract is signed or the sale is made, as applicable. By having operations worldwide, we seek to match our operating costs with operating revenue in each of the major currencies in which we operate. To the extent that we have incurred expenses that are not denominated in the same currency as related revenue, exchange rate fluctuations may in some cases cause our expenses to increase or decrease as a percentage of total revenue. We believe, however, that using the euro as the transactional currency for most transactions almost eliminates the risk tied to fluctuations in exchange rates. _Translation Risk_ 107 ----- Our currency translation risk is primarily related to the recognition of revenue generated by subsidiaries during our period-end consolidation and reporting. To prepare the consolidated financial statements of the Group, we translate assets, liabilities, total revenue and expenses into euro at applicable exchange rates. To determine the applicable exchange rate, assets and liabilities are converted using the exchange rates prevailing at the reference date of the relevant consolidated financial statements, and costs and revenue are converted at the average exchange rate for the relevant period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors affecting the comparability of our results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions and other transactions affecting our scope of consolidation and comparability of our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: During the periods under review, we completed several acquisitions and other transactions through which we changed the size of our operations, and which enabled us, among others, to further strengthen our presence in certain geographical markets and distribution channels that are relevant to our business. In general, such transaction impact the comparability of our results of operations from period to period. In addition, following an acquisition, we may be required to, or may elect to, make certain investments in the acquired assets or companies, including to integrate them into our operational structure. The following is a description of the key acquisitions and other transactions completed during the periods under review: - in June 2021, we indirectly acquired Lumens (formerly YDesign), which specializes in the online offering of modern and contemporary lighting, fans, furniture and accessories to design-driven consumers and trade professionals through the website Lumens.com. Through the acquisition of Lumens, we expanded our e-commerce sales channel in the North American market. Prior to its acquisition by the Group in 2021, for the year ended December 31, 2020, Lumens generated net sales of USD163.2 million and Adjusted EBITDA of €11.7 million (equivalent) calculated by converting Adjusted EBITDA from U.S. dollars into euro by applying an exchange rate equal to 0.88$/€, corresponding to the average exchange rate for the period from January 1, 2020 through December 31, 2020. As Lumens was consolidated in our financial statements starting from June 2021, such acquisition affected the comparability of all of our results for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, we funded the acquisition of Lumens through a portion of the proceeds from the issuance in May 2021 of the Issuer’s €470.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing Floating Rate Notes (which replaced the Issuer’s previously existing €320.0 million aggregate principal amount of floating rate notes due 2025), as a result of which our debt and associated interest expense increased as compared to the prior year. The total consideration we paid for the acquisition of Lumens was USD 179.2 million; - in 2021, we also entered into a joint venture agreement with Fendi, the Italian luxury brand that is part of the LVMH Group, for the establishment of FF Design, in which we indirectly hold an 80% stake, while Fendi holds the remaining 20%. The agreement includes the licensing of Fendi’s registered trademarks, including “Fendi Casa”, along with other intellectual property rights. This strategic collaboration aims to develop the brand Fendi Casa, the home segment of Fendi, by designing, producing, and distributing collections that reflect the brand’s style as well as the expertise of our Group; - in May 2022, with the objective of consolidating our market position in the European market and in the U.S., we acquired Designers Company, a Danish holding company that included the brands Menu, by Lassen and Audo, each a designer, manufacturer, and distributer of furniture, lighting, and accessories with a Nordic style. In June 2023, Menu, by Lassen and The Audo merged into the new brand “Audo” with the aim of enhancing the Nordic-style design archives owned by Designers Company; and - prior to its acquisition by the Group in 2022, for the year ended December 31, 2021, Audo generated revenues of €53.9 million (equivalent) and Adjusted EBITDA of €9.3 million (equivalent) calculated by converting Revenue/Adjusted EBITDA from DKK into euro by applying an exchange rate equal to 7.44 DKK/€, corresponding to the average exchange rate for the period from January 1, 2021 through December 31, 2021. The total consideration for the acquisition of Audo (including deferred consideration but net of transaction costs) amounts to DKK 977.364,000 (approximately €131.4 million as of December 31, 2022 by applying an exchange rate of 7.44 DKK per euro). In addition, the Audo SPA (as defined herein) provides, among others, that in addition to the purchase price, the seller thereunder would be entitled to an earn-out for an amount of DKK 80,000,000 (approximately €10.8 million as of December 31, 2022 by applying an exchange rate of 7.44 DKK per euro) in case Audo’s turnover for the 108 ----- financial year 2023 had reached DKK 529,400,000 (approximately €71 million by applying an exchange rate of 7.44 DKK per euro). See “—Contingent Liabilities—Earn-out related to the acquisition of Audo”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors affecting the comparability of our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: The global outbreak of COVID-19 resulted in a widespread health crisis that adversely affected the economies and financial markets of many countries and regions from which we derive a significant amount of our revenue, including Europe and North America. Various governments around the world, including Italy, adopted measures to contain the spread of COVID-19. These measures, along with decreased consumer spending and widespread uncertainty following months of lockdowns and other restrictive orders, led to an economic downturn in our markets and had a direct impact on our business across all of the countries in which we operated at the time. In particular, several of the governments of such countries imposed significant lockdown measures in order to control the spread of COVID-19, including the government of Italy, which imposed the temporary closure of all of our manufacturing facilities and the stores in which our products are sold. Similar measures were adopted by the governments of several other countries in which we operate. Although the nationwide lockdowns were gradually lifted (e.g., on May 4, 2020, in Italy), significant restrictions and social distancing measures were imposed. In particular, our Contract and DOS experienced a decline as compared to prior years, as our DOS were repeatedly shut for several weeks or otherwise faced reduced opening hours as a result of the measures adopted by the competent government and authorities to prevent the spread of the virus. We also experienced a decline in the demand for bespoke design and contract projects, such as large fit-outs, during the lockdown periods, given our customers in the hospitality, retail, travel industries were severely impacted by restrictions put in place following the onset of the pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic affected our financial performance, particularly in 2020, across our operations, exerting downward pressure on global sales as a result of government regulatory constraints. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we incurred €1.7 million of costs related to COVID-19, such as cost for enhanced safety measures in our plants, stores and offices, increased shipping costs, and non-reimbursable costs that we incurred for setting up fairs that were cancelled. Such additional costs and expenses were only partially offset by cost reduction initiatives such as reduction of discretionary spend, absence of travels and diminished marketing expenses due to the cancellation of fairs and other events. In addition, we benefitted from certain subsidies available to us as a result of the measures adopted by the governments of the countries in which we operate, including recourse to Cassa _Integrazione in Italy, ERE in Spain and furlough in the United States._ Notwithstanding, our strong performance in 2019 and in the first few months of 2020 enabled us to enter the COVID-19 crisis from a position of financial strength; in addition, the positive performance of our business in the second half of the year, including due to our e-commerce capabilities as well as growth in the online furnishing market, limited the negative effects of the prolonged shutdowns and other restrictive measures in most of the countries in which we operate. While we were negatively impacted by certain COVID-19 related restrictions and lockdowns in 2020, our revenues in 2021 increased compared to 2020 following the progressive easing and removal of the relevant restrictions in the countries in which we operate. We believe that our business has demonstrated resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenues recording a robust recovery following the easing of restrictions. We continue to closely monitor the impact of COVID-19 on our business to ensure the safety of our employees and to be in a position to quickly react to any operational developments, logistics disruptions and any adverse developments in our financial condition, cash flows and liquidity. For more information see “—Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—The COVID 19 pandemic adversely affected _and may continue to pose risks to our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and other epidemics or outbreaks of infectious diseases may have a similar impact”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenues are stated net of returns, allowances, discounts and premiums, as well as taxes directly related to the sale of goods or provision of services, in compliance with the accruals and prudence concepts. Revenues from the sale for the goods are recognized when the production process for the goods has been completed and the exchange has already taken place, upon the substantial rather than formal transfer of title, with the transfer of risks and benefits being the key parameter. Revenues from the provision of services are recognized once the services have been provided. In connection with long-term contracts, revenues are recognized only once the relevant project is completed. 109 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other revenues and income represents non-core business activities, including sundry revenues, rental income, insurance repayments, revenue for transport, capital gains from asset disposals and other items.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories
Subsubsection Text: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories includes costs associated with the supply of materials, components, semi-finished or finished products and other goods used for operating purposes. Inventory items whose estimated realizable value based on market trends is lower than their carrying amount are written down, with a corresponding negative impact on the income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Personnel costs represent wages and salaries (including to members of the board of directors), social security contributions, employee severance indemnities and pensions, as well as other personnel costs incurred in the ordinary course of business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Service costs includes costs incurred in connection with production services, such as costs for subcontracted production work, maintenance and ancillary costs, transport and customs costs, commercial services, such as fees and royalties for advertising and communications, administrative services, such as fees paid to certain corporate bodies (e.g., statutory auditors), independent auditors and other professional consultants, and other minor services.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions represent amounts set aside for pension funds and business risks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other costs and charges primarily represent property rents and rental and leasing fees, as well as other administrative costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Amortization, depreciation and write-downs represent depreciation charges on tangible assets, amortization charges on intangible assets and other write-downs. Depreciation is booked monthly on a straight-line basis starting from the month when the asset is available for use or potentially able to provide the economic benefits associated with it. Intangible fixed assets are amortized along their useful life, with the amortization period and method reconsidered at least at the end of each year. Profits or losses arising from the elimination of an intangible fixed asset are measured by the difference between the net revenue of the disposal and the book value of the intangible asset, and are recognized on the profit and loss statement of the year in which the elimination occurs. Financial assets are tested for impairment at every balance sheet date with write-downs recorded in the profit and loss statement when a loss event takes place that has an impact on the future estimated cash flows of the financials assets, if such impact can be reliably estimated.

Revenues generated from APAC and the Americas are higher in the six months ended June 30, 2023 compared to the same period in 2022, and offset lower revenues from the EMEA region where lower revenues from Nordics offset growing revenues from Italy and the Middle East.

Subsubsection Text: Other revenues and income increased by €2.0 million or 100.0% from €2.0 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €4.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This was mainly due to the gain on the disposal of a DOS in Rome, Italy.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories
Subsubsection Text: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories increased by €9.0 million or 8.7% from €103.1 million (representing 25.6% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €112.1 million (representing 27.3% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2023, mainly due to the consolidation of Audo in our results of operations for the six month ended June 30, 2022 only since May 2022. If Audo had not been consolidated in our results of operations for the six months ended June 30, 2023, our purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories would have decreased mainly as a result of lower costs due to lower volumes for the period, particularly in the Nordics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Personnel costs increased by €5.7 million or 7.2% from €79.6 million (representing 19.8% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €85.3 million (representing 20.8% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2023. Personnel costs increased, mainly due to the consolidation of Audo in our results of operations for the six month ended June 30, 2022 only since May 2022 and an increase in the number of executives which resulted in higher salaries and wages and other personnel costs, notwithstanding an overall decrease in the number of our employees to 2,171 employees as of June 30, 2023, compared to 2,267 employees as of June 30, 2022, as a result of certain employee reduction initiatives we adopted at Louis Poulsen since August 2022. 112 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Service costs decreased by €7.0 million or 5.7% from €123.3 million (representing 30.6% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €116.3 million (representing 28.4% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the six month ended June 30, 2023, mainly due to lower costs for contractor work and outsourced production work, costs for fees, royalties, expenses for advertising and communication and consultant costs for the six months ended June 30, 2023 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022, as a result of our decision to temporarily internalize certain activities to optimize utilization given then current demand for our products, which was only partially offset by higher costs for utilities and maintenance and IT expenses and travel and lodging expenses as a result of the consolidation of Audo in our results of operations for the six month ended June 30, 2023 (compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022 when Audo was consolidated only since May of that year).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions increased by €1.1 million from accruals of €0.5 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to reversals of €0.6 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023. This was mainly due to lower accruals of provisions for pension liabilities and product warranty and the reversal of a provision for risk and charges pertaining to one of our subsidiaries in the six months ended June 30, 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other costs and charges increased by €0.7 million or 7.7% from €9.1 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €9.8 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023, mainly due to higher costs for property services as a result of the consolidation of Audo in our results of operations for the six month ended June 30, 2022 only since May 2022, and higher services and license fees, other taxes and duties and other expenses for the implementation for IT systems (e.g., ERP, SAP and Oracle) for the six months ended June 30, 2023 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Amortization, depreciation and impairment increased by €4.7 million or 22.4% from €21.0 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €25.7 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023, mainly due to increased depreciation of both tangible assets and right of use assets (i.e. leases), along with higher amortization of intangible assets mainly as a result of (i) the consolidation of Audo in our results of operations for the six month ended June 30, 2023 (compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022 when Audo was consolidated only since May of that year) and (ii) investments (including the opening of the Fendi Casa store) we made in recent years which resulted in higher amortized costs in the period under review.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial income decreased by €0.6 million or 13.6% from €4.4 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €3.8 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023, mainly as a result of lower exchange gains on foreign exchange transactions, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar against the euro, which was only partially compensated by higher interest income on cash balances due to an increase in interest rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial charges increased by €7.9 million or 24.1% from €32.8 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €40.7 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023 and mainly comprises interest expenses on the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility, lease liabilities and exchange losses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes decreased by €4.5 million or 34.6% from €13.0 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €8.5 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023. This was mainly due to lower current taxes and deferred taxes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Profit for the period decreased by €6.7 million or 24.9% from €26.9 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €20.2 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023 due to the factors discussed above. 113 -----
