Subsubsection Text: Revenues from contracts with customers increased by €173.1 million or 25.8% from €670.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €844.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was the result of solid growth of all of our Core Brands (with Flos and B&B growing double-digit and LP growing by 3.2%), as well as the positive contribution to our results of operation of Fendi Casa following the debut of the new Fendi Casa collection and the opening of the first Fendi Casa DOS in Milan, and the other Emerging Brands, including Lumens which we acquired in June 2021 and the results of which were not therefore fully reflected in 2021 and Audo, which we acquired in 2022 and the results of which were not reflected in 2021. Excluding the revenue contribution of our Emerging Brands, our revenues from contracts with customers would have increased by €71.3 million or 11.3% from €629.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €700.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. In terms of geographical area, our revenue from contracts with customers grew across APAC (particularly, China), the Americas and EMEA, where our performance was only partially affected by lower consumer confidence in Denmark due to uncertainty on the economic outlook. Revenues from our wholesale, contract and DOS channels grew by 11.7%, 30.0% and 32.9% compared to the year ended December 31, 2021, whereas direct e-commerce grew by 125.7% over the same period due to the full consolidation of Lumens into our results of operation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories
Subsubsection Text: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories increased by €47.2 million or 25.6% from €184.7 million (representing 27.5% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €231.9 million (representing 27.5% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2022, mainly due to increased purchases of raw materials, semifinished goods and finished products and purchases of various other materials due to (i) the contribution from our Emerging Brands (particularly, Audo, which was not consolidated in 2021 and Lumens and Fendi Casa which were only consolidated for part of the year in 2021) and (ii) higher volumes from each of Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Personnel costs increased by €31.2 million or 23.2% from €134.2 million (representing 20.0% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €165.4 million (representing 19.6% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2022. Personnel costs increased mainly as a result of higher costs for salaries and wages, employees severance indemnities and pension charges and other personnel costs, due to, among others, the contribution from our Emerging Brands which resulted in an increase in the number of our employees to 2,271 employees as of December 31, 2022 from 2,020 as of December 31, 2021. 115 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Service costs increased by €66.4 million or 36.4% from €182.7 million (representing 27.2% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €249.1 million (representing 29.5% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was mainly due to higher costs for fees, royalties, expenses for advertising and communication, transport and customs expenses, costs for utilities and maintenance and IT expenses as well as travel and lodging expenses, including as a result of (i) the contribution from our Emerging Brands (particularly, Audo, which was not consolidated in 2021 and Lumens and Fendi Casa which were only consolidated for part of the year in 2021), (ii) higher volumes from our Core Brands and (iii) the global inflationary trend in 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions remained substantially stable and amounted to €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This was mainly due to lower provisions for pension liabilities, but higher provisions for risks and charges related to certain settlements we reached mainly in the United States.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other costs and charges increased by €8.1 million or 75.7% from €10.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €18.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This was mainly due to higher costs for property services and other expenses due to the contribution from our Emerging Brands (particularly, Audo, which was not consolidated in 2021 and Lumens and Fendi Casa which were only consolidated for part of the year in 2021).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Amortization, depreciation and impairment increased by €7.3 million or 19.3% from €37.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €45.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This was mainly due to increased depreciation of both tangible assets and right of use assets (i.e. leases), along with higher amortization of intangible assets manly as result of (i) the contribution from our Emerging Brands (particularly, Audo, which was not consolidated in 2021 and Lumens and Fendi Casa which were only consolidated for part of the year in 2021) and (ii) investments we made in recent years which resulted in higher amortized costs in the period under review.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial income increased by €4.9 million or more than 100% from €3.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €8.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, mainly due to gains on exchange rates relating to foreign exchange transactions, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar against the euro.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial charges slightly decreased by €0.1 million or 0.1% from €69.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €69.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Despite an increase in interest expenses on, among others, the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility for the year ended December 31, 2022, our financial charges decreased in 2022 compared to the previous year, mainly due to the one-off effect of the reversal in 2021 of the amortized costs on the senior secured floating rate notes which we redeemed in 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes decreased by €0.4 million or 1.5% from €26.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €26.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Profit for the period increased by €16.9 million or 54.7% from €30.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €47.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 due to the factors discussed above. 116 -----

Subsubsection Text: Revenues from contracts with customers increased by €150.3 million or 28.9% from €520.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €670.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was the result of a strong rebound in the Group’s activities in 2021 following the progressive easing and removal of the restrictions imposed in the countries in which we operate to overcome the COVID-19 pandemic. Excluding the revenue contribution of our Emerging Brands, our revenues from contracts with customers would have increased by €108.5 million or 20.8% from €520.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €629.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Our revenue experienced a solid growth across all the main regions in which we operate (EMEA, the Americas and APAC) and type of goods sold. Revenue from our direct e-commerce grew from €3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €46.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly as a result of the €41.8 million seven-month revenue contribution of Lumens, which we acquired in June 2021.

Subsubsection Text: Purchases of raw materials and variation in inventories increased by €30.5 million or 19.8% from €154.2 million (representing 29.6% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €184.7 million (representing 27.5% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly due to increased purchases of raw materials, semifinished goods and finished products and variations in stock as a result of higher volumes in 2021 including as a result of the post-COVID-19 pandemic rebound and the price increase of such materials and products as well as the contribution from Lumens which we consolidated in our financial statements starting from June 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Personnel costs increased by €24.9 million or 22.8% from €109.3 million (representing 21.0% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €134.2 million (representing 20.0% of our revenues from contracts with customers) for the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly as a result of higher costs for salaries and wages, employees severance indemnities and pension charges and other personnel costs, due to, among others, an increase in the number of our employees to 2,020 employees as of December 31, 2021, compared to 1,704 employees as of December 31, 2021 primarily due to the consolidation of Lumens in our results of operations from June 2021. 118 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

This was mainly due to lower allowance for bad and doubtful debt, provisions for other risks and provisions for other charges in 2021, partially offset by higher provisions for pension liabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other costs and charges increased by €2.5 million or 30.5% from €8.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €10.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This was mainly due to higher costs for property services, other taxes and duties, purchase of office supplies and consumables and other operating costs due to the consolidation of Lumens in our results of operations from June 2021 or in connection with the acquisition thereof as well as the setting up of Fendi Casa.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Amortization, depreciation and impairment increased by €5.1 million or 15.6% from €32.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €37.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was mainly due to increased depreciation of both tangible assets and intangible assets as a result of investments made in recent years which resulted in higher amortized costs in 2021, while the depreciation of right of use assets (i.e. IFRS 16 leases) remained substantially stable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial income amounted to €3.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to €2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 and mainly comprises gains on exchange rates relating to foreign exchange transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial charges increased by €11.3 million or 19.6% from €57.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €69.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, mainly as a result of the higher amount of the Existing Floating Rate Notes issued in 2021 (i.e. €470.0 million) compared to the Issuer’s previously existing €320.0 million aggregate principal amount of floating rate notes due 2025. Financial charges also comprise the release of amortized costs on the notes that were redeemed in 2021, realized and unrealized differences in exchange rates and other interest expense on the Revolving Credit Facility and other indebtedness.

This increase was mainly due to higher profit for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the corresponding period of 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Profit for the period increased by €8.3 million or 36.7% from €22.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €30.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to the factors discussed above. 119 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the ability of a group to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, capital expenditure, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations and acquisitions. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily to operate our business, meet our debt service obligations, fund capital expenditures, including for our research and product development activities, fund salaries and other associated costs, fund acquisitions and pay taxes. Our primary source of liquidity is our cash from operating activities. Drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility represent a supplemental source of liquidity which we utilize from time to time primarily for working capital requirements. For instance, as a precautionary measure, we entirely drew the Revolving Credit Facility on March 17, 2020 to strengthen our cash position in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which we fully repaid in the fourth quarter of 2020. We expect that €18.6 million of drawn amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will remain outstanding following the Refinancing. In addition, in the event that freely available cash on our balance sheet on or about the Issue Date is lower than our estimate, we may draw down additional amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date or shortly thereafter. On or around the Issue Date, we expect to upsize the Revolving Credit Facility from €100.0 million to €140.0 million, hence further enhancing our liquidity sources. In the periods under review, our debt service obligations consisted primarily of interest payments on the Existing Notes (as well as certain previously existing senior secured floating rate notes due 2025 which we refinanced in 2021 through the issuance of the Existing Floating Rate Notes) and borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility. Following the Transactions, including the offering of the Notes and the application of the proceeds therefrom, our debt service obligations will consist primarily of interest payments on the Notes and the Existing Floating Rate Notes and borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings, will be adequate to meet our anticipated general liquidity needs and debt service obligations, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes or other debt, including the Existing Floating Rate Notes, when due. If our cash flows from operating activities are lower than expected or our capital expenditure requirements exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of capital depend on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions, and capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our debt, and our general financial performance. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Structure and Our Indebtedness—Our substantial leverage and debt service _obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial position and results of operations and preclude us from satisfying our obligations under the Notes and the Notes Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Structure and Our Indebtedness—The Issuer is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and depends exclusively on cash from its operating companies”._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Net cash flows from operations_ Net cash flow from operating activities decreased by €5.7 million or 24.6% from €23.2 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €17.5 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023. The decrease was primarily due to higher financial interest paid due to the increase in the applicable interest rate on our floating rate indebtedness, from €25.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022 to €33.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. 120 ----- Net cash flow from operating activities decreased by €21.6 million or 22.8% from €94.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €73.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily due to a change in net working capital from positive €12.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to negative €25.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, higher income taxes paid in 2022 due to the increase in business activity in the preceding year as well as higher financial interest paid for the year ended December 31, 2022 in connection with the increase in the applicable interest rate on our floating rate indebtedness, which offset the higher profit for 2022 compared to 2021. Net cash flow from operating activities increased by €26.4 million or 38.7% from €68.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €94.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily due to higher profit for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the same period in 2020 including as a result of strong business growth for the year as well as the positive contribution of the change in net working capital which amounted to €12.6 million in 2021 compared to €0.3 million in 2020. _Net cash flows from / (used in) investing activities_ Net cash flows used in investing activities decreased by €74.0 million or 80.6% from €91.8 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €17.8 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023. The decrease was primarily due to higher cash used in investing activities in the six months ended June 30, 2022 for the acquisition of Audo, for €74.9 million, net of cash acquired. Net cash flows used in investing activities decreased by €62.8 million or 36.2% from €173.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €110.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily due lower cash invested in acquisitions which, net of cash acquired, amounted to €74.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (in connection with the acquisition of Audo) compared to €131.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 (in connection with the acquisition of Lumens). Net cash flows used in investing activities increased by €153.3 million from €20.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €173.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Lumens in 2021 for €131.3 million, net of cash acquired as well as €7.5 million of cash invested in acquisition of non-current financial assets in 2021, compared to € nil in 2020. _Net cash flows from / (used in) financing activities_ Net cash flows used in financing activities increased by €6.0 million or more than 100% from €4.0 million for the six month ended June 30, 2022 to €10.0 million for the six month ended June 30, 2023. The increase was primarily due to the balance between the amount of the first tranche of the deferred price for the acquisition of Audo (€39.0 million) and the cash from the drawdown of the Revolving Credit Facility in January 2023 (€29.8 million). Net cash flows used in financing activities amounted to €18.7 million (mainly consisting of payments of principal amount of lease liabilities for €16.2 million) for the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to net cash flow from investing activities of €130.5 million (mainly consisting of the difference between the floating rate notes which were redeemed in 2021 and the Existing Floating Rate Notes which were issued in connection therewith). Net cash flows from financing activities amounted to €130.5 million (mainly consisting of the difference between the floating rate notes which were redeemed in 2021 and the Existing Floating Rate Notes which were issued in connection therewith) for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to cash flow used in financing activities of €19.1 million (mainly consisting of payments of principal amount of lease liabilities for €10.1 million and a decrease in financial payables) for the year ended December 31, 2020.

For the year ended December 31, 2022, our capital expenditure was €39.0 million (4.6% of our revenues), primarily in molds and industrial equipment, development costs, patents, licenses, trademarks and other intellectual property rights, investments in B&B’s plants in Novedrate, Misinto e Caldogno and the renovation of 121 ----- certain B&B’s DOS, investments in IT, e-commerce platforms, supply chain and logistics, investments in leasehold improvements of the Fendi Casa DOS in Milan and the opening of a DOS in Miami. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our capital expenditure was €34.7 million (5.1% of our revenues), primarily in connection with investment in production lines and to further strengthen our research and development for the realization of prototypes and molds and new products, as well as investments in IT, digital initiatives and shop-in-shop facilities. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our capital expenditure was €22.7 million (4.3% of our revenues) primarily to fund improvements at Arclinea’s plant in Caldogno and B&B’s plant in Novedrate and for research and development expenditures. Subsubsection Text: We normally provide warranties for general repairs pursuant to contracts with our customers. Extended warranties or maintenance services are usually not provided. The amount of the provisions for such contingencies included in our financial statements as of June 30, 2023 was €4.2 million. Additionally, when we receive advance payments in connection with a project in B&B’s Contract division, we may from time to time be required to provide the relevant customer with bank guarantees and/or performance bonds to protect the customer in case of our non-performance of our obligations under the relevant contractual arrangements. As of June 30, 2023, B&B bank guarantees and performance bonds given to third parties amounted to €6.0 million. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to Our Business—We may be subject to production and litigation risks associated with our commercial contract divisions”. Earn-out related to the acquisition of Audo_ On May 24, 2022, we completed the acquisition of Audo. The relevant share purchase agreement dated April 27, 2022 (the “Audo SPA”) provides, among others, that in addition to the purchase price, the seller thereunder would be entitled to an earn-out for an amount of DKK 80,000,000 (approximately €10.8 million as of December 31, 2022 by applying an exchange rate of 7.44 DKK per euro) in case Audo’s turnover for the financial year 2023 had reached DKK 529,400,000 (approximately €71 million by applying an exchange rate of 7.44 DKK per euro). As we do not consider reaching the threshold identified above probable, we did not recognize any financial liability in relation to such earn-out.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or the future cash flows of a financial instrument will be changed because of changes in market interest rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates primarily relates to long-term debt with variable interest rates, such as the Existing Floating Rate Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The exchange rate risk is the risk that the fair value or the future cash flows of an exposure will vary because of fluctuations in exchange rates. The Group’s exposure to the risk of fluctuations in exchange rates arises mainly from the Group’s operating activities (when revenue or costs are denominated in a foreign currency) and the Group’s net investments in foreign subsidiaries. Although the Group has a strong international presence, use of the Euro as the transactional currency for most transactions currently mitigates the risk tied to exchange rate fluctuations. The Group is mainly exposed to positions denominated in Euro, Danish Krone, Yen and U.S. Dollar; however, current volumes do not have a material impact on the Group’s financial and economic results. Consequently, no analysis was carried out with respect to the Group’s sensitivity to fluctuations in exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations in respect of a financial instrument or a commercial agreement, thus leading to a financial loss. The Group is exposed to the credit risk deriving from its operating activities (mostly for trade receivables and credit notes) and deposits with banks and financial institutions. 123 ----- The credit risk correlated to commercial counterparties is managed by the individual subsidiaries and monitored by the Group. The Group has no significant credit risk concentrations. However, procedures are in place to ensure that sales of products and services are carried out to customers with high reliability, taking into account their financial position, past experience and other factors. Credit limits on main customers are based on internal and external valuations on the basis of thresholds. Use of credit limits is monitored periodically. We do not deem our customer credit risk to be high; therefore, we do not hedge this risk beyond implementing ordinary credit risk management procedures and controls. As of June 30, 2023, there are €2.1 million of receivables overdue for over twelve months, which are fully covered under a provision for allowance for bad and doubtful debt.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk we will not have enough financial resources available to meet our financial obligations and commitments when due. In particular, the two main factors that determine our liquidity are, on one hand, the resources generated or absorbed by operating and investment activities and, on the other hand, the maturity and renewal of financial liabilities. Historically, we have put in place certain procedures aimed at optimizing cash flow management and reducing our liquidity risk, including the maintenance of an adequate level of available liquid assets and adequate borrowing facilities. We continue to monitor our liquidity risk by using a liquidity planning tool.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our activities and debt financing expose us to a variety of risks, the most significant of which are exchange rate risk, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. Our overall risk management strategy seeks to minimize the potential adverse effects of such risks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Policies and New Accounting Standards
Subsubsection Text: For a discussion of the critical accounting estimates and judgments and certain new accounting standards affecting us, please see the notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. 124 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The historical data below should be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalization”, “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data” and along with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the related notes thereto, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The information below is not necessarily indicative of our future results of operations. The following discussion contains forward-looking statements that reflect our plans, estimates and beliefs. Our actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to these differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, particularly in the sections entitled “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements”._

We operate in the Core High-End Design market, which accounted for approximately €47 billion by retail value globally in 2022. The Core High-End Design market is comprised of the following segments: - Living and Bedroom: includes living room and bedroom products, such as upholstery, beds, drawers, tables, cabinets, desks, chairs and other furnishings; - Kitchen: includes fitted kitchens, kitchen units, cupboards and other furniture and decorative items; - Bathroom: includes bathroom equipment products such as bath tubs, whirlpools, ceramics, bathroom furniture, sanitary fittings, faucets, shower units and related accessories; - Lighting: includes lighting products for both indoor and outdoor use such as pendants, floor lamps, wall lamps, light fixtures, fittings and other lighting products; and - Outdoor: includes outdoor furniture items such as tables, sofas, chairs and other items for residential and commercial use. The segmentation of the Core High-End Design market for 2021 is represented below. Source: Industry Report, Management Estimates 125 ----- While our product portfolio spans all segments of the Core High-End Design market, we primarily operate in the Living and Bedroom and in the Lighting segments. Living and Bedroom represents the largest segment of the Core High-End Design market, accounting for almost 50% of the market total value in 2021. The distribution of high-end furniture and lighting products occurs through both direct and indirect channels: - Wholesale: includes products sold through a network of third-party distributors, agents, and dealers across a range of formats, including third-party mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops, corners and displays within multi-brand design retailers, as well as online third-party retailers, to various types of customers including personal consumers, architects, designers, contractors, developers and corporate customers; - Retail: includes products sold directly by the producer through dedicated directly-operated stores (comparable to our DOS channel); - Contract: includes bespoke design services for residential and commercial customers; and - Online: includes sales through both directly operated and third-party operated e-commerce websites (in contrast to the Group’s direct online channel, which only includes directly operated e-commerce websites). The Core High-End Design market has been growing steadily over the past few years. Between 2019 and 2022, the market grew at a CAGR of 7%. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, between 2014 and 2019, the market grew at a CAGR of 5%. Management estimates that 2023 will experience a slight decline in growth based on temporary headwinds which they do not expect will affect the long-term trajectory of the market. Between 2022 and 2026, the market is forecast to grow at a CAGR of between 2% and 5%. While data for 2026 are still provisional, preliminary forecasts estimate the Core High-End Design market reaching the range of €50 to €60 billion, with structural tailwinds driving the growth: - Cocooning & self-expression: Covid-19 has reshaped the relationship between individuals and interiors, driving demand across home categories: interior design is becoming an aesthetic aid to inner peace and wellbeing with the home representing a focal point for everyday life activities, providing a personal ‘safer’ shelter; and furniture as a means for self-expression with increased “at home” conviviality with enlarged groups of people entering our houses through work video conferencing and at home social moments; - Space hybridization: Living spaces are transforming into “multi-purpose” areas, equipped for several functions such as home office, gym at home and spa-feel bedroom etc.; - Everything but better: Outside of the home, design consumption is increasingly driven by a continuous appetite for High End Design and a refined aesthetic together with a progressive evolution of commercial spaces toward residential aesthetics and search for improved quality and a refined aesthetic of spaces; - Wealth ruralization: Major metropolitan areas will remain central, although dispersion of wealthy people across suburban areas is accelerating, creating additional demand for holiday houses and investments in furnishing; and - Further urbanization in emerging market: Urbanization remains a significant trend in emerging markets especially with the expanding Chinese middle class and can be a catalyst for high end design product demand. 126 ----- Source: Industry Report, Management Estimates

The high-end design market is characterized by a number of consumer trends that are segment-specific. However, the market is generally influenced by three key factors: - GDP growth; - real estate market conditions; and - consumer confidence and disposable income. These factors tend to affect or reflect consumer behavior towards the purchasing of lighting and furniture products. While demand for high-end design products is generally less price-elastic than for products in other segments, slowdowns in real estate development also tend to affect high-end design products’ demand. Other factors affecting market performance include demographic and socio-economic trends, such as: - increasing urbanization rates, especially in emerging economies; - decreasing average household size; - improving availability of western consumer goods driven by the increasing prevalence of large organized retail chains in many large emerging economies; and - rapid growth of middle and high-income middle classes in emerging markets, who are increasingly oriented towards sophisticated and high-end design products.

Demand is also affected by product innovation deriving from technological advances. The introduction of LED technology in the lighting segment, for instance, has fostered the design of new products, while also lowering production costs. The efficiency of LED technology has acted as a further driver of demand, bolstered by the importance of energy saving solutions in modern projects and certifications (e.g. LEED). Other factors influencing demand are the availability of credit (including both the availability of financing for real estate developments and the provision of mortgage financings) and the product replacement cycle (i.e. the frequency with which consumers purchase replacement products). Consumer spending trends across different segments show that: - the Lighting and Outdoor segments are generally characterized by shorter replacement cycles and lower average pricing per item (given the typically smaller size of these items); and 127 ----- - the Kitchen segment is generally characterized by longer product replacement cycles and higher pricing per item.

Europe (including Turkey and Russia) accounts for approximately 44% of the high-end design market, the Americas (including North and South America) accounts for approximately 31%, APAC (including Asia and Japan but excluding Australia and New Zealand) accounts for approximately 19% and the Rest of the World accounts for approximately 7%. The increasing importance of the APAC region in the global Core High-End Design market has been driven by continued demand over the last few years, mainly reflecting the economic performance of the reference economies. Less pronounced market growth in Europe in recent years has led to an increase in the relative share of APAC and the Americas in the overall market. Rebounding GDP growth in the world’s larger economies following the COVID-19 pandemic, the renewed “home role”, the recovery of the real estate market coupled with historical trends such as a rising class of middle and high-income consumers in emerging markets, and the ongoing “westernization” of Asian consumer preferences are all expected to have a positive impact on future demand. We expect the increase in demand will be driven primarily by the APAC region, with expected growth per annum to 2026 at 11%. Demand in Europe and Americas is expected to further benefit from favorable demand trends with expected growth per annum of 5% and 6% respectively. Source: Industry Report, Management estimates

We distinguish three main groups of competitors in the markets in which we operate: - pure design, personal luxury and designer-driven brands; - premium design brands; and - branded retailers. Pure design brands (including Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen) are usually European independent players who have developed significant design heritage through a long track record of iconic products. Pure design brands are characterized by their strong design roots, collaborations with prestigious architects and designers, iconic products and international reach, primarily through multi-brand retailers, as well as by their high specialization and strong production skills. Other notable pure design brands include Artemide, Vitra, Poltrona Frau and Bulthaup. 128 ----- Personal luxury brands are typically large luxury brands that have diversified into homewares. Personal luxury brands rely on their brand strength to market their products and as a result, the design of the products tends to reflect the influence of the style of the brand’s creative directors. Personal luxury brands typically rely on external production and utilize a mixed distribution model, with sales through a combination of multi-brand retailers and directly operated stores. Personal luxury brands include brands such as Armani Casa, Fendi Casa, Kenzo and Versace. Designer-driven brands are typically managed by a single iconic designer who leverage their “brand name” to generate demand. Designer-driven brands tend to position their products as a lifestyle offering, characterized by a strong identity and recognizable style. Production of designer-driven brands is typically external. Examples of designer-driven brands are Liaigre and Visionnaire. Premium design brands are typically Lighting and Furniture retailers that either have general upper-premium positioning (with differences among geographies) or have more mainstream positioning but have extended certain product lines into the upper-premium range. This includes brands such as Ligne Roset, Cattelan Italia, Moen and Kos. Branded retailers are typically geographically specific mono-brand retailers with an upper-premium positioning, such as Restoration Hardware, Williams Sonoma and Design Within Reach. The degree of competition among these brands differs by geographic area. Branded retailers have had considerable success in the United States market and their significant growth over the last few years has been partially linked to the overall positive performance of the United States economy. Retailers accounted for approximately 15% of the total Core High-End Design market by value in 2021. Pure design brands tend to be more common in the European market, but are also present in the United States market, predominantly in large cities such as Los Angeles and New York. The competitive environment in Europe remains more fragmented, with small pure design brands addressing specific customer segments or serving a specific design taste in niche markets. Personal luxury brands are more popular in emerging economies, which is where most of their revenues originate. Premium and pure design brands accounted for approximately 84% of the market in 2021. 129 -----

We are a leading global design company in the high-end furniture and lighting markets. We design, produce, distribute and sell high-end lighting and furniture solutions. We offer our products through three core companies with leading positions in the global high-end design market: Flos, an Italian lighting brand, Louis Poulsen, a Danish lighting brand, and B&B, an Italian group comprising several leading furniture brands (B&B Italia, Maxalto, Azucena and Arclinea). Our Core Brands are complemented by our three Emerging Brands, which have growing relevance in the global high-end lighting, accessories and furniture markets: Lumens, a U.S. digital ecommerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture which we acquired in June 2021, Fendi Casa, an Italian furniture, lighting and home accessories brand and operated through our joint venture with high-end luxury brand Maison Fendi, which commenced operations in January 2022, and Audo, a Danish furniture, lighting and accessories brand which we acquired in May 2022. For the twelve months ended June 30, 23, we had total revenue of €857.3 million, Adjusted EBITDA of €218.4 million, net profit of €41.1 million and Adjusted EBITDA Margin above 25% and, as of June 30, 2023, we had 2,171 employees. Since our incorporation in 2018, we have successfully created a one-stop shop for high-quality design furniture and lighting products for both individuals and businesses around the world. We benefit from a well-balanced and diversified portfolio resulting from the combination of unique brand heritage and iconic products of each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B Italia and those of our Emerging Brands, and provide a complementary, high-end offering across a broad range of product categories, brands, sales channels and geographic areas. As part of our business model, Design Holding provides the strategic direction necessary for the continued development of our business, while acting as a “center of excellence” across key capabilities. Through its coordinating activities, Design Holding sets the vision and strategic direction of the Group and establishes the necessary guidelines and coordination among our brands, in particular in the areas of finance, control, legal affairs, governance, human resources management, business strategy and digital strategies. In particular, we believe the role of Design Holding in coordinating our efforts among our distribution channels with the aim to foster the growth of our brands is of paramount importance and has been one of the key contributors to our success. Design Holding also facilitates the adoption of consistent Group policies and operating processes, with a particular focus ESG matters. The following charts set forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by brand and product category, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022:

(1) Includes the B&B Italia, Maxalto, Arclinea and Azucena brands. (2) Includes the Lumens, Fendi Casa and Audo brands. As a global design company, we offer our high-end lighting and furniture products to a diversified customer base of individual consumers, architects, designers and other specifiers for residential use and businesses around the globe for commercial use through an omni-channel approach comprising four key sales channels: 130 ----- (i) _Contract. Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services for residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom-made products, as well as certain complementary products from third-party producers; (ii) _Direct E-Commerce. Our direct e-commerce channel consists of our e-commerce websites selling in approximately 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our U.S. online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products; (iii) _Directly-Operated Stores. Our DOS channel comprises retail stores that are directly managed by us and sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands; and (iv) _Wholesale. Our wholesale channel comprises over 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale, operated by third parties, located around the world in a range of formats, including mono-brand stores, shop-in-shops and multi-brand stores, as well as 1,122 e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure players in e-commerce. Our contract, DOS and e-commerce channels represent our “direct-to-customer” channels, which allow us to directly reach our end-customers with a flexible, tailor-made and cost-efficient approach adapted to a rapidly evolving market. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by sales channel, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: We operate directly or indirectly in more than 130 countries around the world. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022 by geography, giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022: Our products are distinguished by their design content, combining innovation and technology with the rich design heritage that characterizes the Italian and Danish traditions. Each of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B maintains a portfolio of iconic products, a number of which have been popular for more than 50 years and were created in collaboration with some of the most prestigious designers in the world, including Antonio Citterio, Gaetano Pesce, Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, Philippe Starck, Poul Henningsen and Arne Jacobsen. Our products have received numerous global design awards and are held in the permanent collections of art and design museums worldwide, including in the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, Le Centre Pompidou in Paris and La Triennale di Milano in Milan. Our Core Brands are complemented by the over 400 brands (including third-party brands) sold by Lumens through its U.S. ecommerce website, the prestigious Fendi Casa brand, which is the result of our joint venture with Maison Fendi, 131 ----- and The Audo, Menu and ByLassen (now merged into the Audo brand), our Nordic-design furniture and lighting brands, which draw upon both historical design archives and collaborations with new designers. Throughout our history, our strong relationships with prestigious designers and our ability to attract up-and-coming design talents coupled with our continuous efforts in technology and product development have enabled us to complement our heritage collection with successful new products that have reinforced the growth of each of our brands over the years. Since our early years of operation, we have also shown attention to sustainability, as demonstrated by the publication of sustainability reports by Flos and B&B since 2015 and 2016, respectively, and by Louis Poulsen since 2019, and the publication of the first Group Sustainability Report in 2021. Sustainability is key to our business and our brands are committed to being recognized as leaders in adopting sustainable policies and practices and in developing a new concept of luxury high-end design that has sustainability at its core. The Group achieved carbon neutrality (scope 1 and 2) in 2020. Our commitment to sustainability is founded on the following three principles: (i) Design for Planet, (ii) Design for People and (iii) Design for Culture. For more information on our ESG initiatives, achievements and goals, see “Our Business—ESG Initiatives”.

Subsubsection Title: Leadership position and strong track record of prestigious industry awards in the attractive luxury design market with highly attractive growth prospects
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global design company in the highly fragmented and attractive core high-end design market, with €857.3 million in total revenue, Adjusted EBITDA of €218.4 million and net profit of €41.1 million, in each case for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. We believe that we are approximately 1.2 times larger than our closest competitor, almost 2 times larger than our second closest competitor and 3.2 to 3.8 times larger than our third through fifth closest competitors, in each case based on 2022 revenues and our analysis of publicly available financial data for such year. Despite our size, our reference market is highly fragmented. We focus on the luxury segment of the core high-end design market, characterized by rich product heritage, strong and globally recognized brands, iconic products, superior craftmanship, brand exclusivity and premiumness. We estimate our market share to be approximately 4% based on 2022 revenues and our analysis of publicly available financial data for such year, implying a tangible opportunity to further consolidate our market share by expanding in underpenetrated geographies. Many of our brands and products have received various international design accolades and the highest industry awards throughout their history, including 16 Compasso d’Oro awards (including the Compasso d’Oro Product Lifetime Achievement Award awarded to Flos’ Arco lamp in 2020), the first of which in 1955 and the last of which in 2022, NYCxDesign Award, IF Gold Award, IF Design Award, FX Interior Design Awards, Danish Design Award, German Design Award, Elle Deco International Design Award and Lighting Design Award. Our products are held in the permanent collections of art and design museums such as the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, Le Centre Pompidou in Paris, the Design Museum in Copenhagen, La Triennale di Milano in Milan and the Today Art Museum in Beijing, confirming the excellence, renown and appeal of our designs. We estimate that in 2022 the luxury design market (a subset of the global luxury market), which is our focus market, represented approximately 63% (valued at approximately €31 billion in that same period) of the total core high-end design market, with the remaining approximately 37% represented by the premium design market (valued at approximately €16 billion in that same period), typically addressed by branded retailers and premium design brands. The global luxury market grew at a CAGR of 6% between 2014 and 2019 and 3% between 2019 and 2022, reaching €1.4 trillion in 2022, while the global core high-end design market grew at a CAGR of 5% between 2014 and 2019 and 7% between 2019 and 2022, notwithstanding a moderate contraction in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The global core high-end design market exceeded pre-pandemic levels already in 2021, reaching €40 billion in such year (compared to €38 billion in 2019 and €35 billion in 2020), continued to grow in 2022, reaching €47 billion, and is estimated to further grow between 2022 and 2026 at a CAGR of between 2% and 5%, reaching approximately €50 to €60 billion in 2026. For 2023, temporary headwinds are expected to affect the global core high-end design market, while the mid-term outlook remains broadly unchanged. Between 2014 to 2022, we outperformed our reference market by increasing our revenues at a CAGR of 9% for each period, which enabled us to reinforce our market positioning, notwithstanding a moderate contraction in 2020 due to the COVID 19 pandemic. Our CAGR for these periods was calculated on the basis of like-for-like growth of certain of our acquired brands beginning from the year of their respective acquisition (namely, Flos in 2014, B&B in 2015, Louis Poulsen in 2018 and Lumens in 2021). The growth of the high-end design market is driven by certain structural tailwinds, including (i) the increasing working time that people spend in their homes (estimated to be approximately 3.5 days per week in 2022, 132 ----- compared to approximately 2.6 days per week prior to COVID-19 pandemic), with approximately 98% of workers indicating that they prefer to work remotely, in part due to the change of work habits resulting from the COVID19 pandemic, (ii) the increased use of home offices (with approximately 60% of the people working from home estimated to have a dedicated home office space) and the increasingly important role played by kitchens, which are often considered the heart of the home (with approximately 60% of kitchen renovators having upgraded or added a kitchen island), (iii) the global GDP increase driven by infrastructure renovation (estimated to have contributed approximately 20% of the global GDP growth from 2010 to 2020), (iv) wealth ruralization, which has caused migration of wealth to rural communities and countryside, thereby increasing the demand for high-end design products (with over 50% of adults estimated to prefer living in small towns and rural areas compared to approximately 39% in 2018), and (v) the urbanization trends and associated economic growth in emerging markets, in particular China and India, with an urbanization index estimated to reach approximately 116 and 113, respectively, in 2025 (compared to approximately 100 for both countries in 2016). In addition, the high-end design market is characterized by smaller competitors, making us one of the few design groups that can serve a diverse customer base across a variety of product and service categories and geographies, enabling us to benefit from cross-selling initiatives and giving us the opportunity to grow through selected strategic acquisitions in the segments where we currently operate or in complementary adjacent segments. See “Our Strategies—Pursue _strategic acquisition opportunities that align with our overall goals and objectives”._

Subsubsection Title: Balanced and highly resilient portfolio of iconic designs and new products generating a predictable revenue mix
Subsubsection Text: Our internationally-acclaimed product portfolios represent a balance between timeless heritage designs and innovative products. Certain iconic designs have become synonymous with our brands and continue to attract significant customer demand decades after being introduced. We believe that maintaining these products in our portfolio helps to limit the effect of market trends and improves our revenue resiliency. Our internal research and product development teams work closely with our designers to continually update and reconfigure iconic pieces to meet the evolving needs and tastes of our customers while maintaining the identity of each of our brands and the distinctive original features that loyal customers worldwide have long associated with our products. Moreover, to further support the success of our most iconic designs and refresh existing and new customers’ interest in our products, from time to time, we also launch new special or limited editions of our heritage products, such as Flos’ Arco K lamp in 2022 with an innovative crystal base, B&B Italia’s Le Bambole x Stella McCartney in 2023, as a result of a collaboration with the renowned English stylist, and PH Pale Rose, a special edition collection of Louis Poulsen’s PH lamps designed in 1926, which we launched in 2022. We also launch new products on an ongoing basis to complement our portfolio of heritage designs and our design portfolio also comprises numerous unexploited heritage designs from prestigious international designers that have not been commercialized before, which we believe represents an important growth opportunity for our Group. For example, we estimate that Louis Poulsen, Audo, B&B and Flos have a significant archive with unexploited designs from heritage designers dating back to the 1950s and 1970s. Between 2020 and 2023, our brands have reintroduced several heritage designs from their archives, including “Camaleonda” and “Scacchi” from B&B Italia, certain versions of “La Lampadina” by Flos, and the “PH Septima Pendant” and “PH 2/2 Question” from Louis Poulsen. Our efforts in research and product development and innovation in both design and technology ensure both the longevity of our iconic products and the continued introduction of creative and successful new designs, all of which ensures a balanced and predictable revenue mix. The following chart sets forth the revenue of B&B Italia, Maxalto, Flos and Louis Poulsen for the year ended December 31, 2022, divided by launch year of the products that these brands sold in such year (i.e. before 2010, between 2010 and 2017 and between 2018 and 2022). 133 ----- Our revenue mix is well balanced relative to the year of launch of the various products we sell in any given period. We believe that such balanced revenue mix, coupled with the significant contribution of made-to-order sales to our total sales, gives us good visibility of our expected revenue streams in the short term (approximately eight weeks for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, providing estimated revenue visibility of approximately two months for our made-to-order products).

Subsubsection Title: Unique brand power based on design heritage, iconic products, long-standing relationships with top designers and loyal networks of specifiers in local markets
Subsubsection Text: Our business benefits from significant competitive advantages that make our business model difficult to replicate, including our iconic product portfolio, design heritage, long-standing relationships with top designers and specifiers and strong technical know-how. Our iconic brands benefit from association with a broad base of (i) prestigious and globally renowned designers, such as Mario Bellini, Antonio Citterio, Vincent Van Duysen, Piero Lissoni, Philippe Starck, Jasper Morrison, Gaetano Pesce, Olafur Eliasson, Patricia Urquiola, Nendo, Michael Anastassiades, Konstantin Grcic, Naoto Fukusawa, Barber & Osgerby, Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec and Formafantasma; (ii) heritage designers, such as Tobia Scarpa, Poul Henningsen, Arne Jacobsen, Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, Gino Sarfatti, Mogens Lassen, Flemming Lassen and Verner Panton; and (iii) talented emerging designers, such as Chiara Andreatti, Anne Boysen, Joris Laarman, Gabriel Tan, Øivind Alexander Slaatto and Peter Mabeo. Many of our designer partners have received multiple awards and recognitions for their designs and have their designs held in the collections of museums around the world. We believe our privileged relationships with renowned designers and our ability to attract new promising designers represent a significant competitive advantage. Some of our designers have collaborated with our brands for many years, creating a strong design relationship and mutual understanding of the needs and preferences of our customer base. Our relationship with designers is mutually beneficial, as it allows us to expand our brand recognition across a wider customer demographic and adds value for the designers, who gain prestige and visibility by working with leading furniture and lighting brands. Designers collaborate closely with our internal research and product development teams, which have accumulated extensive technical expertise and industry knowledge over decades and continually support our design innovation. The research and product development teams add substantial value to designers, providing an extensive knowledge base on product feasibility with respect to design, materials and market success; research on the latest trends, materials and technological innovations; design and development support for concepts, prototypes and molds; negotiation support with suppliers to ensure high component quality standards at competitive prices; and centralized assembly process and production planning. In addition, management teams at each of our brands ensure that any new design that is being proposed or considered internally is fully consistent with the relevant brand’s image and philosophy, which we believe is key to the success of any product and the continued integrity of our brands. In addition to our ability to attract and maintain relationships with world-renowned designers, we also benefit from strong relationships with a widespread network of specifiers, especially smaller, committed professional design and architecture studios that continually choose and promote our products to meet the design needs of their clients. We consider these specifiers, which we define as any party that is involved in the purchasing decision but is not the end user of our products, including but not limited to architects, interior designers, lighting engineers 134 ----- and landscape architects, a loyal and resilient customer intermediary that, through repeat business, provides us with a significant competitive advantage locally in the geographic markets we serve and add to our recognition with end customers.

Subsubsection Title: Diversified business model across product categories, geographies and distribution channels with low customer concentration risk
Subsubsection Text: Our business is well diversified across product categories, geographies and distribution channels. We offer a broad and diversified portfolio of products addressing the full spectrum of our customers’ requirements and we believe we are not dependent on any specific product category. Our product offering is comprised of two product categories, lighting and furniture, which accounted for 64.0% and 34.1% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively, giving _pro forma effect to the acquisition of Audo as if it had occurred on January 1, 2022. The lighting category includes our decorative, architectural and outdoor products, which accounted for 27.0%, 11.1% and 5.7% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively). The furniture category includes our living room and bedroom furniture and kitchen products (which accounted for 19.6% and 4.0% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively). Geographically, our business benefits from a balanced and diversified reach, with more than 130 countries served. The United States and Italy, as individual countries, represent the two largest contributors to our sales and accounted for 23.7% and 14.2% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively. Customers outside of our home geographies of Italy and Denmark generated approximately 79.3% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022, and approximately 26.0% of our GMV for such period was generated from sales in North America which were mainly attributable to Lumens, our digital e-commerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture in the United States, which we acquired in 2021. We expect the APAC region and North America to continue to drive growth, with consistent demand also expected in our home geographies and Western Europe. We also benefit from a diversified distribution network comprised of four distribution channels (contract, ecommerce, DOS and wholesale), enabling us to reach a broad range of customers. We expect our omni-channel distribution network will continue to represent a key contributor to our growth, driven in particular by our ecommerce business, which grew from €3.9 million of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 (or 0.7% of our revenue from contracts with customers in such year) to €103.7 million of revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 (or 12.2% of our revenue from contracts with customers for such period), mainly as a result of the acquisition of our U.S. based e-commerce platform Lumens in 2021. For further details on our distribution channels, see “—Sophisticated omni-channel distribution network focused on DTC and branded channels, _optimizing customer reach and maximizing brand strength”._ In addition to a diversified mix of product categories, geographies and distribution channels, we benefit from low customer concentration risk. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our top 20 customers generated 18.9% of our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Sophisticated omni-channel distribution network focused on DTC and branded channels, optimizing customer reach and maximizing brand strength
Subsubsection Text: Our distribution network is comprised of three direct-to-customer (“DTC”) channels (contract, DOS and ecommerce) and the wholesale channel. For the year ended December 31, 2022, the wholesale channel generated approximately 47.2%, the contract channel approximately 24.5%, the DOS network approximately 5.7% and ecommerce sales approximately 22.6% of our GMV, respectively. Our omni-channel approach allows us to reach a wide range of diversified customers both directly via our contract, DOS and e-commerce channels, and indirectly via our wholesale channel through a variety of intermediate players, including dealers, resellers, retailers and an extensive network of approximately 350,000 loyal specifiers, including architects and designers serving the local markets where we are present, which in our experience have a high degree of influence over the end customers purchase decisions. We believe our omni-channel distribution network optimizes customer reach and maximizes the strength of our brands. _Contract_ Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services to customers that are not typically accessible through traditional retail outlets, including residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom made products, as well as certain complementary products from third party producers. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our contract channel has approximately 12,000 projects in pipeline. 135 ----- Among some of the notable recent projects completed by the Contract division are the One Thousand Museum Residences by Zaha Hadid Architects in Miami, The Polaris Lounge by Studio SCB Chicago and the Bulgari Hotel in Tokyo and Rome by Antonio Citterio and Patricia Viel. We believe the wide variety of commercial customers and the larger scale of contract projects make our contract channel a strong vehicle for cross-selling opportunities, increasing the visibility of the products from all our brands and our market penetration. Although a large proportion of contract work is currently driven by B&B, the combination of our brands has provided us with the opportunity to broaden the scope of our contract work, offering a floor-to-ceiling contract service encompassing furnishings from B&B, kitchens from Arclinea and lighting products from Flos and Louis Poulsen. _DOS_ Our DOS channel is a powerful marketing tool that drives brand awareness, allows full control over our brands and often provides enhanced visibility to our end customers. It comprises retail stores that sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands, thereby increasing cross selling opportunities by giving our customers the opportunity to purchase such products. As an example, our new DOS in Boston, Massachusetts, sells products from our B&B Italia, Maxalto and Arclinea brands. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our DOS channel includes 19 stores managed directly by our Group companies, all located in key luxury markets around the world in cities such as Milan, London, New York, Paris and Hong Kong. DOS and directly-operated showrooms are a highly valuable distribution channel as they not only drive sales, but also increase brand strength, serving as a hub for marketing events and design fairs. _E-Commerce_ Our e-commerce channel consists of our e-commerce websites selling in 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, along with our U.S. online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products. _Wholesale_ Our wholesale channel includes 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale throughout the world, managed by third parties, in various different formats, with a special focus on (i) mono-brand stores (137), accounting for 6.9% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022; (ii) shop-in-shops (875), accounting for 9.0% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022; and (iii) multi-brand stores (4,490), accounting for 21.2% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022. We classify the mono-brand and shop-in-shop stores as the branded segment of our wholesale channel as our brands in those stores are clearly identifiable by the end-customers. The wholesale channel also includes e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure players in e-commerce (approximately 1,122), accounting for 10.1% of our GMV for the year ended December 31, 2022. The wholesale channel enables us to increase customer reach while limiting distribution costs. We benefit from long-standing customer relationships within our wholesale channel, with many of our dealers having sold products from our respective brands for several years.

Subsubsection Title: Flexible and robust industrial platform with control over entire value chain
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have ten in-house production facilities, differentiated by brand and product type, each of which focuses on the most critical and delicate processing phases to ensure the highest quality of our products. Specifically, we operate seven production facilities in Italy (two of which are located in Misinto (Milan), dedicated to B&B Italia and Fendi Casa, respectively), one in Valencia (Spain), one in Vejen (Denmark) and one in New York. Each facility is dedicated to a single brand’s production. As of June 30, 2023, our production facilities were supported by a network of approximately 1,950 carefully selected and diversified external suppliers located throughout the world and typically in close proximity to our inhouse production facilities, many of whom have been longstanding partners of ours. The following chart shows the composition of our suppliers by geographical area as of December 31, 2022: 136 ----- For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, approximately 44% of our production was carried out in house at our production facilities (typically relating to the most critical components of our products), while the remainder of our production (fabrication or assembly) was carried out through suppliers and partners outside the Group. This approach enables us to combine high levels of flexibility and scalability of production levels with the maintenance of high-quality standards and, coupled with our make-to-order driven footprint (with approximately 69% of our total production relating to make-to-order purchases for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023), allows us to have strong control over the entire value chain, from initial design of the product to supply and in-house production or outsourced production, as applicable, assembly of the finished product and transportation and logistics.

Subsubsection Title: Predictable revenues coupled with asset light, variable cost base and limited working capital requirements and strong cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: Our production is mainly focused on sales of made-to-order products, in particular that associated with our furniture, which represented approximately 69% of our total production for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, with the remainder being made-to-stock products. Our made-to-order sales typically have upfront payment terms, with approximately 30% to 50% of the final product price being paid by customers at the time of the order confirmation and the remaining approximately 70% to 50%, as applicable, being paid upon delivery. The significant contribution of our made-to-order sales to our total sales gives us visibility of our expected revenue streams in the short term (approximately eight weeks for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, providing revenue visibility of approximately two months for our made-to-order products). Where we do not operate on a made-to-order basis, we benefit from limited inventory risk given the long lifespan of our products. Our business, which is asset light by nature, also has a predominantly variable cost base. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we estimate that approximately 68% of our operating expenses was represented by variable costs. Our cash flow generation is in turn supported by low working capital and capital expenditure requirements. Our net operating working capital was €69.9 million as of June 30, 2023 (representing 8.2% of our total revenues for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023), €46.9 million as of December 31, 2022 (representing 5.5% of our total revenues for such year), €3.3 million as of December 31, 2021 (representing 0.5% of our total revenues for such year) (exceptionally low mainly due to the acquisition of Lumens in 2021), and €33.9 million as of December 31, 2020 (representing 6.4% of our total revenues for such year), resulting in limited working capital requirements. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively, capital expenditures represented only 4.7%, 4.6%, 5.1% and 4.3% of our total revenues for such periods, of which the majority represented discretionary growth capital expenditures. We have historically enjoyed strong cash flow generation through the economic cycle, including during the 20082010 global financial crisis, the European sovereign debt crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic, supported by our high profitability levels and limited capital expenditure requirements. We have also historically recorded stable Adjusted EBITDA Margin and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, we delivered consistently high Adjusted EBITDA Margins above 25% for each relevant period, despite the Emerging Brands having delivered lower margins than our Core Brands for these periods, mainly in light of the initial phase of their development. For the six months ended June 30, 2022 and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, our Pro Forma Revenue was €426.5 million, €700.3 million and €867.6 million, respectively (in each case giving pro forma effect to the acquisition of Lumens, as regards 2021, and Audo, as regards 2022, as if we had acquired them on January 1 of the relevant year). The revenue of Flos for the year ended December 31, 2014, the year of its acquisition, was €159.2 million. For the same periods, our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA was €102.2 million, €194.6 million and €219.3 million, respectively, and Pro Forma 137 ----- Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 24.0%, 27.2% and 25.3%, respectively. Our Free Cash Flow (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant period minus Maintenance Capital Expenditure for such period) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020 was €208.0 million, €206.6 million, €175.0 million and €133.2 million, resulting in Free Cash Flow Conversion (calculated as the ratio of Free Cash Flow for the relevant period to Adjusted EBITDA for such period) for each such period of 95.2%, 94.7%, 91.8% and 93.0%, respectively. We believe that our brand strength gives us strong pricing power, typically allowing us to pass the effects of increased raw material and component costs or adverse exchange rate fluctuations to our customers. Since our incorporation upon the joint acquisition by entities affiliated with Carlyle and Investindustrial of Flos, B&B Italia and Louis Poulsen in 2018, we have been able to reduce our net leverage from approximately 5.4x at the time of the acquisition (calculated at that time as the ratio of net financial indebtedness to (pre-IFRS 16) “Target Group Synergized EBITDA”) to 4.4x as of June 30, 2023 (calculated as the ratio of net financial indebtedness to Adjusted EBITDA, as presented in this Offering Memorandum).

Subsubsection Title: Experienced management team backed by a strong holding structure and committed shareholders
Subsubsection Text: All the Group companies operate under the strategic guidance of the highly dedicated and experienced management team and the board of directors of Design Holding. Our Group Chief Executive Officer Daniel Lalonde, who joined the Group in October 2021, and our Group Chief Financial Officer Alberto Toni, who joined the Group in May 2023, have brought a wealth of experience and an exceptional track record, further strengthening our role as an industry leader. In addition to the Group CEO and CFO roles, over the past few years, Design Holding has further reinforced its holding structure through the hires of a Group Strategy, M&A & Business Development Director, Group Chief Digital Officer, Group Human Resources Director, Group Contract Director, Group General Counsel, Group Marketing Director and Group E-commerce Manager. All of our recently hired personnel have long-standing experience and proven track-record in their respective fields, with over 20 years of experience on average per each member of the management team. See “Management”. Additionally, the executive teams at each of our brands are highly experienced in leading and growing successful design businesses, with relevant prior experience at large international companies. This experienced management team is backed by our principal shareholders, Investindustrial and Carlyle, each of which, directly or through its affiliates, has successfully invested in the design and luxury industries both in Europe and worldwide.
