We believe that our current management team and ownership structure will allow us to continue to attract and retain the industry’s top talent, further driving profitable growth. See “Principal Shareholders”.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance the desirability and strength of our brands
Subsubsection Text: Leveraging on our existing portfolio of high-end lighting and furniture solutions, we intend to further enhance the desirability of our brands through a series of initiatives. We aim to continue to attract up-and-coming international design talents and seek new collaborations with renowned stylists, fashion maisons and other players in the highend luxury industry to both develop new attractive and innovative products and reinforce the strength of our existing heritage designs, through for example the launch of new limited editions of our timeless iconic products. Our collaboration with English stylist Stella McCartney in 2023 for the development of B&B Italia’s Le Bambole x Stella McCartney is an example of how the close cooperation with top international brands in the high-end Luxury industry can reinforce the strength of our existing heritage designs. In addition, Louis Poulsen’s collaboration with talented emerging architect and designer Anne Boysen led to the production of the Moonsetter lamp, which was the winning design in the Next Danish Design Classic competition broadcast on national Danish television in 2020 and received the Lamp of the Year Award at the Design Awards in 2021. Another example of recent successful cooperation with a talented emerging designer is the Kompa Collection, designed by Botswanan Peter Mabeo for Fendi Casa, merging traditional African artisanship with luxury design. Going forward, we believe the enhancement of the desirability of our brands will also be increasingly dependent on our ability to deliver innovative products with a sustainability focus, including through eco-design, which considers environmental aspects at all stages of the product development process, in an effort to develop design solutions which make the lowest possible environmental impact throughout the product life cycle. For example, 138 ----- in 2023, we launched several eco-design projects, including Céramique, Emi, Bilboquet, Black Flag and Workmates for Flos, Eryt, Tortello Heri ‘O, Nooch and Cordoba Outdoor for B&B Italia, and Arclinea’s “g_cover” innovative new finishing, which is made with the recycled by-product from the manufacturing process of man-made graphite, enhancing the durability of Arclinea’s kitchens. We also intend to continue to support our younger brands through the various development phases and, in particular, we seek to accelerate the growth trajectory of our brands which are currently in their start-up phase, such Audo and Azucena, and development phase, such as Fendi Casa, Maxalto, Lumens and Arclinea, and to continue to develop new products. In order to continue to strengthen the desirability of our brands, we expect to continue to coordinate our marketing and advertising efforts through a single and pre-defined strategy for the Group, focusing on the creation of compelling contents, the prioritization of digital and social media for our advertisement campaigns and a deeper comprehension of our customers’ preferences and behaviors through dedicated CRM tools.

Subsubsection Title: Expand our geographic reach with focus on the United States and Greater China
Subsubsection Text: We plan to strategically expand our geographic reach in markets where we expect to see continued growth, particularly outside of Europe. In particular, we aim to concentrate our focus on North America and Greater China, where we believe there is the greatest growth potential. As part of our strategy to expand in the United States, in 2021, we acquired Lumens, our U.S. based online platform which sells both products from our brands as well as third-party products. This acquisition materially boosted both e-commerce sales and sales in the Americas, which grew from €3.9 million and €74.9 million in 2020, respectively, to €103.7 million and €225.3 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, respectively. We believe the U.S. market is still underpenetrated and plan to continue to leverage on Lumens and our network of architects and designers to increase our sales in the region. Key growth initiatives in the United States will include: (i) expanding our architects and designers network through CRM and other digital tools and marketing events across brands; (ii) increasing the number of points of sales with a focus on space branding (mono-brand and shop-in-shop); (iii) selectively opening new stores in key locations with high growth potential, including New York, Miami and Boston; (iv) accelerating our contract channel expansion in the hospitality and retail space; and (v) optimizing the regional supply chain in our lighting business (both production and logistics). Moreover, the expansion in the Greater China region is one of our strategic priorities and, to that end, we have appointed a CEO Greater China at the Design Holding Level who oversees the commercial efforts in the region, including the opening of local stores, the roll-out of mono-brand stores with local partners and a digital-led marketing strategy to generate brand awareness and support distribution of products in the area. In 2022, we incorporated a new subsidiary in Shanghai, Design Holding (Shanghai) Co. Ltd., to facilitate our expansion in the region. We have the opportunity to establish our brands as pioneers in the region, especially in light of the still underdeveloped knowledge of the luxury design market among customers. Key growth initiatives in Greater China will include: (i) the creation of a Greater China Business Unit with its own sales and marketing teams and a dedicated e-commerce website; (ii) increasing wholesale distribution in key urban areas through mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops; (iii) selectively opening new stores (including via the B&B Italia Design Studio format) in key locations with high growth potential, such as Shanghai; and (iv) accelerating marketing activities and digital penetration through dedicated platforms. We also plan to expand our reach in the Middle East, Korea and Japan.

Subsubsection Title: Shift focus towards DTC and “branded” channels, develop our store network and foster growth of our online segment
Subsubsection Text: One of our key strategic goals is to grow our DTC distribution channels, which typically allow us to exercise greater control over pricing of our products and be closer to our end customers, in particular by supporting the migration of end customers in our wholesale channel (e.g., consumers walking into third-party managed multibrand or mono-brand stores or shop-in-shops or customers purchasing our products from online resellers) to either our DOS or in-house e-commerce platforms. Growth initiatives for our DOS channel will include (i) the selected roll out of B&B Italia, Fendi Casa and Flos / Louis Poulsen DOS in key cities with high growth potential; (ii) the enhancement of retail customer experience across our network through sales personnel excellence; and (iii) increased focus on our architects and designers network to drive qualified traffic into our DOS. Growth initiatives for our e-commerce channel will include (i) the launch of new limited editions, collaborations and other exclusive products or e-marketing campaigns; (ii) the enhancement of digital services available to architects and industry 139 ----- professionals, which raise our profile and support our success across the value chain from the creation of the designs, to the development of the products and the final distribution to customers; and (iii) offer premium services to our e-customers in connection with product delivery and installation. In our wholesale channel, our main efforts will focus on the “brandization” of wholesale spaces through the increase in the number of mono-brand stores and shop-in-shops and, wherever possible, the increase of in-store space, as well as the selective expansion in luxury department stores.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance leadership position in high-end contract business
Subsubsection Text: We intend to selectively accelerate the growth of our contract business in attractive sectors with high growth potential, such as the high-end residential, hospitality and office sectors, and expand our contract channel in selected underpenetrated geographies, such as North America and Greater China. Our contract channel played a key role in the recent projects relating to the Bulgari Hotel in Rome and Tokyo and the One Thousand Museum Residences by Zaha Hadid Architects in Miami, as regards our Arclinea and B&B Italia brands, as well as the Bourse du Commerce in Paris, as regards our Flos brand. Key growth initiatives include: (i) improvement of the contract business capillarity by expanding the pipeline in specific regions (United States, China and the Middle East) and segments (residential, hospitality, retail and office for lighting); and (ii) increase synergies with other brands of the Group, increasing average project value and accelerating business generation by adding sister brands to projects and boosting cross-brand penetration on identified top accounts. We also plan to increase “soft” contract retail business opportunities within our DOS network by targeting retail customers and their specifiers in connection with smaller projects than the projects traditionally developed by our contract business. Soft contract projects may entail, for example, the supply of integrated furniture and lighting products to private individuals in connection with the construction or refurbishment of their homes or vacation houses. We believe the required cooperation with our customers in the development of these projects helps us build closer relationships with them.

Subsubsection Title: Significant opportunity from new procurement cost saving initiatives under implementation
Subsubsection Text: One of our key operational priorities, along with maintaining and improving our high quality standards, is to continue the deployment of cost synergies from the creation of Design Holding and the further consolidation of our Group and coordination among our brands. In particular, we have identified a number of procurement optimization opportunities across both direct and indirect procurement categories, which we currently expect will deliver run-rate annual cost savings for an aggregate estimated amount of €17.8 million in the next three to four years, with approximately 43% of these savings estimated to be achieved by 2024 (€1.4 million in 2023 and €6.2 million in 2024) and the remainder in 2025 (€6.6 million) and 2026 (€3.6 million). We expect to incur one-off costs in order to achieve these cost savings of approximately €3 million between 2023 and the first half of 2024 related to the fees charged by the external consultant we have engaged in connection with the implementation of these procurement optimization initiatives. In the case of direct procurement, the identified initiatives relate to the procurement of semi-finished and finished products and raw materials. With respect to semi-finished and finished products, initiatives include the application of best-practice contracting methods and negotiations with suppliers, leveraging price transparency, should-cost analyses and win-win strategies, as well as improved visibility over prices applied by competing suppliers. With respect to raw materials, we intend to increase the competition among our suppliers (including by approaching competing suppliers and reviewing the existing supplier base) to obtain immediate or retroactive price decreases. We currently estimate that our cost savings and efficiency initiatives in the direct procurement category have the potential of delivering €9.4 million of run-rate annual cost savings in the next three to four years. In the case of indirect procurement, the identified initiatives relate to: (i) logistics and facility management, where we intend to call for tenders of regional logistics services with volume bundles over common routes, as well as renegotiate existing contractual arrangements; (ii) marketing and sales, where we intend to consolidate our expenditures by bundling our products into a single unit, apply demand management and leverage marketing benchmarks; (iii) professional services, where we intend to bundle demand, select preferred suppliers, review and renegotiate contracts and disable unused licenses; (iv) information technology and communication, where we intend to reduce costs by bundling hardware and software volumes, using benchmarks to increase supplier competition and renegotiating contracts; (v) packaging, where we intend to reduce costs by calling for tenders, leveraging value engineering and harmonizing specifications; and (vi) other indirect categories (e.g. R&D 140 ----- activities, mobility and travel, maintenance, repair and operations, etc.), where we intend to achieve cost savings by performing structured procurement activities, such as harmonization, bundling, benchmarking, standardization and negotiation. In addition, we launched the optimization of our insurance coverage by way of coordinated policy management and alignment of risk management across our brands. We currently estimate that our cost savings and efficiency initiatives in the indirect procurement category have the potential of delivering €8.4 million of run-rate annual cost savings in the next three to four years.

Subsubsection Title: Pursue strategic acquisition opportunities that align with our overall goals and objectives
Subsubsection Text: Although we are currently focused on delivering organic growth by further developing and consolidating our brands, our global footprint and diverse product portfolio create opportunities for acquisitions of selected and profitable brands in the high-end design market or adjacent markets that may bolster or complement our existing offering and geographical footprint. We are open to considering and we constantly scrutinize additional strategic acquisitions, some of which could be significant in size, to add to our portfolio, capitalize on our competitive strengths, expand our geographic footprint and reach in jurisdictions, including outside of Europe, where we see potential growth opportunities and/or where we currently have limited operations, further diversify our product offering, preserve or improve our financial performance and/or benefit from further consolidation expected in the design industry. Any further potential acquisition opportunities will be evaluated in light of a prudent and rigorous analysis to preserve a solid financial position and high profitability. We will continue to apply a disciplined approach to pricing in connection with these potential acquisitions and will place significant emphasis on carefully planning and executing our acquisition strategy. As part of this strategy and to the extent possible, we will aim to use the investments we have already made in our IT, finance, operational, governance and business processes to reduce costs associated with on-boarding acquired businesses and will aim to utilize these synergies to benefit the entire Group.
The key elements of our strategy are:

We are a leading global design company in the high-end furniture and lighting markets. We design, produce, distribute and sell high-end lighting and furniture solutions. We offer our products through three core companies with leading positions in the global high-end design market: Flos, an Italian lighting brand; Louis Poulsen, a Danish lighting brand; and B&B, an Italian group with several brands in its portfolio (including B&B Italia, Maxalto, Azucena and Arclinea). Our core brands are complemented by three emerging brands with growing relevance in the global high-end lighting, accessories and furniture solutions markets: Lumens, a digital ecommerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture in the United States; Fendi Casa, an Italian furniture, lighting and home accessories brand, based on a joint venture with the luxury brand Fendi; and Audo, a Danish furniture, lighting and accessories brand. Through these six complementary brands, we offer a broad range of product categories and brands across multiple sales channels and geographic areas. The management team that oversees and coordinates the operations of our brands is employed by Design Holding. From a governance perspective, since the formation of Design Holding in 2018 we underwent a major change, by transitioning from a founder-led to a management-led group. We believe that our holding operating model is a key contributor to our success as it enhances value creation through performance management and sharing of ideas, best practices and capabilities across our brands. Moreover, we have further strengthened our governance by coupling the governance teams at each of our brands with a centralized management team at the level of Design Holding (including Group CEO, Group CFO, Group Strategy, M&A and Business Development Director, Group Chief Digital Officer, Group Contract Director, Group Marketing and Sustainability Director, Group Human Resources and Organization Director, CEO Greater China at the Design Holding Level, Group General Counsel and Group E-Commerce Manager) in charge of overseeing the overall operations of the Group and coordinating with each operating company. In order to maximize our potential synergies in the Contract division, we have also set up a Contract committee, which meets monthly, coordinated by the Group Contract Director to discuss channel performance, industry opportunities, sharing projects and coordinate joint activities. From an operational perspective, we launched a centralized CRM platform, thus administering the interactions with customers in a more efficient way, leveraging the data gathered by our group companies. This initiative allows our Contract sales organizations at Flos, B&B Italia, Louis Poulsen and Arclinea to coordinate with each other and in the different geographical areas in which we operate. Moreover, the centralized CRM platform has enhanced the capability of the Group companies to connect with the architect community and end-consumers target segments. Additionally, we have also focused on establishing consistent cross-brand data governance, creating a digital centralized financial reporting tool for this purpose. 141 ----- We also launched several optimization projects to accelerate the work on cost synergies, starting from our procurement processes where, following an analysis with a specialised procurement consultant, we identified certain cost savings that we intend to implement in the coming years. Another example of our ongoing optimization projects is the optimization of our insurance coverage by way of coordinated policy management and alignment of risk management across our brands. For more information on our structure and management, see “Summary—Corporate Structure and Certain _Financing Arrangements” and “Management”._

Since our incorporation in 2018 following the initial acquisition by entities affiliated with Investindustrial and Carlyle of Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B, and with the subsequent add-ons of (i) Lumens, which was acquired in 2021, (ii) the joint venture with Fendi Casa in 2021 (with operations starting in 2022) and (iii) Audo, which was acquired in 2022 (and, at the time of our acquisition, was doing business through the brands Menu, by Lassen and The Audo), our goal has been to create a global high-end design group that brings together a collection of renowned and complementary brands. By bringing together and coordinating these six groups of companies and managing a total of nine brands to date, we have successfully created a one-stop shop for high-quality design furniture and lighting products for both individuals and businesses around the world. Design Holding, the direct parent company of the Issuer, provides the strategic direction necessary for the continued development of our business, while acting as a “center of excellence” across key capabilities. Through our coordinating activities, we set the vision and strategic direction of the Group and establish the necessary guidelines and coordination among our brands, in particular in the areas of finance, control, legal affairs, governance, human resources management, business strategy and digital strategies. We are also responsible for delivering specific guidance in the Wholesale, Contract, Directly Operated Stores (“DOS”) and Direct ECommerce sales channels, aimed at fostering the growth of our brands. We also facilitate the adoption of consistent group policies and operating processes, with a particular focus on ESG matters. One of our key goals is to ensure that our companies have a platform for developing industrial and commercial synergies, attracting talent in the design field, as well as highly qualified personnel in other areas, and improving brand awareness and growth through global omnichannel go-to-market policies. Our global brands have relationships with a broad base of leading designers who rely on our platform to develop high-end furniture and lighting products. These products are usable in a range of different environments and are distributed to consumers worldwide through a flexible and scalable industrial business model based on the following main four pillars. For more information see “—Business Model” below. As an aggregation platform, we also manage the Group’s merger and acquisition activity. Our platform enables our Core Brands to continue their growth and global expansion as well as to improve and consolidate their leadership in various markets. Through our merger and acquisition activity, we primarily seek to acquire new brands in the early stages of development, which may benefit from a fast growth trajectory as a result of their participation in our platform. 142 -----

We have developed a flexible and scalable Group business model based upon four pillars ((i) expertise in research and development and close relationships with international designers, (ii) in-house manufacturing and established manufacturing partnerships, (iii) marketing channels fostering brand recognition in the market and (iv) omnichannel distribution structure) shared across all of our brands. _Expertise in Research and Development and Relationships with International Designers_ We are a preferred partner for world-leading designers seeking a solid platform on which to develop their ideas. Our brands provide designers with advanced research and development facilities that support their work by making available the most up-to-date technologies in the industry, enabling them to bring their designs to life. Owing in part to this commitment to research and development, we are able to attract and collaborate with established international designers with diverse professional experience and across different generations. We have collaborated with approximately 160 world-renowned designers. Some of our brands also collaborate with art directors, who work together with the designers to ensure unity of vision in branding and product catalog management. As of June 30, 2023, we employed approximately 127 employees dedicated to research and product development and, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, allocated a total amount of about 1% of our sales in such period to research and product development. In 2022, we launched more than 90 new product families (including extensions of existing product lines and special editions). In general, we structure our product lines as follows: (i) iconic products constantly present in our offering (such as the Arco lamp by Flos or the UP5_6 armchair by B&B Italia); (ii) products based entirely on new designs or on historical designs not previously commercialized; (iii) modernization and sale of existing products in order to reflect new technical specifications, such as updating certain designs that are part of our heritage for the implementation of new LED technology; (iv) relaunch of products that were already part of our offerings (such as (i) B&B Italia’s Camaleonda sofa, which was first launched on the market in 1970 and subsequently re-released in 2020, positioning itself as one of our best-selling sofas and an iconic hero product in social media in the year following its launch, and (ii) “Le Bambole” Collection, first launched in 1970 and new “Le Bambole” collection re-released in 2022 with circularity in mind and designed to be fully disassembled); and (v) limited edition products (such as the Arco K lamp by Flos, of which only 2,022 pieces were made available for sale). _In-house Manufacturing and Established Manufacturing Partnerships_ With the exception of Lumens (which does not operate a production facility), as of June 30, 2023, we had ten inhouse production facilities, differentiated by brand and product type, each of which focuses on the most critical and delicate processing phases of their respective products to ensure the highest quality of our products. Our inhouse production facilities include seven in Italy (two of which in the same location in Misinto (Milan)), one in Valencia (Spain), one in Vejen (Denmark) and one in New York. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, approximately 56% of our production capacity was carried out through the operation (fabrication or assembly) of suppliers and partners outside of the Group, while the remaining approximately 44% was carried out in house and typically relates to the most critical components of our products. Our production is mainly focused on sales of made-to-order products, which represented approximately 69% of total revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, with the remainder being made-to-stock products. As of December 31, 2022, our facilities were supported by a network of approximately 1,950 carefully selected external suppliers located throughout the world and generally in close proximity to our production facilities. As part of our ongoing effort to secure partnerships with high quality suppliers, we are requiring all of our suppliers 143 ----- to adhere to our supplier code of ethics, which grants us audit rights as well as supply agreement termination rights in the event of any breaches by the supplier. The following chart shows the composition of our suppliers by geographical area as of December 31, 2022: By utilizing a wide network of suppliers, we can combine high flexibility and scalability of production levels with the maintenance of high-quality standards. _Marketing Channels Fostering Brand Recognition in the Market_ Each of our brands also benefits from a strong digital channel and social media presence, which supports brand awareness across all of our distribution channels and facilitates earlier customer acquisition, as compared to more traditional sales channels. Our brands have enhanced their presence on social media in recent years, with large fan bases and followers across all the main platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Pinterest and X (Twitter). Through sophisticated marketing tools across various media and channels, we aim to expand the recognition of our brands on the market, enhancing their value and increasing customer engagement across various touch points. Our integrated marketing approach is implemented through (i) digital communication tools and publications in the main international media, (ii) events such as the Milan Design Week (Salone del Mobile) and other prestigious international events in the design field, (iii) sophisticated branded publications and magazines supporting sales and dealers, (iv) tools enhancing consumers’ experience in stores, (v) social media and key opinion leader engagement and (vi) visibility resulting from specific projects that are commissioned to us, including, among others, B&B Italia Bulgari Hotel and Resorts in Tokyo, Paris and Rome, M+ Museum in Hong Kong, La Bella Vita in Taichung, Taiwan, One Thousand Museum Residences in Miami and The Whiteley in London. We constantly strive to integrate the above-mentioned channels in order to efficiently bring to the final consumer a consistent brand image capable of expressing the values and correct market positioning of our brands. _Omnichannel Distribution Structure_ Our omnichannel approach comprises four key sales channels: 1. _Direct-to-customer. Our direct-to-customer channels allow us to directly reach our end-customers with a flexible, tailor-made and cost-efficient approach adapted to a rapidly evolving market, and comprise: - _Contract. Our contract channel delivers bespoke design services for residential and commercial customers, utilizing both products from our catalogues and custom-made products, as well as certain complementary products from third-party producers. This channel has approximately 12,000 projects in its pipeline and represented 30.2% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; - _Direct E-Commerce. This channel encompasses our e-commerce websites selling in approximately 36 geographies across the world and managed directly by our various companies, as well as our online platform Lumens, which sells both products from our brands as well as 144 ----- third-party products, and represented 12.2% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; and - _Directly Operated Stores. Our DOS channel comprises retail stores that sell only products from our brands, either individually by brand or in a combination with products from our other brands. An example is our new DOS in Boston, Massachusetts, which sells products from our B&B Italia, Maxalto and Arclinea brands. In the past year, we have accelerated our openings of DOS, mono-brand and shop-in-shop spaces, with 61 new openings during the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. The DOS channel includes 19 stores managed directly by our companies and represented 6.7% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. 2. _Wholesale. Our wholesale channel includes over 5,521 brick-and-mortar points of sale throughout the world, in various different formats managed by third parties, with a special focus on (i) mono-brand stores (137), managed by third parties and accounting for 8.1% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; (ii) shop-in-shops (875), accounting for 8.7% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023; and (iii) multibrand stores (4,490), accounting for 23.3% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. The wholesale channel also includes e-tailers (e-commerce websites), omnichannel partners and pure player e-commerce businesses (1,122 and accounting for 10.8% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023). Overall, our wholesale channel represented 50.9% of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 by sales channel: We operate directly or indirectly in more than 130 countries around the world. The following chart sets forth a breakdown of our revenue from contracts with customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 by geography: 145 -----

We coordinate and manage the business operations of nine design brands in the high-end lighting, furniture and accessories segments. Our brands carry out the customer-facing activities through their independent identities and design DNAs. Each of our brands is independently responsible for implementing the relevant brand strategy in accordance with the common strategic framework set by Design Holding and through close collaboration with our center of excellence. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our brands may be subdivided into: - Core Brands that are established on the market and linked to iconic and historical designs, such as Flos, Louis Poulsen and B&B. These groups have been part of our platform, and have benefited from our strategy, for many years; and - emerging brands that are in the initial phases of their development and that we have acquired between 2021 and the 2022, including Lumens, specializing in e-commerce of design products; Fendi Casa, announced following the launch of Fashion Furniture Design S.p.A. (“FF Design”) partnership between us and Fendi S.r.l. (“Fendi”); and Audo, a Danish designer, manufacturer, and distributer of furniture, lighting and accessories.

The business of Flos comprises four divisions: Decorative, Architectural, Outdoor and Custom. _Decorative_ The Decorative division can be traced back to the company’s original business founded in 1962 and offers high-end decorative lighting products, such as the Arco floor lamp by Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, the 146 ----- Superloon floor lamp by Jasper Morrison, the Noctambule lighting products by Konstantin Grcic and the Arrangements collection by Michael Anastassiades, primarily for residential applications. The Decorative division forms the core of Flos’ product offering and is managed by Flos S.p.A. primarily from the company’s headquarters in Brescia. The production of Decorative products is mainly outsourced to a selected number of trusted manufacturers, primarily in Italy, and quality control activities are carried out internally. The Decorative division product offering is broad and consists of more than 2,100 different products (including different configurations of the same product and excluding spare parts). _Architectural_ Flos’ Architectural division was established in 1996 in response to growing demand for high-profile commercial lighting products and is managed by Flos’ subsidiary Antares in Valencia, Spain. The Architectural division provides lighting products primarily for sophisticated, high-end commercial applications including retail stores, hotels, offices and luxury residential properties. Approximately 10% to 20% of Flos’ Architectural products are assembled at the Antares plant in Valencia. The Architectural division product offering is also broad and includes approximately 7,800 products (including different configurations of the same product and excluding spare parts). _Outdoor_ Following the acquisition of Italian outdoor lighting producer Ares in 2015, Flos began incorporating Ares products into its catalogue, resulting in the launch of the first Flos Outdoor collection in 2017. In 2022, Flos fully consolidated the Ares product catalogue into the Flos Outdoor catalogue. Production of Flos Outdoor is managed directly by Ares and takes place entirely in Bernareggio, in northern Italy. The Outdoor collection is designed for open spaces and aims to strike a balance between complementing the existing architecture and blending into the landscape. The Outdoor division comprises approximately 3,800 products (including different configurations of the same product and excluding spare parts). _Custom_ The Custom division delivers custom-made lighting products for commercial and residential applications and is mainly managed by the Flos subsidiary Flos Bespoke S.r.l. (formerly Light Contract S.r.l.) in Collebeato, in northern Italy, and the Custom division of Flos USA Inc., in New York, U.S. Although the Custom division is a relatively small component of Flos’ business, it might be an entry point for new customers who first come into contact with Flos lighting in retail, hospitality or other commercial environments and provides cross-selling opportunities for all other business divisions. The Custom division’s capabilities range from the personalization of standard collections with special finishes and light sources to the custom-tailoring of high-performance products and the customized production of unique solutions for large-scale projects, where each device is designed and developed according to the most challenging architectural needs.

Since it was established in 1962, Flos’ business model has relied on iconic design coupled with technological innovation. The creation of a Flos product is the culmination of an integrated process involving designers, architects and the company’s in-house research and development department, with full-time employees dedicated to such activity. As of June 30, 2023, Flos’ research and development division had 50 full-time employees. Designs begin at the concept stage, in which designers either propose their own ideas for designs or produce concepts for designs based on Flos’ instructions and request. The concept stage is followed by a period of research, in which designs are further developed and modelled, materials are selected, and products undergo initial engineering. During the refining stage, the product is developed as a prototype and undergoes a second round of engineering and analysis against safety standards. The product then moves to the defining stage, in which final engineering takes place, the product is measured against internal and external quality standards and arrangements are made for production logistics and the supply of raw materials. Finally, the product moves to the production stage, which encompasses the procurement of raw materials, production planning and the final manufacturing of the product. During this stage, agreements for production logistics and sourcing of raw materials are made. Flos benefits from of a vast archive of designs by distinguished Italian designers dating back to the 1950s that has never been commercialized, which we believe represents an important growth opportunity for Flos. 147 -----

The majority of Flos’ production operations benefit from a flexible supply chain, with a focus on lean operations. Due to the complexity of the techniques and materials required for the manufacture of Flos’ products, production is mostly outsourced to carefully selected manufacturers, with a majority of production on the basis of make-to-order and make-to-stock principles. Within the Decorative and Architectural divisions, manufacturing is primarily outsourced, and assembly is almost entirely outsourced. Production levels of Decorative products are based on a forecast of sales volumes at stock keeping unit (“SKU”) level which is normally made on a yearly basis, but such forecast is then adjusted on a monthly basis throughout the year based on actual demand with a very short lead time, as Decorative products (as well as certain readily available Architectural products) can generally have short delivery timeframes. In the Architectural, Outdoor and Custom divisions, production is done on order; within the Outdoor division, manufacturing is entirely internal and assembly is almost entirely internal, with production taking place to order. Custom products are tailored to each customer’s satisfaction and are entirely custom-made, with custom projects taking up to several months to be completed, depending on the size and complexity of the project.

Although a majority of production is outsourced, Flos remains directly involved in the manufacturing process, with quality control assessments taking place during every step of production. Prior to being sent to assemblers, raw materials and product components undergo an initial round of quality control, during which Flos (or the third-party assembler, in the case of products assembled outside of Italy) utilizes specialized quality control software to run quality controls on a statistical basis, the frequency of which varies depending on the specific type of material or component. The raw materials and components are then either assembled internally or packaged into assembly kits and sent to third-party assemblers. Flos generally contracts with assemblers that are located in close proximity to its headquarters in Bovezzo and members of its internal quality control organization make regular visits to assemblers to gauge the assemblers’ quality control procedures. During the assembly phase (both internal at Flos and external at the third-party assembler), quality controls are performed on every product and the outcome of each quality control test is collected by Flos through its quality control software. Assembled products are then returned to Flos, where products undergo a further quality control assessment on a statistical basis to ensure that they meet internal and external standards of quality and safety, while adhering to the original design principles, before being stored in Flos’ warehouses and shipped to customers as required. In addition, the first production run of new products is always assembled internally, so that Flos can then share best practices with its external assemblers. Flos contracts with a diverse group of mainly non-exclusive suppliers to provide the raw materials, assembly and finished products it requires. Suppliers are carefully selected mainly according to their technical capacity, quality, finance reliability and cost and are usually located in close proximity to Flos’ facilities to minimize transportation costs and timing. Flos group contracted with approximately 500 suppliers in 2022. The relationships between Flos and its suppliers are governed mainly through (i) purchase orders with general terms and conditions specifying the purchase process, the general terms of delivery of purchased materials, the terms of invoicing and certain general obligations of the suppliers; (ii) standard supply agreements or (iii) framework supply agreements specifying terms, termination rights and minimum quantities. Flos also requires its suppliers to adhere to a set of guidelines provided by the company concerning the quality and any technical requirements of the products. If materials or products are found to be defective, Flos can return them to the supplier to be replaced or repaired at the expense of the supplier. Flos also requires its suppliers to adhere to our code of ethics implemented on November 28, 2022.

Flos monitors the quality of its products throughout the entire production process and carries out quality controls (i) on a sample basis on raw materials and components prior to shipping them for assembly operations; (ii) on all products during the assembly phase, entering the results on dedicated quality control software; and (iii) on a statistical basis on assembled products, to ensure that they satisfy internal and external quality as well as safety standards and standards of conformity to the original design, prior to sale. In addition, the first production cycle of each new product is conducted in-house by Flos to allow the company to share and fine tune the production processes with its suppliers. In addition, Flos employs a dedicated quality control manager to inspect and monitor the quality of the products manufactured by its production partners in China. 148 -----

Flos’ marketing efforts are coordinated and unified across channels, media and distributions around four areas of focus: (i) brand experience, (ii) sales support, (iii) B2B relationships and (iv) customer relationships. Brand experience is a key element underlying all of Flos’ marketing efforts and consists of highlighting the perception of a strong and distinctive brand through the use of storytelling that engages the potential customer, and following an omni-channel marketing strategy. Sales support is a key element of Flos’ omni-channel marketing strategy. Support for the Flos sales force includes both online dealers and various brick-and-mortar dealers (“doors”) through the use of Salesforce, the Group-level CRM platform dedicated to the B2B channel, which is currently used in most of the countries in which we operate. The platform administers the interactions with customers in a more efficient way, leveraging the data gathered by each of our companies and, in turn, enabling our companies to coordinate with each other and in the different geographical areas in which we operate. In addition to the sales support provided to all online dealers and doors, Flos adopted Salesforce as well as launched a professional website for its B2B customers that is easy to navigate and dedicated to the needs of B2B customers and that we continue to improve on the basis of feedback collected from professionals. Customer relationships are key to Flos’ success and brand reputation, and continuing to build and maintain these relationships, particularly through digital channels (including the brand’s website and relevant social media), is a key element of Flos’ marketing strategy.

Flos primarily sells directly to retail customers through its network of flagship stores and through its e-commerce site in the U.S. and Europe. The remainder of Flos’ international distribution is primarily conducted by its network of doors and by wholesalers and distributors which on-sell Flos’ products to their customers. Flos contracts with its international dealers using a standard commercial customer agreement, which provides for the terms of delivery and payment, as well as base discount from the standard purchase price for all products purchased by the dealer under the agreement. Flos provides its retailers with a list of recommended retail prices for its products, although retailers are not contractually bound to apply such prices.

Flos serves a wide range of customers, including design-conscious individuals, architects, interior designers, other design professionals and wholesalers and distributors of design lighting products. Flos also serves high-end fashion brands, retail stores, hotels and other businesses primarily as part of its Architectural division. Flos’ B&M dealers are primarily high-end interior design shops dealing either exclusively in lighting or in a combination of furnishings and lighting.

Flos has developed a dedicated strategy to improve the protection of its intangible assets and enforce the underlying intellectual property, which primarily consists of trademarks, designs, copyrights, utility models and domain names. Flos owns a large portfolio of Italian, European and other international trademarks, including for the name “Flos”. In addition to registered trademarks, Flos also owns several _de facto trademarks covering the names of its products and product lines. Flos also owns more than 898 registered designs (of which 68 are pending), primarily registered in Italy, the European Union, the U.S., Canada, China, Japan, South Korea and India, covering the shapes of certain products. Flos’ portfolio of patents, primarily registered in Italy and the European Union, provides additional protection for the inventions inherent in certain of Flos’ products. Flos also seeks to protect its company know-how through the use of non-disclosure agreements. Flos contracts with a thirdparty service responsible for monitoring and removing any intellectual property used without permission on websites, e-commerce platforms and social media, while also regularly conducting its own trademark surveillance. For more information on risks related to our intellectual property rights and efforts to protect them, see “Risk _Factors—Risks Related to our Business—If we are unable to protect our license and other intellectual property rights from others, if counterfeiting increases or if our competitors or third parties assert intellectual property rights against us, our business may suffer, and we may incur significant additional costs”._ Additional intellectual property rights are governed by Flos’ license agreements with individual designers. See “—Agreements with Designers” below. 149 -----

As of June 30, 2023, Flos was party to 205 license, transfer and/or assignment agreements with Italian and foreign designers in connection with the design of lighting products, all providing for the payment of consideration to the designers for the use or transfer of their intellectual property rights. These agreements can be divided into two broad categories: (i) intellectual property transfer agreements providing for the complete assignment of intellectual property rights from the designer to Flos, which represents the majority of agreements between Flos and designers, and (ii) license agreements with Flos as licensee, which comprise a limited amount of agreements relative to intellectual property transfer agreements. Most of the transfer agreements grant to Flos all of the rights arising from any potential future versions of products that could be developed by the relevant designer without need to enter into further agreements and expressly grant Flos registration rights with respect to the designs. Flos has entered into five license agreements. These agreements typically do not include exclusivity clauses, although _de facto exclusive relationships have been created following several years of collaboration. Flos’ design_ agreements are typically open ended in duration. Pursuant to most of its license agreements, Flos is required to make quarterly payments to the relevant designers in amounts that are calculated on the basis of net sales, whether in Italy or abroad, net of any discounts, return of unsold goods, shipping charges, as well as any other expenses arising out of and in relation to such sales. For the year ended December 31, 2022, Flos recorded a total of €4.4 million in royalties to designers.

Flos is one of the world’s leading brands in high-end lighting products for residential and commercial use. Flos was founded in Merano, in northern Italy, in 1962 by Arturo Eisenkeil and Dino Gavina, in partnership with the Cassina family. In 1962, Flos introduced the Arco lamp, which became one of its most iconic and best-selling lamp designs. Flos transferred its headquarters to Brescia, in northern Italy, in 1964, opened its first store in Milan in 1968 and embarked upon its international expansion in 1971, with the opening of its first foreign branch in Germany. In 1974, Flos acquired the heritage Italian lighting brand Arteluce, significantly expanding its product range and international reach. Flos began its exclusive collaboration with Philippe Starck in the 1980s, and throughout the 1990s, Flos unified its divisions into a unique brand catalogue and continued its global expansion into North America and Asia. The contract business was first introduced in 1996, in response to growing demand from commercial customers. In the early 2000s, following its participation in the first International Light & Building fair, Flos launched its architectural business, Flos Architectural, which represented its first venture into lighting for commercial spaces, which later expanded to cover residential spaces. The Architectural business was significantly bolstered with the acquisition in 2005 of a majority stake in Antares, a Spanish commercial lighting producer based in Valencia, Spain. In 2016, 2020 and 2022, Flos received its fourth, fifth and sixth Compasso d’Oro awards for the lamps “OK” by Konstantin Grcic, “Arrangements” by Michael Anastassiades, and “Belt” by Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, respectively. In addition, in 2020, Flos received also the first Compasso d’Oro Product Lifetime Achievement Award for the “Arco” lamp. Entities affiliated with Investindustrial acquired a majority stake in Flos in 2014. In 2016, Flos acquired the New York City-based custom lighting producer Lukas Lighting, further strengthening the company’s presence in the custom sector, and Italian outdoor lighting company Ares, which allowed Flos to expand into outdoor lighting. In 2017, Flos began a rebranding of a portion of the Ares catalogue, introducing its first “Flos Outdoor” collection, and acquired Flos Projets (formerly KKDC S.à r.l.), a French distributor of LED lighting products, supporting its distribution capacity in the area. In 2018, entities affiliated with Investindustrial and The Carlyle Group acquired Flos (along with Louis Poulsen and B&B) with the goal of creating a global high-end design group that brings together a collection of renowned and complementary brands. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and for the year ended December 31, 2022, Flos generated revenues from contracts with customers of €258.8 million (30.4% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers) and €267.1 million (31.6% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers).

Louis Poulsen’s operations are divided into three business divisions: (i) wholesale; (ii) contracts; and (iii) Directto-Customer (“D2C”). Although Louis Poulsen primarily depends on its own directly-employed sales consultants, in certain markets third-party agents or distributors are considered more customary or efficient, based on the features and the commercial practices of each market. For example, in the U.S., while Louis Poulsen uses its own directly-employed sales consultants for sales of decorative and architectural lighting in the contract channel, it relies on a distributor to sell post lighting in certain contract channels. In addition, in the wholesale sector, Louis Poulsen has increased its presence through online resellers, such as Lumens, Royal Design, Design Within Reach, Iabelfarm GmbH, Connox GmbH and nest.co.uk. In addition, Louis Poulsen has enhanced its e-commerce in Denmark and expanded its online services also to Sweden, Norway and Germany. Most importantly, LP has introduced a directly operated wholesale e-commerce platform, which is available throughout Europe and in the United States.

Louis Poulsen’s distinct design philosophy originates from Poul Henningsen’s ambition to give electrical light similar ambient properties as the candlelight it replaced in the early 20[th ]century. With that goal in mind, Louis Poulsen has always sought not to design lamps, but to shape light. The company’s philosophy, “Design to Shape 150 ----- Light”, represents the duality between design and light, where every detail of the product has its own purpose. On the basis of the design principles dictated by Poul Henningsen, light must always be indirect, diffused and easy on the eyes and every single detail of the product design must have its own purpose. Louis Poulsen designs have been awarded numerous prestigious design awards, including the 2018 IF Gold Award for the Yuh lamp by GamFratesi, the Danish Design Award, Dansk Industri og Danish Design Center award, the Lighting Design Award, Revo Media award and the Design Award, Bo Bedre for the Flindt wall and several other Danish Bo Bedre Design Awards for Lamp of the Year, for the Patera lamp by Øivind Slaatto, and the Wallpaper* Design Awards 2022 for the Moonsetter lamp by Anne Boysen, among others, and are collected by design museums around the world, including the Danish Design Museum. Louis Poulsen’s design philosophy is strongly rooted in Danish design heritage. Since its first collaboration with Poul Henningsen in 1924, Louis Poulsen has expanded its influence through partnerships with the most celebrated designers in Danish design history, eventually acquiring intellectual property rights to some of the most famous lighting designs of the “big 5” Danish industrial designers: Poul Henningsen, Vilhelm Lauritzen, Arne Jacobsen, Finn Juhl and Verner Panton, which remain at the core of Louis Poulsen’s offering. See “—Agreements with _Designers” for information on Louis Poulsen’s contractual arrangements with its designers. Whether recently_ developed or part of the core collection, all of the Louis Poulsen designs incorporate the company’s philosophy of “Design to Shape Light” and the simple, timeless expression that is core to Danish design. Louis Poulsen has an archive of more than 1,000 patterns and designs from designers, including Poul Henningsen, Arne Jacobsen and Finn Juhl, which have never been commercialized, which we believe represents an important growth opportunity for Louis Poulsen.

Louis Poulsen utilizes a highly scalable operating model, based on an institutionalized, commercially-driven design process, a well-invested production setup with an increasing share of outsourcing and a majority of sales activities conducted through its own global salesforce. _Production cycle_ Louis Poulsen’s production follows a cycle revolving around two main product launch phases, Spring (February to April) and Fall (September and October), during which new products are formally marketed and sold to end-customers. Each market launch phase is preceded by a corresponding internal preparation phase (November to January and May to June), during which the salesforce deploys marketing content to wholesalers and sells them new products internally, the supply chain is engaged based on demand estimates and the production lines are prepared accordingly and extended, to the extent required. On the sales side, prior to launch, new products are previewed with new and existing customers, who provide feedback to the marketing team to further refine demand estimates, and sales teams are brought in-house to refresh their general sales training and receive specialized training on new products. In the Contracts channel, production of custom products is initiated in collaboration with the architects and designers acting as specifiers on the relevant project. In the wholesale channel, immediately prior to launch, the sales teams communicate details of the new products to external customers and use social media and other marketing channels to generate interest around the products. During the official launch phase, the marketing team prepares content for the launch, while the new products are distributed to customers and subsidiaries and customer service and technical specifications are prepared. Louis Poulsen’s production is mainly conducted in-house at the company’s production facility located in Vejen, Denmark, where it employs approximately 136 full-time and part-time employees, and which includes mechanical workshops, painting areas and assembly areas. In the assembly area, the products are also tested and packaged to be transported to Louis Poulsen’s warehouses, which have implemented a third-party logistics setup, and stored with components and products originating from third-party suppliers. _Supply Chain Management_ Louis Poulsen primarily sources raw materials and components that it does not have the capacity or volume to produce internally, such as cast aluminum, polycarbonate items, mouth-blown glass and electrical drivers. A small number of Louis Poulsen suppliers are considered key to its operations due to their expertise and ability in manufacturing sophisticated high-end materials, such as mouth blown glass. Whilst maintaining low input prices is important to Louis Poulsen, a few of the raw materials used, such as steel, copper and plastic, may be subject to global price volatility. Louis Poulsen does not normally hedge against this risk and believes it continues to be in the position to mitigate this risk as it has historically been able to pass any 151 ----- such price increases onto customers or has used different third-party suppliers. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related _to our Business—If prices of the raw materials we employ in our manufacturing processes or of the components or finished products we purchase were to increase, our business could be adversely affected to the extent we are not able to pass any such price increases on to our customers”. Quality Controls_ Louis Poulsen maintains a high standard of quality control throughout the manufacturing process, with a dedicated internal quality department that inspects raw materials, components and products at all stages of manufacturing and assembly to ensure compliance with the expected quality standards. In addition, Louis Poulsen employs a dedicated quality control manager to inspect and monitor the quality of products produced by its production partners in China. In order to ensure the compliance to the high product quality standards, Louis Poulsen also conducts a thorough quality assessment at third-party retail locations involved in distribution. This assessment evaluates the brand’s position, product assortment, and the level of service provided. _Distribution_ Louis Poulsen manufactures its products primarily internally, at the company’s plant in Vejen, Denmark. European sales are managed principally from the warehouse located in Vejen, which also supports the exports to Africa, the Middle East and South America. In addition to the main warehouse in Vejen, Louis Poulsen operates three additional distribution centers in the United States, Japan and Singapore to support global sales. The regional distribution centers ship products directly to retailers and architectural projects, ensuring high responsiveness and short delivery lead times. The warehouse in the United States supports North and Central America and Canada, the warehouse in Japan supports the surrounding region and the Singapore warehouse supports the rest of the APAC region, including Korea. In addition, Louis Poulsen launched a new “shop-in-shop” concept in 2016, through which it provides resellers with an easy-to-build branded structure with specific sizes and features, so as to increase visibility of the Louis Poulsen brand in stores. Louis Poulsen is working on a new customer virtual experience, which will be implemented in its shop-in-shops and rolled out over the coming years. Louis Poulsen has implemented a “dual pricing” system as a new way of balancing and differentiating its discounts to wholesalers. This differentiates the discount given to pure e-retail wholesalers compared to wholesalers with physical stores where customers can experience the products. Further, we have implemented a Tier 1 dealership, where certain products are exclusively available to a limited range of existing dealers under additional requirements to support the high-end exclusivity of the brand.

Louis Poulsen benefits from a central marketing division comprised of 17 full-time employees specialized in central marketing activities (including brand, public relations and communications), of which three employees in the local divisions in Germany, United States and Singapore as of June 30, 2023. Louis Poulsen’s marketing activities include mainly the management of the brand and related storytelling to ensure an effective communication of the brand’s history and philosophy, with a particular focus on the company’s Danish identity and design. The business development and sales organization use digital tools to coordinate the efforts related to internal preparations and external product launches, as well as to simplify the business relationships between the company’s sales division, end customers and Louis Poulsen. Louis Poulsen has significantly expanded its digital marketing activities, strengthening its presence on the main social networks. Traditional print media also play an important role in Louis Poulsen’s marketing strategy, with advertising campaigns included in specialized design magazines such as Elle Décor and Wallpaper as well as through Louis Poulsen’s own magazine, Reflections. In addition, Louis Poulsen displays its products in seven directly managed showrooms located in New York, Oslo, Copenhagen, Vejen (Denmark), Dusseldorf and Singapore, which also host events aimed at announcing the launch of new products.

Louis Poulsen serves a diverse range of customers across its wholesale and contract sales channels. Louis Poulsen’s most important customer categories in the wholesale market are high-end interior design stores (such as Design Within Reach and Paustian), department stores (such as Illums Bolighus and Hyunday, Korea), lighting 152 ----- specialist stores (such as Lysmesteren and Christiania Belysning) and pure online retailers (such as Lumens, Royal Design and nest.co.uk) where Louis Poulsen is able to leverage its strong brand and extensive product portfolio. Louis Poulsen’s Contracts business comprises sales through specifiers in professional projects, such as architects, lighting designers, interior designers and building engineers, of both indoor and outdoor lighting products. Over the past five years, Louis Poulsen’s Contracts division has partnered with leading architects such as BIG (Bjarke Ingels Group), Henning Larsen Architects, KHR Architecture, PLH Arkitekter and Kilo Design in a variety of professional projects across the education and government, business, retail, hospitality, healthcare, residential and other commercial sectors, while the vast majority of Contracts Outdoor end-customers are public entities.

Louis Poulsen has developed a dedicated strategy to improve the protection of its intangible assets and enforce the underlying intellectual property, which primarily consists of trademarks, designs, copyrights, and domain names. Louis Poulsen owns 36 registered designs, primarily registered in the European Union, the U.S., Japan, China, South Korea, Australia, UK and Norway, covering various lighting fixtures, as well as a large portfolio of Danish, European and other international trademarks, including for the name “Louis Poulsen”. Louis Poulsen has a zero tolerance policy for intellectual property infringement and regularly enforces and prosecutes unauthorized use of its designs, trademarks and other intellectual property, and each Louis Poulsen subsidiary is assisting with monitoring its local market and reporting any instances of infringement. However, certain of its products and designs may still be copied, and Louis Poulsen may not be able to prevent the production or sale of all such copies. For risks related to intellectual property rights and efforts to protect them, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to _our Business—If we are unable to protect our license and other intellectual property rights from others, if counterfeiting increases or if our competitors or third parties assert intellectual property rights against us, our business may suffer, and we may incur significant additional costs”._ Additional intellectual property rights are governed by Louis Poulsen’s license agreements with individual designers. See “—Agreements with Designers”.

Louis Poulsen is party to license agreements with designers (or their legal representatives, in case of deceased designers) granting it the exclusive commercial rights to develop, manufacture, market and sell lighting designs by the “big 5” Danish designers Poul Henningsen, Arne Jacobsen, Verner Panton, Vilhelm Lauritzen and Finn Juhl. Louis Poulsen’s license agreements generally grant Louis Poulsen the exclusive, non-revocable worldwide right to commercially exploit certain specified lighting designs in exchange for royalties paid to the designer or the designer’s legal representatives, generally providing for payment on a quarterly or annual basis per unit sold. These royalties are alternatively based on a percentage of the proceeds from net sales of the product designed or on a fixed fee per designed product. In general, licenses are granted for the duration of the validity of the copyright of the design, which extends for 70 years after the death of the designer. The first of such licenses to expire will do so in 2037. After the relevant expiry date, Louis Poulsen will still be able to produce and sell the designs of such designers, but without exclusivity. In addition, Louis Poulsen relies to a more limited extent on license agreements with other designers to complement its heritage collection that have different terms. Although these license agreements do not have set termination dates, most grant the designers the right to terminate the agreement should certain minimum sales rates fail to be met over a specified period, or should Louis Poulsen significantly reduce or cease production of certain products. Furthermore, license agreements can generally be terminated by the designers or their legal representatives in the case of material breach, for instance if royalties are not paid when due and following notice from the licensor. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Our business _is in part dependent on our ability to negotiate, maintain and renew license agreements with leading designers on satisfactory terms”. For the year ended December 31, 2022, Louis Poulsen recorded a total of €3.8 million in_ royalties to designers.

Louis Poulsen is a leading global high-end lighting brand with an iconic portfolio focused on Nordic-inspired design. Originally founded in 1874 as an electrical wholesale business, Louis Poulsen began its transition to a design-driven lighting producer in 1924, when the company began its collaboration with iconic Danish designer Poul Henningsen, with the resulting collection of “PH” lamps distributed through agents in Europe and North America. Throughout the 1950s, 60s and 70s, Arne Jacobsen, Vilhelm Lauritzen and Verner Panton designs were added to the product portfolio, cementing Louis Poulsen’s reputation as a leader in the field of Danish industrial design. Subsequently, Louis Poulsen underwent various changes in ownership structure and reorganizations of the company’s management and business, until 2014, when the management renewed its focus on product innovation, such as LED products or LED-compatible products, and invested significantly in production and design, increasing the launches of new products from four or five new products per year between 2011 and 2015 to an average of approximately 14 new products or extensions in existing product lines per year over the period between 2018 and 2022. Louis Poulsen now operates a robust global distribution network and also has dedicated directly managed showrooms, located in New York, Oslo, Copenhagen, Vejen (Denmark), Dusseldorf and Singapore, which showcase Louis Poulsen designs as well as host marketing events, for example in connection with the launch of new products. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and for the year ended December 31, 2022, LP generated revenues from contracts with customers of €127.3 million (15.0% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers) and €149.3 million (17.7% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers), respectively.

Certain economic and industry data and market forecasts set forth below were extracted from market research, governmental and other publicly available information, independent industry publications and reports prepared by industry consultants, including the Industry Report. Industry reports, publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. We believe that these industry reports, publications, surveys and forecasts, to the extent quoted or referred to herein, are reliable, but we have not independently verified them and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. While we accept responsibility for accurately summarizing the information from these external sources, and as far as we are aware and able to ascertain no facts have been omitted which would render this information inaccurate or misleading, we accept no further responsibility in respect of such information. Certain information in this section has also been based on our own experience, internal studies, estimates and investigations of market conditions, in some cases combined with the aforementioned external sources. We cannot assure you that any of the assumptions we have made are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the market. The information and estimates in this section involve risks and uncertainty and are subject to change based on various factors. See “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements”. Prospective investors should not place undue reliance on any forecasts presented below and should make their own independent assessment of our future prospects and the risks relating to the markets in which we operate. See also “Presentation of Industry and Market Data”._

Our product offering is further supported by our Emerging Brands, which have growing relevance in the global high-end lighting, accessories and furniture solutions markets: Lumens, a U.S. digital e-commerce platform of lighting, accessories and furniture, Fendi Casa, an Italian furniture, lighting and home accessories brand, operating as a joint venture with the luxury brand Fendi, and Audo, a Danish furniture, lighting and accessories brand. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and for the year ended December 31, 2022, our Emerging Brands generated revenues from contracts with customers of €167.0 million (19.6% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers) and €143.6 million (17.0% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers), respectively.

Lumens does not manufacture any products. The merchandising team is responsible for maintaining the accuracy of the assortment and identifying new products, which are primarily sourced from European companies or brands in the United States. The merchandising team is also responsible for vendors’ compliance with the operational guidelines that Lumens has established to optimize the customer experience. Contracts with vendors usually regulate the main terms of the relationship, including tax matters, discounts, fees, rebates, rules on advertising and allocation of liability for damaged or defective products.

Customers may make orders through both Lumens’ website and by email or telephone through the group’s sales network. While consumers’ orders are usually placed through the website, professional customers generally prefer to order through the Lumens’ sales team and a specific account manager. Lumens has a large customer base of approximately 300,000 active customers over the past 24 months, of whom approximately 43% were repeat customers. Lumens has three types of customers: consumers, trade partners and contract customers. - _Consumer. This customer category includes individual homeowners and tenants. Consumers generally order through Lumens’ website or, alternatively, through the sales team. - _Trade partners (Architects and Designers). Trade partners consist of,_ _inter alios, interior designers, architects, contractors and business owners. These customers liaise with Lumens to satisfy their and their clients’ needs for lighting and furniture solutions. Lumens’ dedicated account managers support trade partners through the entire ordering process and provide them with customized advice. Many trade partners rely on Lumens services and products on a regular basis. 159 ----- - _Contract Customers. Contract sales consist of sales to electrical suppliers, purchasing agents and wholesale distributors, purchasing products for commercial projects including hotels, restaurants, and office spaces.

Once orders are received, depending on the availability of such products at Lumens’ warehouse, the company either instructs the relevant vendor to drop ship products directly to the customer or ships on-hand products directly. Approximately 31% of orders are shipped in-house with respect to products available at the warehouse, while other shipments are handled through third parties.

Lumens operates as an online multi-brand seller across its website and via sales teams, with no showroom or physical footprint. Customers can locate products on the company’s website by either navigating or using the onsite search function. Products are organized by category and brand, and products are also recommended in various locations, based on the customer’s search and browse behavior. The website includes detailed descriptions of the main features of each product and a comparison tool allows customers to compare different products. Customer support is offered through dedicated, live customer service and self-service tools. Lumens marketing activities are primarily digitally oriented and range from paid and natural (unpaid) search, shopping, affiliate, retargeting, email, social and display advertising as well as direct mail (catalogs), print advertising and public relation efforts. In addition, Lumens has a presence on the main social networks, including Pinterest, Instagram and Facebook and is increasing its presence on mobile, with a fully responsive site, where customers can explore the catalogue of Lumens’ products seamlessly and make purchases.

_Agreements with Customers_ Lumens does not typically enter into written agreements with consumers or trade partners. Sales to contract customers are conducted on a purchase-order basis and no master or general agreements are entered into in respect thereto. _Agreements with Suppliers_ Lumens generally has in place framework agreements with its suppliers which generally govern (a) distribution terms (such as geographical scope), (b) pricing terms and structure (including any discount policy), (c) rebates and terms of collaborative advertisement programs (if any), the costs of which are generally calculated based on the company’s purchases from the applicable supplier during the term of the agreement, and (d) Lumens operational terms to provide the best customer experience. While contracts are usually for an indefinite term, they can be terminated for convenience by either party upon prior written notice. Lumens is party to exclusive distributor agreements with certain of its vendors, pursuant to which the company is the exclusive e-commerce distributor of the products of the relevant vendor in the United States and possibly in Canada.

Founded in 2001 as YDesign Group, Lumens specializes in the online offering of modern and contemporary lighting, fans, furniture and accessories to design-driven consumers and trade professionals through the website Lumens.com. YDesign Group originally focused on the sale of lighting products, as the group’s flagship brand YLighting was launched in 2001. The company subsequently launched additional brands and categories and created the YDesign group branding for the corporate entity in 2013. To this end, in 2016, YDesign acquired Lumens, a leading multichannel retail brand in lighting, modern furniture and furnishings, thereby further expanding YDesign Group’s importance within the design lighting sector in the North American market. In 2021, Design Holding acquired YDesign Group and on January 1, 2023, Lumens LLC merged into YDesign Group, which, in turn, merged into IDG Apollo Parent Inc. and, at the same time, was renamed Lumens, Inc. Lumens commercializes its product line principally through the website Lumens.com, which offers a complete portfolio of more than 400 brands, including our other brands’ products and competitors’ products (for example, Artemide, Foscarini, Kartell, etc.). Lumens focuses on modern products at different price levels, thus targeting a wide range of consumers. This platform provides us with access to a sizeable customer base in the United States and Canada. Lumens also relies on a sales and assistance team comprised of personnel certified by the American Lighting Association which service over one million residential, professional and commercial customers.

Our agreement with Fendi is based on a joint venture agreement, which was initially signed between Design Holding and Fendi on January 29, 2021 (and subsequently amended on March 3, 2021). The agreement governs the establishment of FF Design, in which the Issuer holds an 80% stake through the subsidiary DQM, while Fendi holds the remaining 20%.
