Pursuant to the agreement, Fendi licenses its registered trademarks, including “Fendi Casa,” along with other intellectual property rights, for the purpose of producing and distributing furnishing products. Pursuant to the agreements between the parties, DQM is required to produce the products to be brought to the market by Fendi Casa and to provide logistics services. The corporate governance of FF Design is governed by a shareholders’ agreement entered into on March 3, 2021, which, among others, provides for voting at board meetings and shareholders’ meetings to take place pro rata to the shareholders’ respective shareholdings in FF Design, and sets forth provisions with respect to veto rights applicable to deadlocks.

The creation of Fendi Casa products is the result of an integrated process that starts with product development involving external designers and architects, coordinated by the manager of the Fendi Casa collection and supported by the in-house research and development department. This process is supervised by the creative director of Fendi Casa, Silvia Venturini Fendi. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, FF Design collaborates with internationally renowned designers, including Studio Marcel Wanders, Atelier OI, Piero Lissoni, Dimorestudio, Chiara Andreatti, Cristina Celestino, Peter Mabeo, Formafantasma, Toan Nguyen, Thierry Lemaire, Controvento, Stefano Gallizioli, Studio Luca Barengo, and Palomba e Serafini. FF Design has an in-house product research and development team, led by the merchandise manager, which is closely aligned with the designers’ activities. This department ensures coordination with the designers throughout the entire design process, providing professional support related to materials and production technologies. They oversee the activities from the initial design to the final sample assessment, consistently communicating with the creative director of Maison Fendi.

A dedicated industrial platform within the Misinto (Monza Brianza) production facility, managed by DQM, supports the product development and the production of Fendi Casa products. Within the Misinto facility, DQM develops, manufactures, and controls the quality of nearly all of the upholstered products in the collection (including sofas and armchairs) implementing state-of-the-art technologies for leather and fabric cutting as well as advanced industrial processes. The products are developed on an industrial scale, while preserving their artisanal quality, and are completed by craftsmen and specialized production staff. Special attention is paid to raw materials and components, which are sourced from a network of approximately 50 suppliers primarily located in the Brianza district. For other product categories, primarily wooden and marble furniture, production is carried out through a small network of suppliers selected from among the best in the area of Brianza and the Italian region of Marche. Highend carpets are manufactured in Nepal and India, while some accessories, such as boxes and vases, are manufactured directly by Fendi. Production is entirely made-to-order, with the exception of the accessories, with delivery times ranging from 8 to 14 weeks. Throughout the production process, each product is subject to rigorous quality assessments conducted by dedicated in-house personnel. These assessments include a final authorization for the release and shipment of the product.

FF Design’s approach to distribution is focused on establishing the most direct and effective relationship with the end customer to preserve and convey the unaltered identity of the Fendi brand. Distribution is divided into three main channels: 161 ----- - _DOS. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the retail distribution includes one DOS in Europe, located in Milan, one DOS in London, as well as a DOS in Miami and another in Shanghai that opened in July 2023. - _Wholesale. FF Design’s wholesale channel includes mono-brand stores, shop-in-shops and multi-brand stores. FF Design enters into agreements with its resellers based on standard agreements, which govern, among other things, the requirements that retailers must meet to be admitted to and remain in FF Design’s distribution network, thus being recognized as authorized reseller of Fendi Casa products. Additionally, FF Design provides to its authorized resellers a list of suggested and non-binding retail prices for its products. The Wholesale channel is directly served by Fendi Casa’s headquarters and does not employ sales agents. The Americas and APAC regions are managed directly by Fendi Casa’s in-house sales employees operating in these regions. - _Contract. This distribution channel is aimed at offering project management and custom design services to residential and commercial customers. The contract channel’s development projects are divided into (i) branded projects that entail the use of the Fendi brand, such as the development of the Fendi Private Residences, and (ii) projects furnished by Fendi Casa, which entail supplying Fendi Casa products and interior design services by the FF Design group without the direct application of the Fendi brand to fixed decorative elements.

FF Design develops its marketing and communication activity in coordination with the marketing and communication department of the Maison Fendi and Design Holding with the aim of supporting its business, improving Fendi Casa’s image and promoting new home collections. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Fendi Casa maintains a website, covering China and the rest of the world, which is available in Italian, English and Chinese. The website caters to both end consumers and industry professionals, allowing them to explore the entire product range by collection and setting, as well as by product type. The website also provides in-depth content on possible sources of inspiration; profiles of international designers collaborating with the brand; purchasing preference filters, including by location through a store locator; and promotion of interior design services. Marketing and communication activities also include planning advertising campaigns and creating promotional materials, such as advertising images set in exclusive locations, often associated with art and architecture (such as the iconic house of the Catalan artist, Xavier Corberò), in line with the brand’s image. Furthermore, the brand participates in various industry events, such as Design Miami, Art Basel and the Milan Design Week (Salone del Mobile). The brand also manages international press activities and publication in some of the most exclusive and representative design and lifestyle magazines. FF Design also collaborates with influencers to create content and increase awareness and reputation related to Fendi Casa products.

Fendi Casa serves a range of customers, including design-conscious individuals, architects, interior designers and other design professionals in the retail channel and businesses in the residential, hospitality, yachts, retail and office sectors in the contract channel.

We have entered into a license agreement with Fendi for the production, design and distribution of furniture, lighting and kitchens. The term of this agreement is effective from January 1, 2022 and will terminate on the date falling 13 years from the date of effectiveness. Under this license agreement, we will pay royalties on the net sales of the related collection and various other guaranteed or minimum amounts. This agreement can be terminated early by either party for several reasons, including, by way of example, non-payment of royalties, failure to reach minimum sales thresholds, breach of any obligations relating to Fendi intellectual property rights, manufacturing, marketing and distribution of the products in violation of the provisions of the license agreement. For information on risks related to intellectual property rights and the efforts to protect them, please see “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to Our Business—If we are unable to protect our license and other intellectual property rights from others, if counterfeiting increases or if our competitors or third parties assert intellectual property rights against us, our business may suffer, and we may incur significant additional costs”._ 162 -----

FF Design has entered into consultancy agreements, together with Fendi, with various Italian and foreign designers to market products specifically designed and created by these designers. In general, these agreements provide that Fendi is the owner of all intellectual and industrial property rights generated in connection with the performance of the agreement. The agreements also grant FF Design an exclusive license to use the aforementioned rights in accordance with the specific terms of the licensing agreement between FF Design and Fendi. The intellectual property covered by these contracts is typically listed in terms of products or images rather than a list of registered, applied, or de facto used intellectual property rights. The agreements generally set forth the intellectual property rights covered by such agreements in the form of a list of products or images, rather than a list of intellectual property rights that are registered, applied for or used on a de facto basis. The agreements generally provide for a long term or indefinite term, with termination clauses mainly in favor of FF Design. Once the licensing agreement has terminated, the intellectual property rights over the products created during the contractual relationship are retained by Fendi, while the designer usually retains the right to receive the relevant royalties. In terms of designer compensation, the agreements provide for (i) an initial payment, deemed a “development fee” and (ii) the payment of specific royalties, usually on a quarterly basis, calculated based on net sales of the designed product, in Italy and abroad, net of possible discounts, returned goods, shipping expenses and other fees. The agreements also provide for the payment of royalties by FF Design to Fendi.

Fendi Casa was established with the founding on May 4, 2021 of FF Design, a company indirectly controlled by one of our wholly-owned subsidiaries and Fendi, the Italian luxury brand that is part of the LVMH Group. This strategic collaboration aims to develop the brand Fendi Casa, the home segment of Fendi, by designing, producing, and distributing collections that reflect the brand’s style as well as the expertise of Design Holding. The creative direction is assigned to Silvia Venturini Fendi, who previously served as the artistic director for accessories and the men’s line at Fendi and now aims to strengthen the aesthetic of the Fendi Casa line. The new Fendi Casa furniture collection was first presented in October 2021 during a preview in Rome, and the first Fendi Casa flagship store opened in Milan in April 2022. FF Design operates through an organizational structure dedicated to the management and development of the business across-the-board, including the integrated development of digital activities. FF Design develops new Fendi Casa collections to offer a comprehensive range of contemporary designer home furnishings that cater to all major segments, namely, (i) living and bedroom, (ii) kitchen, (iii) accessories, (iv) lighting and (v) outdoor. Fendi Casa operates through selective distribution channels in key markets and by establishing a network of new flagship stores, designed to offer interior design services and enhance customer engagement. 160 -----

Audo draws upon both a historical design archive and collaborations with new designers. Designs are then developed and modeled, with a meticulous selection of materials. These models are subsequently produced and tested in order to create a prototype which is then subject to thorough assessments and functionality tests. Once the product is finalized, the final assessment of product quality standards is carried out. 163 -----

The production of Audo’s products is entirely outsourced. Suppliers of furniture products are mainly located in the Baltic countries while those in the lighting and accessories sector are mainly located in China. Sourcing for the “heritage” segment is outsourced, with a main upholstery supplier based in Eastern Europe and other suppliers generally from Nordic countries. In 2020, Audo (then doing business as Designers Company) optimized its entire operating platform to increase product quality, delivery accuracy, and seamless customer service, while also implementing significant digitalization improvements, such as updating the website layout, creating a new digital sales tool and opening its own operational online shop in Europe.

The distribution of Audo is divided into three main channels: - _Wholesale. The wholesale distribution channel consists of multi-brand stores worldwide and omnichannel players comprising retailers, global distributors, online through its website and, in North America, its subsidiary Audo North America. Additionally, Audo relies on external distributors, which operate nonexclusively for Audo and are located in Australia, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Japan. Audo holds monthly sales meetings with distributors, providing guidance but not dictating the terms of product sales. - _Online Distribution. The online distribution channel involves distribution through e-commerce websites and online retailers operated by third parties. - _B2C and Contract. The B2C and contract distribution channel focuses on supplying customized or catalog products for projects such as restaurants, hotels, apartments and offices.

Audo promotes its activities through various means, including the execution of complex projects such as hotels, lobbies, offices, and restaurants, where potential clients can experience Audo’s products first-hand. Additionally, Audo uses social media platforms like Instagram, Facebook, Pinterest, and LinkedIn, for its marketing efforts to reach a wider customer base and generate an increase in sales. Audo’s product portfolio is also featured in international press and industry-specific magazines. In addition, the Audo showroom garners attention from architects, interior designers, decision makers and influencers, as evidenced by the numerous photoshoots held on the premises.

Audo is party to license agreements with designers to market the products they designed and created. In general, these agreements provide that Audo is the licensee of all intellectual and industrial property rights generated in connection with the performance of the agreement. The agreements also grant Audo rights to use the aforementioned rights in accordance with the specific terms of the licensing agreement between Audo and the relevant designer. Most of the license agreements are made on an exclusive basis. The license agreements generally provide for royalties paid to the designer or the designer’s legal representatives on a quarterly or annual basis per unit sold. These royalties are alternatively based on a percentage of the proceeds from net sales of the product designed or on a fixed fee per designed product. While most of the license agreements do not include termination provisions, some license agreements may be terminated at any point in time with notice, while others have no term limits. Most license agreements also grant designers the right to terminate the agreement should certain minimum sales rates fail to be met over a specified period or should Audo significantly reduce or cease production of certain products. Furthermore, license agreements can generally be terminated by the designers or their legal representatives in the case of material breach, for instance if royalties are not paid when due and following notice from the licensor. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Our business is _in part dependent on our ability to negotiate, maintain and renew license agreements with leading designers on satisfactory terms”._ 164 -----

In May 2022, with the objective of consolidating our market position in the European market and in the U.S., we acquired Designers Company, a Danish holding company that included the brands Menu, by Lassen and The Audo. Menu and ByLassen designed, manufactured and distributed furniture, lighting, and accessories with a Nordic style and The Audo is a hybrid of a café, a restaurant, a small boutique hotel and a retail store in Copenhagen, Denmark. At the time of our acquisition, Menu was the group’s main operating company, which was responsible for the design, development and sale of design products, distributed to end users worldwide through resellers, including online distributors. Menu’s headquarters were located at The Audo. The café at The Audo and the restaurant were managed and owned by third parties, while the hotel and retail unit was self-operated and owned. In June 2023, Menu, by Lassen and The Audo merged into the new brand “Audo” with the aim of enhancing the Nordic-style design archives owned by Designers Company. The company is headquartered in Nordhavn, Copenhagen, Denmark, and also has a presence in the United States. Designers Company was founded in 1978 by the Hansen family under the name “Menu”, with a focus on the production and distribution of home accessories. Beginning in 2013, the group repositioned itself in the market by phasing out most of its low-price home accessories from its product portfolio and adding a wide range of furniture, objects and lighting products inspired by Nordic design. Starting in 2018, the group further expanded its offerings and acquired a U.S. distribution company to broaden its market presence. In 2021, Designers Company acquired “by Lassen”, a historic brand founded by the Lassen brothers, which also owned the rights to certain historic designs and iconic products. The brand was based on the legacy of designers Mogens Lassen and Flemming Lassen, dating back to the 1930s. Designs by Morgens Lassen and Flemming Lassen, which are archived at the Royal Art Library in Søborg, were reworked and relaunched as part of the by Lassen catalogue. Products under the by Lassen brand were characterized by a focus on producing and designing furniture and accessories that are of high quality, and therefore more sustainable. Furthermore, Designers Company acquired Brdr. Petersen in 2021 as a way to accelerate and further strengthen Designers Company’s offering of heritage and vintage products. The acquisition of Brdr. Petersen and original designs by the legendary Danish designer Ib Kofod-Larsen gave Designers Company the global right of all rights for Ib Kofod-Larsen products and archives globally.

Subsection Title: Common Factors Across Flos, B&B, Louis Poulsen and the Emerging Brands
Subsubsection Text: We own certain real estate properties, including production premises and warehouses, and we generally enter into lease agreements, including with respect to flagship stores. The term of lease for our properties is between two and 24 years on average. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we recorded a total of €21.4 million in rent and lease obligations. _Flos_ Flos owns four material real estate properties: the company’s 17,529 square meters headquarters in Bovezzo, Antares’ headquarters in Valencia of 17,961 square meters, assembly premises of 6,187 square meters in Collebeato and office space of 330 square meters in Milan. The Ares subsidiary also owns three production premises and warehouses in Bernareggio and a warehouse in Aicurzio. Outside of these owned properties, Flos generally enters into commercial lease agreements covering its flagship stores, corporate offices for its local subsidiaries and warehouses. _Louis Poulsen_ Louis Poulsen does not own any real estate and instead enters into commercial lease agreements covering its head office, production facilities, warehouses and showrooms. _B&B_ B&B owns two material properties, namely the headquarters in Novedrate and a manufacturing facility in Misinto. In addition, B&B leases under commercial lease agreements the Arclinea manufacturing facility in Caldogno (which includes the headquarters of the Arclinea business line and a training center), the warehouses for the storage of raw materials, semi-finished products and finished products in Carugo and Arosio and the DOS. B&B’s production operations are based in northern Italy, with three manufacturing facilities (the Novedrate and Misinto facilities which are owned and the Caldogno facility which is leased), one research and product development center (which is part of the Novedrate facility), three warehouses for finished products (one rented and two managed by third parties) and one rented warehouse for semi-finished products and outdoor assembly. _Emerging Brands Fendi Casa_ Fendi Casa’s production operations are based in northern Italy, with one manufacturing facility in Misinto (which is leased from B&B) and one rented warehouse for finished products (managed by third parties). Fendi Casa enters into commercial lease agreements covering its stores, including its flagship store in Milan (which includes the headquarters of Fendi Casa). _Audo_ Audo does not own any real estate. However, Audo has in place commercial lease agreements covering its head office, warehouses and showrooms.

Subsection Title: Common Factors Across Flos, B&B, Louis Poulsen and the Emerging Brands
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2023, we had 2,171 employees. Our success is highly dependent on our ability to attract and retain qualified employees. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Our future success depends on our _ability to continue to retain and attract highly skilled employees. The loss of key personnel could have an adverse effect on our operations”._ As of June 30, 2023, we estimate that approximately 20% of our employees belonged to trade unions and we believe we have good relationships with both our employees and their labor unions. We are party to collective bargaining agreements in Italy and Denmark and we believe that the terms of these agreements are consistent with industry practice. 165 ----- Of the 2,171 employees that we had as of June 30, 2023, 652, 419, 709, 194, 137 and 61 were employed by Flos, Louis Poulsen, B&B, Lumens, Audo and Fendi Casa, respectively. The table below provides a breakdown of our workers by function, as of such date:

From time to time, we are involved in administrative, legal and arbitration proceedings that arise in the ordinary course of business and may also be subject to certain audits by tax or social security authorities. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Potential liabilities and costs from litigation and other proceedings could adversely affect our business”. Moreover, from time to time, former and present directors, officers, agents_ and employees may be involved in civil and/or criminal proceedings. While in certain cases, there might substantial uncertainty regarding the outcomes of the proceedings and the amount of any possible losses and we cannot rule out that the claims or proceedings could result in rulings against us, we would defend, in any claims or proceedings to the extent necessary and prudent. Although the outcome of any of these legal disputes, administrative proceedings or audits cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not believe that the ultimate resolution of any current or potential matters of which we are currently aware will have a material adverse effect on our financial conditions or results of operations. As of June 30, 2023, we had set aside €2.1 million of provisions for risks and charges in connection with legal proceedings.

We maintain customary insurance coverage in our primary operating areas. We believe that we have adequate insurance coverage against all material risks that are typically insured by similar companies with comparable risk exposure. Insurance cover is regularly verified and adjusted when necessary. We have conducted a discerning assessment of various risks, distinguishing between those that are not feasible to insure on economically viable terms and those that can be effectively transferred through insurance solutions. In light of this evaluation, we have decided to buy insurance coverage for certain identified risks. Among these risks we have decided to insure scenarios such as those related to IT incidents that could potentially disrupt our infrastructure or lead to data breaches, thereby impacting our business operations. Such cyber policy allows us to get compensation for loss of profit, costs event management or third party claims due to a cyber event. However, we may incur losses that are not covered by existing policies or that exceed the coverage level stipulated in our insurance policies. Furthermore, it is possible that we may not be able to maintain adequate insurance coverage at appropriate premiums in the future. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Our insurance coverage could prove inadequate”.

We believe that we are substantially in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, including those regarding the protection of the environment and the health and safety of our employees, consumer protection and competition matters, data privacy, as well as the laws and regulations governing the manufacturing of furniture in the various markets in which we operate, based upon existing facts presently known to us. Compliance with local, national and international laws and regulations, including those relating to the discharge of substances into the environment, the disposal of hazardous wastes and other regulated activities has had and will continue to have an impact on our operations, but has to date been accomplished without having a material adverse effect on our operations. We have trained staff responsible for monitoring compliance with environmental, health and safety requirements. Our goal is to reduce and, whenever possible eliminate the creation of hazardous waste in our manufacturing processes. While it is difficult to estimate the timing and ultimate costs to be incurred for the achievement of such goal due to uncertainties about the status of laws, regulations and technology, based on information currently known to management, we do not expect environmental costs or contingencies to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations, competitive position or cash flows. However, as the operation of manufacturing plants entails risks in these areas, we cannot be certain that we will not incur material costs or 166 ----- liabilities in the future which could adversely affect its operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our _Business—More stringent regulations, including in the area of consumer data privacy, product safety and ESG could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations”._ We are also subject to laws and regulations governing the production and sale of lighting devices in each jurisdiction in which we operate. Specifically, when entering a new market or introducing a new product to an existing market, the product shall comply with the requirements of the applicable laws and regulations. Such requirements vary depending on the specific geographical area and may include a manufacturer’s so called “Declaration of Conformity” (e.g., in the EU) or a mandatory certification from the relevant authority (e.g., in China). Depending on the country of operations, the process may take from two weeks to several months. As part of the approval process, a change of the product to comply with the requirements could be necessary; furthermore, the relevant authority might ask for certain minor changes to the specifications of the product. Historically, however, we have not experienced any material issues or delays in connection with obtaining regulatory approval for our products. In 2018, the U.S. introduced certain bans on formaldehyde-releasing agents which are often found in, among other things, resins used in the manufacture of composite wood products, glues, paints, coatings and lacquers. As a result of these new rules, B&B adjusted its manufacturing processes to ensure that no such agents were contained in its products, thus demonstrating its ability to promptly adapt its manufacturing standards and processes to the highest industry standards required by the laws of the countries in which it operates, as these may change from time to time. Although this change did not result in any material cost increases, there can be no assurance that future changes in environmental, product safety or other regulations would not result in material increases in raw material costs or delays in production. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—More _stringent regulations, including in the area of consumer data privacy, product safety and ESG could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations”._

Since its early years of operations, we have shown particular attention to sustainability, as demonstrated by the publication of sustainability reports by Flos and B&B since 2015 and 2016, respectively, and by Louis Poulsen since 2019, and the publication of the first Group Sustainability Report in 2021. Sustainability is key to our business and our brands are committed to being recognized as leaders in adopting sustainable policies and practices and in developing a new concept of luxury high-end design that has sustainability at its core. As a result of this commitment, in 2020, the same year in which Flos and B&B published certain ESG targets, among which an emission reduction target aligned with the Science Based Targets initiative (“SBTi”), Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen achieved carbon neutrality in scopes 1 and 2 of greenhouse gas emissions, as set by the GHG Protocol Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard. Our focus on ESG continued to be evident in 2021 through the achievement of carbon neutrality in our own operations; Flos’ industrial plants obtaining the ISO 14001:2015 standard; and start of Louis Poulsen’s buy-back program of lamps discarded by customers. In 2022, the Group extended its efforts and achievements in sustainability by joining the UN Global Compact and achieving carbon neutrality in scopes 1 and 2 of greenhouse gas emissions. B&B Italia also implemented various sustainability-focused initiatives, such as the reuse of 100% of the scraps of polyurethane of the Novedrate’s production line for the production of cushions for the Nooch outdoor sofa. More recently, we extended the reporting perimeter of our SBTi scope 3 emissions, decreased the emission intensity compared to previous years, used renewable sources of energy for 78% of the electricity that we consumed and launched various new ecodesign projects. In addition to our sustainability efforts, our commitment to forward-thinking social and governance policies in the Group has led to 97% of our employees having permanent employment contract. We promote transversal committees that enable an innovative style of governance and foster dialogue by sharing information, projects, competences and best practices. With our international presence and shared values, the Group reflects the diversity of our employees. The variety of talents drives our competitiveness, our ability to innovate and our attractiveness. Our efforts toward a gender-balanced workforce have also led to 45% of our employees being women. Another example of our ongoing commitment to ESG efforts is evidenced by an increase of 20% in training hours delivered compared to 2021. Our commitment to sustainability is founded on the following three principles: - _Design for Planet. Through this pillar, we promote eco-design principles in all of our operations, establish and encourage our manufacturers to align their behavior with best practices and focus on the craftsmanship quality of the product and create more sustainable and eco-circular products. In addition, we are committed to contributing toward the fight against climate change. Our eco-design principles are 167 ----- embedded in our brands, such as Louis Poulsen, which has implemented a policy of reusing components of discontinued lamps to minimize waste. Similarly, certain B&B Italia products may be fully dissembled in order to reuse individual components (for example, the components of the Borea collection can be reused for more than 60%, or the “le Bambole” collection, which can be fully disassembled and more than 80% of the components can be reused), and Flos facilitates circularity by offering models made of innovative materials from industrial waste, such as Almendra and Skynest; - _Design for People. We promote a better quality of life, with a common focus on principles of creativity, quality and respect. Moreover, designers who are established at the worldwide level, as well as important workshops, work in close contact with our brands, creating synergies within a work environment that is characterized by equity, diversity and inclusiveness to allow each individual to express his or her full potential. Creating a thriving, inclusive and fair working environment is essential and among our key priorities. Within the framework of our sustainability plan, we set and monitor specific ESG targets on diversity and inclusion and people empowerment, to ensure that these principles and rights can be upheld at every level of our operations. As a result, we intend to hire new employees with different nationalities or backgrounds to increase both the diversity within our brands as well as continue to develop a true feeling of inclusion and belonging. - _Design for Culture. We seek to nurture our brands’ identities by preserving the craftsmanship, design heritage and quality of their products. Through an increasingly sustainable approach, we also aim to promote the historical value intrinsic in our brands’ most iconic design pieces, thus guaranteeing their longevity and durability. Our brands work toward driving innovation and research, further strengthening relationships with their community and promoting a culture of design. Under this principle, three Brands’ Academies (relating to Flos, B&B Italia and Louis Poulsen) have been developed as an instrument for accelerating hard skills development, craftsmanship and design mindset. In addition, Lumens launched the “Innovators Council”, featuring prominent figures in the design industry, selected for their unique perspective and experiences and with the goal of inspiring and educating trade and consumer audiences. We also generate value to communities around the world as a proactive actor in the communities in which we take part through the establishment of partnerships that create long-term social value, including, for example, partnerships with universities and trade schools. As an example, in 2022, Arclinea funded a three-year scholarship with University of Venice, Italy, for a PhD research program within the department of Design. Similarly, Flos has also established a new partnership with the “Fundación Universitat Jaume I”, offering extracurricular training programs to students of the university. 168 -----

The Issuer is a joint stock company (società per azioni) incorporated and existing under the laws of Italy. The Issuer was formed as a limited liability company (società a responsabilità limitata) on September 10, 2018 for the purpose of facilitating the acquisition of Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen and was converted into a joint stock company (società per azioni) by way of a resolution of the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on October 23, 2018. The Issuer is registered with the Companies’ register of Milan-Monza-Brianza-Lodi under registration number and fiscal code 10462810960. The registered office of the Issuer is at Via Alessandro Manzoni, 38, 20121 Milan, Italy.

The board of directors of the Issuer (the “Issuer Board”) currently comprises four directors. The Issuer Board is responsible for managing the Issuer in accordance with applicable laws, constitutional documents and resolutions of the shareholders’ meeting. The principal functions of the Issuer Board is to carry out the business of the Issuer and to legally represent the Issuer in its dealings with third parties. The following table lists the current members of the Issuer Board, together with their age and position within the board. These members will remain in office until approval by the Issuer’s shareholders of the Issuer’s financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023. The business address of each member of the Issuer’s Board of Directors is the registered address of the Issuer, Via Alessandro Manzoni 38, 20121, Milan, Italy.

Piero Canzani .................................................... 72 Chairperson Simone Berton .................................................. 42 Director Giovanni Porro ................................................. 67 Director Paolo Solari....................................................... 42 Director The following is biographical information for each of the members of the Issuer Board: _Piero Canzani. Mr. Canzani holds a certificate in accounting from San Marco college in Bergamo. From 1977 to_ 1982, Mr. Canzani worked as an auditor at Peat Marwick Mitchell (KPMG). After that, he has been working as consultant at Studio Riccardi Salom Tedeschi in Milano. _Simone Berton. Mr. Berton holds a bachelor in Business and Economics from the Università Cattolica del Sacro_ Cuore in Milan. In 2007, following his graduation, Mr. Berton worked for a firm specialized in Business and Tax Law. In 2016, Mr. Berton has joined the firm Vanzetta e Associati and has been collaborating with the firm since then. _Giovanni Porro. Mr. Porro holds a bachelor in Economics from the Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore in Milan._ Until 2004 Mr. Porro worked as an accountant in an industrial company. Since 2004, Mr. Porro has joined the firm Riccardi Salom Tedeschi and has been collaborating with the firm since then. _Paolo Solari. Mr. Solari holds a bachelor in Business and Economics from the Università Statale degli Studi di_ Milano Bicocca. In 2008, following his graduation, Mr. Solari worked for various law firms specialized in Business and Tax Law. In 2015, Mr. Solari has joined the firm Studio Vanzetta e Associati and has been collaborating with the firm since then. Gabriele Del Torchio ........................................ 72 Chairperson Daniel Lalonde.................................................. 60 Chief Executive Officer Massimiliano Caraffa ........................................ 48 Director Marco De Benedetti .......................................... 61 Director Roberto Maestroni ............................................ 48 Director Chiara Palmieri ................................................. 52 Director Dante Razzano .................................................. 74 Director Alessandro Varisco ........................................... 58 Director The following is biographical information for each of the members of the Design Holding Board: _Gabriele Del Torchio. Mr. Del Torchio is the Chairperson of Guala Closure and Labrenta S.r.l. Mr. Del Torchio_ served as Chief Executive Officer of Design Holding until April 30, 2021, when he was appointed as non-executive Chairperson. He was the Chief Executive Officer of Il Sole 24 Ore in 2016, Alitalia from 2013 to 2014, Ducati from 2007 to 2013 and Ferretti Group from 2005 to 2007. He has been a board member of, among others, Tecnica, Aereoporto G. Marconi Bologna, Sergio Rossi, Snai, Automobili Lamborghini, Permasteelisa and Tod’s. _Daniel Lalonde. Mr. Lalonde currently serves as Chief Executive Officer of Design Holding and member of the_ Design Holding Board. Mr. Lalonde was appointed as Chief Executive Officer of Design Holding in October 2021 and has three decades of experience serving in senior managerial roles at large international groups in the luxury goods sector. Prior to joining the Group, Mr. Lalonde served as the Chief Executive Officer and Director for SMCP between 2014 and 2021. Previously, he held various senior roles at several luxury goods multinational businesses, including at Ralph Lauren between 2012 and 2013, LVMH between 2002 and 2012, and Nestlé Nespresso between 1994 and 2002. Mr. Lalonde holds an MBA from INSEAD and received an Honour’s Bachelor of Mathematics degree from University of Waterloo in Ontario. He currently serves as Director on the Boards of Design Holding and PUIG SA. He is also on the Advisory Board of INSEAD. _Massimiliano Caraffa. Mr. Caraffa is a Managing Director of the Carlyle European Buyout team based in Milan._ Prior to joining Carlyle in 2004, Mr. Caraffa has been a Business Analyst and Associate with McKinsey & Company in Milan for three years, where he focused on telecom and financial services. He holds a Master of Science degree in Electronic and Telecommunications Engineering from the University of Genoa and an MBA from INSEAD. Mr. Caraffa currently sits on the boards of directors of the Carlyle Group, Golden Goose S.p.A., Astrum 6 S.r.l., TWINSET S.p.A. and Shield S.p.A. _Marco De Benedetti. Mr. De Benedetti received a degree in economics from Wesleyan University in Middletown,_ Connecticut in 1984 and a master in business administration from the Wharton Business School in 1987. From 1998 to 2005, he was Chief Executive Officer of TIM S.p.A. and from July 2005 to October 2005, chief executive officer of Telecom Italia S.p.A. Since November 2005, he has been a Managing Director of the Carlyle Group and he is also a Co-Head of Carlyle’s European Buyout Group. He currently sits on the boards of directors of the Carlyle Group, Moncler S.p.A., TWINSET S.p.A., CIR S.p.A., GEDI S.p.A., Fratelli de Benedetti S.p.A. and 170 ----- Marco De Benedetti Consulting S.r.l. In addition, he is a director of the non-profit organization Save the Children Italia. _Roberto Maestroni. Mr. Maestroni is a Senior Principal for Investindustrial’s advisory group, which he joined in_ 1999. Mr. Maestroni is or has been a board member of a number of consumer and industrial companies, including Guala Closures, Artsana, B&B Italia, Design Holding, Flos, Aston Martin, Stroili Oro, Ducati, Snaitech, Perfume Holding and Gardaland. In recent years, he has played a leading role in the advisory team on the investments in Aston Martin, Ducati, Design Holding S.p.A., Perfume Holdings and Stroili Oro. Mr. Maestroni holds a M.Sc. in Business Administration specializing in financial institution management at Bocconi University in Milan, Italy. _Chiara Palmieri. In addition to her role with Design Holding, Ms. Palmieri is a Chief Executive Officer and_ Founder of TACK SCF S.r.l. and also a board member of numerous companies, including Guala Closures S.p.A., Italmobiliare S.p.A. since 2017 and Snaitech S.p.A. since 2013. In addition, Ms. Palmieri was a board member of Poste Italiane S.p.A. from 2015 to 2017. From November 2013 to December 2019, Ms. Palmieri was Chief Executive Officer at Laprima Holding S.r.l.3 Prior to that, Ms. Palmieri has served as Executive Member of the Private Wealth Management International Management Committee at Goldman Sachs. Ms. Palmieri graduated from Università L. Bocconi in 1994 and then received her Master in Management at HEC Paris. _Dante Razzano. Mr. Razzano joined Investindustrial private equity in January 2004 and is currently Executive_ Vice Chairman. Previously Mr. Razzano spent 33 years in investment banking. From 1992 to 2003 he was a group director of Morgan Grenfell London (later Deutsche Morgan Grenfell) and established both the investment banking business and private equity business in Italy. From 1986 to 1991 he was managing director and senior investment officer of Citibank NA in New York and CEO of Citicorp’s Italian merchant bank and at the same time responsible for their continental merger and acquisitions activity. From 1970 to 1986, he was a Vice President and Group Executive at Manufacturers Hanover Trust in New York (today JP Morgan). Mr. Razzano is today a non-executive director at Design Holding S.p.A., Guala Closures S.p.A., Italcanditi S.p.A., Medical Technology and Devices S.p.A. and La Doria S.p.A. and he is the trustee of an English charitable trust. He is a member of “Roma Polo Club” and director at “Foundation Alta Mane”, a Swiss charitable foundation; he is also director of “Pinacoteca di Varallo”, an Italian museum of art and natural history. Mr. Razzano is “Cavaliere al Merito della Repubblica Italiana”, Knight of the Italian Republic. Mr. Razzano is both a U.S. and an Italian citizen. _Alessandro Varisco. Mr. Varisco obtained a degree in economics from Universita` Cattolica di Milano._ Mr. Varisco served as key account manager at Pagine Utili since 1993 and in 1996 joined the GTF Group. He became area manager for Italy responsible for the Valentino line and contributing to the company’s excellent results in revenue growth. In 1999 he became Italy sales director for Valentino S.p.A. From 2000 to 2004 he worked at Versace S.p.A. in charge of commercial development for Italy and Europe, later becoming their commercial director for Versace Classic and in charge of commercial development in Europe for the Gianni Versace line. From 2004 to 2008 he moved to Gianfranco Ferre` S.p.A. as commercial director for all the lines. In 2008 he joined the Sixty group’s newly acquired company, Roberta Di Camerino S.p.A., as managing director with the goal of repositioning the company in the luxury sector of leather goods. From 2009 to 2015 Mr. Varisco served as Chief Executive Officer of Moschino S.p.A. and he then joined the Twinset group where he currently serves as Chief Executive Officer. In addition, he currently sits as member of the board of directors of Giglio.com S.p.A. and Arper S.p.A. The management team that oversees the operations of the Group is located at the level of Design Holding and reports to the Design Holding Board of Directors. Daniel Lalonde.................................................. 60 Group Chief Executive Officer Alberto Toni ..................................................... 56 Group Chief Financial Officer In addition, we have also hired other central roles, such as the Group Head of Strategy, M&A and Business Development, Group Chief Digital Officer, Group Head of Contract, Group Head of Marketing, Group Head of Human Resources, Group General Counsel, Group Head of Marketing and Group Head of China, in charge of overseeing the overall operations of the Group and coordinating with each operating company. The following is biographical information for each of the members of the Group senior management team: See “—Design Holding Board of Directors” for the biography of Daniel Lalonde. _Alberto Toni. Mr. Toni currently serves as Chief Financial Officer of Design Holding. Mr. Toni joined Design_ Holding in 2023 and has over 25 years of experience serving in senior managerial roles at large international groups. Prior to joining Design Holding, Mr. Toni served as Chief Financial Officer at Bata Group between 2016 and 2023, which was preceded by his role as Chief Financial Officer at Deoleo S.A. between 2015 and 2016. Mr. Toni held various senior management positions in different regions at Heineken Group between 1998 and 2013, including as Regional Finance Senior Director for Western Europe between 2013 and 2015 and Vice President of Finance at Heineken Brasil between 2010 and 2013. Mr. Toni holds a bachelor’s degree in Business Economics from the Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore in Milan.

Pursuant to Italian law, the Issuer has appointed a board of statutory auditors (Collegio Sindacale), the objective of which is to oversee the Issuer’s compliance with applicable law and with its bylaws, monitor the implementation of best practices, and assess the adequacy of its internal controls and accounting reporting systems, as well as the adequacy of the supply of information to its subsidiaries. There are presently three auditors and two alternate auditors on the board of statutory auditors of the Issuer. Members of our Board of Statutory Auditors are appointed by our shareholders at ordinary shareholders’ meetings for a three-year term expiring on the date of the ordinary shareholders’ meeting called to approve the financial statements for the third financial year of their term. The members of the Board of Statutory Auditors of the Issuer will remain in office until approval by the Issuer’s shareholders of the Issuer’s financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023. 169 -----

Design Holding is a joint stock company (società per azioni) incorporated and existing under the laws of Italy and was formed on August 1, 2018 for the purpose of facilitating the acquisition of Flos, B&B and Louis Poulsen. Design Holding directly owns the entire share capital of the Issuer and is registered with the Companies’ register of Milan-Monza-Brianza-Lodi under registration number and fiscal code 10446470964. The registered office of Design Holding is at Via Alessandro Manzoni, 38, 20121 Milan, Italy.

The board of directors of the Design Holding (the “Design Holding Board”) currently comprises eight directors. The Design Holding Board is responsible for managing Design Holding in accordance with applicable laws, constitutional documents and resolutions of the shareholders’ meeting. The principal functions of the Design Holding Board is to carry out the business of Design Holding and to legally represent Design Holding in its dealings with third parties. The following table lists the current members of the Design Holding Board, together with their age and position within the board. These members will remain in office until approval by the Issuer’s shareholders of the Issuer’s financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: Design Holding Board of Statutory Auditors
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to Italian law, Design Holding has appointed a board of statutory auditors (Collegio Sindacale), the objective of which is to oversee Design Holding’s compliance with applicable law and with its bylaws, monitor the implementation of best practices, and assess the adequacy of its internal controls and accounting reporting systems, as well as the adequacy of the supply of information to its subsidiaries. There are presently three auditors and two alternate auditors on the board of statutory auditors of Design Holding. Members of our Board of Statutory Auditors are appointed by our shareholders at ordinary shareholders’ meetings for a three-year term expiring on the date of the ordinary shareholders’ meeting called to approve the financial statements for the third financial year of their term. The members of the Board of Statutory Auditors will remain in office until approval by Design Holding’s shareholders of Design Holding’s financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2023. 171 -----

The governance of the Group is strengthened by a centralized management team at the level of Design Holding (mainly, the Group Chief Executive Officer and the Group Chief Financial Officer). The following table sets forth the name, age and position of the current senior management of the Group.

Subsection Title: Compensation of Directors and Group Senior Management
Subsubsection Text: The total accrued remuneration of the members of the boards of directors of the Issuer and Design Holding and the Group senior management team for the year ended December 31, 2022 totaled €2.4 million, which does not include the remuneration of the Group CFO as he joined the Group in May 2023. The remuneration of the Group senior management on a yearly basis is equal to approximately €2.6 million, excluding the value of the stock option plan granted in favor of certain members of the Group senior management, as further described under “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Management Incentive Plan”. 172 -----

B&B is one of the world’s leading producers of high-end designer furniture for residential and commercial use. B&B was founded in 1966 by Pier Ambrogio Busnelli and Cesare Cassina and the first factory began production in 1968. Originally called C&B (Cassina & Busnelli), the company was renamed B&B Italia S.p.A. in 1973 following Mr. Busnelli’s acquisition of Mr. Cassina’s shares. The first B&B point of sale was opened in New York in 1976. B&B has distinguished itself since its founding with its innovative industrial approach to manufacturing, in contrast to the small, traditional artisan competitors that were typical of the home furnishings sector at the time. For example, in 1968, B&B became the first company to apply polyurethane extrusions to a 153 ----- metal skeleton in a mold, allowing for the production of shapes and for consistency of quality that would not be achievable with traditional production methods, and B&B’s iconic Coronado sofa became the first ever sofa produced using this method in the same year. Based in Novedrate in northern Italy, B&B operates from a headquarters designed in 1972 by the world-renowned architects Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers. B&B’s products have made a rich contribution to the history of Italian design, with styles that represent the union of creativity, innovation and industrial expertise. This approach has garnered B&B numerous international design accolades, including five Compasso d’Oro prizes, the most prestigious industrial design award in Italy, won in 1979 for Le Bambole by M. Bellini; in 1984 for Sisamo by Studio Kairos; in 1987 for Sity by A. Citterio; in 1989 when B&B became the first company to win the Compasso d’Oro in its own right, rather than for one of its products; and in 2022 for the SERIE UP by G. Pesce. In 2022, B&B also won the 2022 Wallpaper* Design Award for the Best Dining Experience. Entities affiliated with Investindustrial acquired 80% of B&B from the Busnelli family in 2015, and in 2016 B&B acquired a controlling stake in the Italian high-end kitchen design firm Arclinea (currently wholly-owned), creating a partnership that combined B&B’s innovative and design-led approach to home furnishings with Arclinea’s established pedigree in creating modern kitchens that are both functional and elegant. B&B has been part of the Design Holding family since we were originally founded in 2018. B&B continues to innovate in production and manufacturing techniques and in 2016 became the first company in Italy to install the “Versalis offline” unit, a completely automatic system for cutting leather. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and for the year ended December 31, 2022, B&B generated revenues from contracts with customers of €298.2 million (35.0% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers) and €284.0 million (33.6% of the Group’s revenues from contracts with customers), respectively. In recognition of its flagship status in the Italian design community, B&B was chosen as the founding member of the “Altagamma” organization, an association of prominent Italian luxury producers considered leaders in their fields and ambassadors for Italian culture and style throughout the world.
Certain affiliates of Carlyle and Investindustrial have entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the “Shareholders’

Subsection Title: Agreement”). The Shareholders’ Agreement governs, among other things, the relationship between
Subsubsection Text: Investindustrial and Carlyle with respect to their interests in the direct parent of Design Holding, (International Design Holding S.à r.l.), Design Holding and its subsidiaries, including the Group. The Shareholders’ Agreement provides for equal governance rights, whereby each of Carlyle and Investindustrial has the right to appoint an equal number of directors to each of the boards of International Design Holding S.à r.l. and Design Holding. The Shareholders’ Agreement also sets forth a procedure for Carlyle and Investindustrial to follow in connection with the joint appointment of the Chief Executive Officer and the Chairman of the board of Design Holding. The board of Design Holding has discretion to manage and control the business of the Group as it deems necessary or appropriate. All significant actions to be taken by the Group require approval of the board of directors of Design Holding, which approval must include the favorable vote of at least one director designated by Carlyle and one by Investindustrial. If a matter is not approved by the board of directors due to a deadlock that is not solved through the procedure set forth in the Shareholders’ Agreement, the relevant resolution shall not be adopted. Similar procedures and provisions apply to the decisions of the board of International Design Holding S.à r.l. Subject to a minimum investment multiple being met and following a certain period of time, in case of an unsolicited offer, either of Carlyle and Investindustrial will be entitled to sell and require the other shareholders to sell all of the share capital of Design Holding or International Design Holding S.à r.l. Following a minimum lock-up period, either party will have the right to sell the entire share capital of International Design Holding S.à r.l. or Design Holding through a joint sale procedure set out in the Shareholders’ Agreement or an initial public offering and, if such sale occurs before a certain period of time has expired, subject to a minimum investment multiple being met. The agreement also provides for the right of each of Carlyle and Investindustrial to cause an initial public offering of Design Holding after a certain period of time has expired, with the other party being entitled to participate in such an initial public offering. The Shareholders’ Agreement contains other customary provisions regarding confidentiality information rights and cooperation. Management investing in equity interests of Design Holding have entered into a separate investment agreement with Carlyle and Investindustrial setting forth the terms and conditions of their relationship as shareholders of Design Holding and the transfer regime of the shares held by them, as reflected in Design Holdings’ bylaws. 173 -----

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, each of Carlyle and Investindustrial, in equal percentages, have direct beneficial ownership, indirectly through intermediate holding companies, of approximately 96.3% of the share capital of the Issuer. Certain affiliates participated by the former management of the Group and a member of the Group management, indirectly hold, via Design Holding (and their respective investment vehicles, if any), approximately 1.3% of the share capital of the Issuer, and the Issuer indirectly owns, via Design Holding, the remaining approximately 2.4% of its share capital.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Certain members of senior management and certain other employees in key departments of the Group participate in a management incentive plan (the “Management Incentive Plan”), pursuant to which International Design Holding S.à r.l., Design Holding and certain managers (the “Co-Investors”) entered into tradable call option agreements with such Co-Investors. Pursuant to such tradable call option agreements, each of the Co-Investors has been granted three classes of options, each of which entitles the relevant Co-Investor to subscribe at a certain strike price new shares issued by Design Holding upon occurrence of certain triggering events. The value attributed to the stock option plans granted to the Group CEO and Group CFO amounted to approximately €3.0 million at the time of the relevant attribution, and the loan outstanding to the stock option plans amounts to approximately €1.0 million as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. In addition, certain other managers of the Group receive monetary incentives at the Group level through (i) investment in certain Group companies (namely, Lumens and Audo), (ii) letters of bonus granting certain senior management cash bonuses and (iii) a stock grant plan for Lumens management, where certain members of management have been granted stock options that will vest upon occurrence of certain triggering events.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: To provide protection to individuals serving as our directors and executive officers, we maintain D&O insurance for the entire Group.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Consulting Services and Recharges of Costs
Subsubsection Text: We have entered into a services agreement with our direct parent company, Design Holding, and Flos, B&B, Louis Poulsen, Lumens and Audo for advisory and coordination activities provided by the group senior management at Design Holding to us and the foregoing Group companies. For the year ended December 31, 2022, the Issuer paid €0.3 million to Design Holding in respect of these services. In addition there are certain pass through costs that are incurred by Design Holding and passed to the Group in connection with e-commerce, CRM platforms and other overhead costs. The total amount of these costs amounted to €9.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial and As _Adjusted Data”._ For further information, see “Management—Group Senior Management”. 174 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We enter into transactions with certain related parties or our affiliates from time to time and in the ordinary course of our business. We believe these agreements are on terms no more favorable to the related parties or our affiliates than they would expect to negotiate with disinterested third parties.

The following contains a summary of the material provisions of our Revolving Credit Facility and the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not purport to be complete and is subject to, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, the underlying documents. The following summary of certain provisions of the documents listed below governing certain of our indebtedness does not purport to be complete and is subject to, and qualified in its entirety by reference to, the underlying documents.

The Issuer as original borrower, and among others, J.P. Morgan Securities plc, UniCredit S.p.A., Goldman Sachs International, DNB Markets, a division of DNB Bank ASA, HSBC Bank plc and Natixis S.A.—Milan Branch, as arrangers and bookrunners (together the “Arrangers”), and UniCredit S.p.A., as Revolving Credit Facility Agent and Security Agent, entered into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement on November 9, 2018, as amended by an amendment letter on November 22, 2018 and as amended and restated by an amendment and restatement agreement entered into on October 31, 2023. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will provide for borrowings up to an aggregate principal amount of €140.0 million on a committed basis following the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions specified therein. We expect the Revolving Credit Facility Upsize will become effective on or around the Issue Date, subject to, among others, the Issue Date occurring. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower (subject to certain exceptions) under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in euros or certain other currencies by the drawing of cash advances or, subject to the appointment of an Issuing Bank, the issue of letters of credit and/or bank guarantees and by way of Ancillary Facilities (capitalized terms used in this sentence that are not otherwise defined in this Offering Memorandum have the meaning ascribed to them in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Subject to certain exceptions, loans may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Borrowings are available to be used towards financing or refinancing the general corporate and working capital purposes of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, including the financing of acquisitions and other permitted investments and capital expenditure.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contemplates the incurrence of additional uncommitted revolving facilities in a maximum amount not to exceed (after taking account of the commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility) the amount able to be incurred under paragraph (a) of the second paragraph of the covenant described under “Description of Notes— Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness”, whether as a new facility or commitment, as an additional tranche of any existing facility or by increasing the commitments under an existing facility in all respects. Such additional facilities shall be secured and shall rank pari passu with the Revolving Credit Facility. The lenders of any such additional facilities, if not already lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, shall be required to accede to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and shall have the benefit of the guarantees and Transaction Security (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). The availability, maturity, pricing and other terms of any additional facility shall be those agreed between the Issuer and the relevant lenders of that additional facility, provided that no additional facility may have a maturity date that is earlier than the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility unless the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility is amended to match that of the additional facility.
The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized until the date falling one month prior to the Termination Date (as defined below). 175 -----

The Revolving Credit Facility shall mature on the earlier of (i) the date falling six months prior to the scheduled maturity date of the Notes and (ii) the date falling 54 months after the Issue Date of the Notes; provided that to the extent more than €100.0 million of the principal amount of the Existing Floating Rate Notes remain outstanding on the date falling three months prior to their scheduled maturity date (i.e. on February 15, 2026), the Revolving Credit Facility will spring to mature on such date (the “Termination Date”). Each advance shall be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to a rollover netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the Termination Date. Amounts of outstanding loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility repaid by the borrowers may be re-borrowed during the availability period for that facility, subject to certain conditions.

The interest rate on cash advances under the Revolving Credit Facility shall be the percentage rate per annum equal to the aggregate of the applicable margin and applicable LIBOR, EURIBOR, CIBOR, NIBOR or STIBOR (subject, in each case, to a zero floor). The interest rate is also subject to the provisions of Italian law of 7 March 1996 No. 108 (Disposizioni in materia di usura), as subsequently amended and supplemented, and any related implementing regulations, such that if the interest (including default interest) payable by a borrower under the Revolving Credit Facility along with any fee or cost or other payments due to the finance parties thereunder, exceeds the maximum rate permitted by such law, the relevant interest rate or default rate shall automatically reduce to the maximum rate permitted to be payable under such laws and related implementing regulations. The initial margin under the Revolving Credit Facility of 3.25% per annum is, subject to a margin ratchet pursuant to which the margin on the loans shall be reduced if certain leverage ratio thresholds are met. A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility to (and including) the last day of the availability period for the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the then applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. The commitment fee is payable quarterly in arrear during the availability period, on the last day of the availability period and on the date on which a lender’s commitment under the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled. Default interest is calculated as an additional 1% on the overdue amount. The Issuer is also required to pay customary agency fees to the Facility Agent and the Security Agent in connection with the Revolving Credit Facility. Customary fees are also payable in respect of any fronted letters of credit issued by an issuing bank.

The Revolving Credit Facility (subject to the Agreed Security Principles set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) is secured by the following existing security: - pledge over the shares of International Design Group S.p.A., granted pursuant to a deed of pledge entered into on November 22, 2018 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, Design Holding S.p.A., as pledgor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - pledge over balance on bank accounts of International Design Group S.p.A., granted pursuant to a deed of pledge entered into on November 22, 2018 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., as pledgor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - assignment by way of security of the intercompany receivables arising under certain proceeds loan agreements of International Design Group S.p.A. vis-à-vis, respectively, Flos S.p.A., B&B Italia S.p.A. and Luminous Designs Investments ApS, granted pursuant to an agreement for the assignment by way of security of receivables entered into on December 17, 2018 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., as assignor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - pledge over the shares of Flos S.p.A., granted pursuant to a deed of pledge originally entered into on 17 December 2018 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., Cocoon S.r.l. and Fiore S.r.l. (Cocoon S.r.l. and Fiore S.r.l. now merged by way of incorporation into Flos S.p.A.), as pledgors, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - pledge over the shares of B&B Italia S.p.A., granted pursuant to a deed of pledge entered into on December 17, 2018 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., as pledgor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - pledge over the shares of Luminous Designs Investments ApS, granted pursuant to a share pledge agreement originally entered into on December 17, 2018 (as amended and restated on 17 June 2021 and as further confirmed, amended and/or restated from time to time) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., as pledgor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con _rappresentanza);_ 177 ----- - pledge over the shares of Louis Poulsen A/S, granted pursuant to a share pledge agreement originally entered into on February 19, 2019 (as amended and restated on 17 June 2021 and as further confirmed, amended and/or restated from time to time) between, inter alios, Luminous Designs Investments ApS (formerly, Luminous Designs Denmark ApS), as pledgor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - pledge over the shares of Antares Iluminaciòn, S.A.U., granted pursuant to a deed of pledge entered into on February 19, 2019 between, inter alios, Flos S.p.A., as pledgor, Antares Iluminación, S.A.U., as company, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza); - assignment by way of security of the intercompany receivables arising under certain proceeds loan agreements of International Design Group S.p.A. vis-à-vis, Lumens (formerly known as IDG Apollo Parent Inc.), granted pursuant to an agreement for the assignment by way of security of receivables entered into on June 17, 2021 (as confirmed and extended from time to time, including as confirmed and extended pursuant to a deed of confirmation and extension entered into on July 12, 2023) between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A., as assignor, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario _con rappresentanza); and_ - security over the equity interests in Lumens granted pursuant to a security agreement entered into on August 5, 2021 between, inter alios, International Design Group S.p.A. and IDG Apollo Parent Inc., as grantors, and UniCredit S.p.A., as security agent and representative (mandatario con rappresentanza). Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, proceeds from the enforcement of the security (whether or not shared with the holders of the Notes) are required to be applied to repay indebtedness outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility in priority to the Notes.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties, subject to certain customary materiality, actual knowledge and other qualifications, exceptions and baskets, and with certain representations and warranties being repeated, including: (i) status; (ii) binding obligations; (iii) non-conflict with other obligations; (iv) power and authority; (v) validity and admissibility in evidence; and (vi) governing law and enforcement.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain of the same incurrence covenants and related definitions (with certain adjustments) that apply to the Notes. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains certain affirmative and negative covenants. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which are subject to customary materiality, actual knowledge or other qualifications, exceptions and baskets.

Current reporting covenants include, among others: (i) annual reports within 120 days after the end of each fiscal year of the Issuer; (ii) quarterly financial statements of the Issuer within 60 days following the end of the Issuer’s first, second and third fiscal quarters of each fiscal year; and (iii) promptly after the occurrence of a material event that the Issuer announces publicly or any acquisition, disposition or restructuring, merger or similar transaction that is material to the Issuer and the restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole, or a senior executive officer or director changes at the Issuer or the parent of the Issuer responsible for the management of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries or a change in auditors of the Issuer, a report containing a description of such event. The affirmative covenants also include, among others: (i) authorizations and consents, (ii) a pari passu covenant; (iii) compliance with laws; (iv) maintenance of Guarantor Coverage Test and security; (v) further assurance; (vi) preservation of assets; (vii) insurance; (viii) maintenance of material intellectual property; (ix) funding of pension schemes provisions; (x) centre of main interests and establishments; (xi) sanctions/anti-corruption; (xii) acquisition of Targets; (xiii) notification of default; and (xiv) compliance certificates.
The negative covenants in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are substantially the same as the negative covenants in the Indenture. 178 -----

Subsubsection Title: Mandatory prepayment requirements upon a Change of Control
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is required to notify the Facility Agent under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement of a Change of Control (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), following which each lender under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement is entitled to require, by written notice to the Issuer, repayment of all outstanding amounts owed to that lender and the cancellation of that lender’s commitments. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any Ancillary Lender or, as the case may be, Issuing Bank may, as between itself and the relevant member of the Group, agree to continue to provide such Ancillary Facility or, as the case may be, Letter(s) of Credit (with such arrangements continuing on a bilateral basis and not as part of, or under, the Finance Documents and the Transaction Security shall not, following release by the Security Agent, secure any such Letter(s) of Credit or Ancillary Facility in respect of any claims that arise after such cancellation). Capitalized terms used in this paragraph that are not otherwise defined in this Offering Memorandum have the meaning ascribed to them in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires the Issuer to comply with a springing super senior net leverage ratio covenant, being a ratio of Super Senior Indebtedness, net of cash and cash equivalents of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, to Consolidated EBITDA of 2.50:1 (the “Financial Covenant”). The Financial Covenant is only tested on the last date of each financial quarter (each such date being a “Test **Date”) and only if, on such date, the aggregate outstanding principal amount of all loans under the Revolving Credit Facility (excluding non-fungible additional commitments and utilizations in respect thereof, utilizations made on the Issue Date and Ancillary Facilities under the Revolving Credit Facility, and utilizations by way of letters of credit (or bank guarantees)), less the aggregate amount of all cash and cash equivalents held by the Group, exceeds 40% of the total commitments of the Revolving Credit Facility (excluding non-fungible additional commitments in respect thereof) as at such date (the “Test Condition”). Capitalized terms used in this paragraph that are not otherwise defined in this Offering Memorandum have the meaning ascribed to them in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. A failure to comply with the Financial Covenant when tested shall not (or be deemed to) directly or indirectly constitute, or result in, a breach of any representation, warranty, undertaking or other term in the finance documents related to the Revolving Credit Facility or any default or event of default under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, and shall be relevant solely for the purposes of being a condition to the drawing of new utilizations under the Revolving Credit Facility (and new utilizations for these purposes, do not include rollover utilizations).
